Like Factorio, but 3D. Infinite amounts of fun, and hours of content. Have non-stopped played this game every time I get home from work until I go to bed. It is so addictive! I love watching my dyson swarm slowly grow, and getting excited when I find the next new thing to start making, or the next ore that makes my life 400 times easier. I'd highly recommend turning the resource amount up or to infinite (You are disassembling planets after all). I really enjoy how big the environment is, there are a lot of solar systems and planets to exploit. Many resources and fun to be had! I love the alternative recipes, wish there were more for some of the weirder crystals n stuff but hey! This game has a really nice vibe and I hope the devs keep it up :)

Would love to see an update where there's a deep-core drill, and it slowly takes resources from the planet itself. Irl, we'd disassemble mercury in its entirety to build a dyson swarm for ourselves. :)

Conveyors automatically snap to conveyors below them with no discernible way to turn this off (even if the conveyor belt doesn't have a connection possible there). I would prefer if conveyor belts only snapped to conveyors on their level, or conveyors with an open connection (as in an incomplete conveyor)

Only issue I have, I have 3 shells over my home star (Dyson sphere) and I'm making over-all less power than I would've if I just invested more into solar sails. Made 60 GW with sails, 60ish with the end-game power-generator???????? I think the Dyson Sphere needs a SEVERE buff. In reality it would be making enough to power that system for the rest of that star's life, no matter what you put down. (Its almost finished, goes up in smaller increments than the sails did). You'd think that if you put 60 GW worth of sails into a dyson sphere you'd get 60 GW.

Amazing visuals, gameplay and balancing.

Probably some of the best money I ever spent. The game gets regular updates including the latest massive Dark Fog update. It has an active modding community with some absolutely excellent mods. You can play it casually just building your production chains on the go and update them as needed or you can be like me and spend another 200-300 hours outside the game just coding and computing optimized builds. For people into that aspect of these kinds of games the sandbox mode (where you can build everything for free if you so please) is also very fun and an excellent way to build up your blueprint library and test your production chains. I now have over 1100 hours in the game and have all achievements done and I am still absolutely in love with the game.

It be like factorio but fun in single player. 
There used to be some issues with things being farther along in the tech tree than they should have been but they seem to be resolved now. 

Definitely a 10/10 for me. 
My only complaint would be that there is no ability to put down blueprints at a distance or to see other planets besides the one you are currently on. But that's more of a nitpick than actual criticism. 

Dark fog update: 

When I saw they were making an opponent to fight on the way to making the Dyson sphere I was exited. The video showed warfare and all of it filled my imagination. When I actually got there it was disappointing. I was expecting a plague but got a mild nuisance after I unlocked the missile launchers. These weapons have a limited range on their own but can cover an entire planet when paired with a station that extends their range and draws the fire of enemies. It also relays power and charges the mech. The invasions themselves are laughable. They spend all their time building up a massive number of units but then send out just a couple tiny units when the threat meter fills. There are also space invasions but I never got to see them even deep into the late game. All of this makes the other weapons obsolete. Why would I make them when I can just automate the production of the relays and build missile ammo. 

There is also the problem of the logistics which wasn't really that bad before the dark fog but with the dark fog I suddenly have an influx of new materials from the destroyed dark fog units which I'll never use because there is no easy way to transport them between planets. The planetary logistics towers only have 5 slots open to transport anything at all and only 4 if you want to bring in new space warpers so they can go between star systems. The dark fog many resources from simple to complex so if I wanted to collect all of them I'd have to set up a dozen towers and find a way to bring them the resources. There are ways of transporting them long distances with drones but each box will only allow one resource to be selected and won't change automatically. The only reasonable option at that rate is to make a track that covers the massive distances. 

Because the game seems to have a vendetta against automation involving drones it just ends up feeling unbalanced and inefficient. Even the act of having a logistics tower drains the power massively while not a problem if you have a Dyson sphere chunk in orbit already it becomes a massive issue if all this is on another planet. 

When you finally have the tech to build space fleets you don't command from the ground, you stick them in a slot on one of your menus and go close enough for them to deploy and wait 20 minutes for them to do enough damage to sort of stop the attacks. Even this is buggy though because if there are planetary bases the core instantly re spawns and even if that is dealt with the craft that floats above planetary bases isn't automatically targeted and have massive health pools. This means they stay floating their and the system is technically not cleared so they continue to be an issue unless you manually target them and destroy them with your own ammo which takes FOREVER to destroy even one of them. 

With all of that being said I cannot recommend this game in it's current state. 
I do recommend that you play factorio instead. You won't have space exploration but there are mods to fix that.

I know it says 166 hours at review time, but you have to trust me on this one. 

I was introduced to factory games by factorio a couple years ago. I hopped around, figured out that I really liked factory games, and started my search for some new ones. I played satisfactory for a while. As well as a couple other similar games. I stumbled upon DSP by chance, and I have never been happier. It might be because I have a slight fascination with Aero-Space industries, but I think that this is the single best factory game ever made. 

Way beyond worth what they are asking. 

The explorability of the vast universe is a bit repetitive, but it is nothing short of exciting to wander into the unknown. 

When starting out in the game, it is hard to grasp the sheer size of how large your factory can grow. In the beginning it seems almost impossible to cover the entire planet, let alone get to another planet. Boy are you in for a surprise. I have been playing this game for a while, and the stunning graphics and sophistication of the game still blow my mind to this day. 
While the game is advanced, and most likely hard to wrap your head around for new factory builders, it actually may seem easy for people coming from factorio. It is a little bit simpler, with less EXTREME sophistication. 

But at the same time, the slightly easier understandable logistics controls are somewhat of a relief, it doesn't feel like you are coding the drones to do certain things, you simply tell it to demand or supply. There are a couple options to fine tune, but unless you have an entire solar system, most of them are irrelevant until you reach late game. 

As you can see, I enjoy this game. A lot. I whole heartedly believe anyone that is invested in factory games, or looking into getting into them will absolutely love this game. 

EDIT: 100 hours later, nothing has changed. Didn't complete the game on my first few runs, I rather enjoy the earlier stages of the game so I've been restarting. 

EDIT 2: I'm in college now, and this game has become my outlet for a lot. Love these devs and this game man.

Thanks for reading, 

Pvt. Spencer

Fun game.  Similar to the other two members of the Big Three, which are Factorio and Satisfactory.

If you liked those, you will most likely enjoy this.  Similar gameplay loop, but you get to build a dyson swarm, dyson sphere, and artistic dyson """sphere""" around stars.  

Note that the endgame is structured differently.  Due to interplanetary logistics being far, far better than any other method of transportation, you end up just building cells that import resources for one item and output that one item.  Interplanetary logistics handles the rest.  Intra-planetary logistics are.... not great.  

Also, you can't have logistics curate your inventory like you can in factorio.  Logistics slots are artificially limited and cap out at 12 or so for no reason.  

Lastly, while the devs make huge efforts to keep the game's processor use low, eventually you're making thousands of items a second and the game starts to slow down.  For me this happened before I was able to get the big production achievements.

Despite the last few paragraphs being complaints, this is a fantastic game.  Recommended.

The game does not allow rebinding of certain keys, making it unplayable on non-QWERTY keyboard layouts.

There does not appear to be any reasonable workaround (I'm not going to install a third-party tool for this), and it appears people have been asking for fully rebindable keys for 3 years and the devs have not added it.

The best 3D chinese knock-off Factorio I ever seen. Conveyor belt spaghetti go brrrr.

The amount of micromanagement in this game makes my head fry.
It's like watching the inner mechanics of computers at work in a way that Factorio or Satisfactory cannot do.

How?
Engine black magic I suspect. The things you can do with this game logistically is another level for me than those two games. It has that right balance of 2D/3D to really highlight the vertical layering element of logistics. Factorio really doesn't do that and Satisfactory is too 3D leaning to be properly informative to me about these complex mechanics.

To emulate such system mechanics using programming (computer logistics essentially) is one thing. But this runs sooooooooo smoothly that I'm actually going to compare the optimisation to much older simulation games: Transport Tycoon and SimCity 3000. 

Why? 

Their level of optimisation made them run well on toasters. My low end gaming pc could play Dyson so smoothly I was baffled, given the complexity of calculations this thing must do behind the scene. I am truly curious how they did this... in Unity. 
CS and other games don't play nearly this well. It's kinda sad that you could get this level of quality with Unity given how it's recently imploded.

Truly a curious game from a program efficiency point of view. It shouldn't run this smooth but it does.

[b]Hours Played:[/b] 288
[b]Rating:[/b] Highly Recommended

If you're a fan of intricate micro-management and logistics, look no further—[i]Dyson Sphere Program[/i] is a gem that shouldn't be missed. With a gameplay experience that elegantly evolves from simple beginnings to complex systems, this game has captivated me for countless hours.

The developers have done an exceptional job, demonstrating a clear passion for their creation and a commendable commitment to their community. Their active engagement and responsiveness to player feedback stand out, enhancing the game's development journey.

What truly sets [i]Dyson Sphere Program[/i] apart is its replayability. No two playthroughs are alike, offering endless possibilities and strategies to explore. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of efficiency simulators or new to the genre, the game's blend of calm, cerebral gameplay and the satisfaction of optimizing your galactic operation is unmatched.

Despite being in early access, [i]Dyson Sphere Program[/i] offers a polished and ambitious experience. Its unique blend of 3D factory building and the grand goal of constructing a Dyson Sphere around a star for energy harnessing is both ambitious and engaging. The game's vibrant visuals and innovative mechanics make it a standout title in the genre.

At its core, [i]Dyson Sphere Program[/i] is more than just a game—it's a testament to the beauty of well-thought-out design and the thrill of optimization and expansion. For anyone with a love for strategy, logistics, and a touch of space engineering, this game is an absolute must-play.

[b]Summary:[/b] An enthralling and deeply rewarding experience that keeps you coming back for more.

For a beginner; This game is awful! It is so inconvenient to do something, because have so much to do by hand unnecessarily. It is a chore at the beginning.
- I want to place a building: "You can't not enough items!" -Okay, so I open the inventory to manufacture that building but I can't because I have to make a material by hand, because that game can't do that, even though the materials are all in inventory!
- Even if I don't have enough items (buildings) I want to place, then just produce it and place it automatically afterward.
- When research is done, you get a huge message right into your face, which block you from building. As long as you don't acknowledge this information, you can't do stuff! -> just a beep and a small information on the top, or let a research icon blink.
- Whenever there are more than one window open (inventory+storage or inventory+production window you have to press ESC several times to close them all -> just close them all on ESC.
- I'm not interested in what items are buffered in a building, what is more important is to see how many are produced per minute/second all the time, even when the buffer is full (zero/minute is useless when the belt is full)
- Let me silence that tutorial voice, it is impossible to tune it down!


+ the rest is okay, or awesome. I don't know, I'm still fighting with the controls and I'm still at the beginning.
A lot of people have compared this to Factorio, but this is so far beyond Factorio. If you didn't like Factorio but you're looking for a game to sink some time into this is definitely it.

Before the combat came out, interstellar logistics broke and stopped working properly; after combat, it is still broken for me. Personal logistics does not work at all; combining these two gives the impression of a broken game that will never be fixed and only accumulate more broken systems. Combining the broken logistics with the ball of annoyance that is combat, and one gets a souring and torrid mess.

the research system's faults are now unacceptable. The entire tech tree is built WITHOUT combat in mind. Each step requires one to "do things wrong, to do things right" namely by forcing the player into horribly inefficient methods of research in order to unlock substantially more effective ones. This structure works well in a game without combat as it adds a layer of difficulty into the research systems, but the combat system now turns these suboptimal periods into ones of intense vulnerability. Doing things "safely" requires a player to take substantially longer to do things than otherwise. Further, the fact that the combat system requires player presence makes planetary travel into a significantly worse timesink 

Combat lacks the ability to create planetary hangars as defense, there is no ability no control fleets remotely, there are no alerts about encroaching enemies onto planets or into systems. No ability to place patrols in systems or create static defenses on the dyson sphere itself. 

Atop the lack of alerts, is a lack of proper threat from the fog makes it feel "gamey". The fog doesn't attack logistics, (good for lack of defensive convoys). Nor are they especially smart.

I will admit, I could sit and watch the fog and player ships fight for hours, but having to physically be present takes away from ones ability to enjoy the fog as an enemy. I also like that while I can control where ship spawn locus is, I can not truly control the ships themselves on an individual basis, and I think that fits well into the game's ethos

The keys to making it all work are physically present, but not properly implemented.

How to fix?

Always have enemy units on a map rendered with ghosts. 

Use the Z mode in the map to control squadrons/fleets remotely while still using the spawn/nav point system, without complete unit control. 

Allow for convoy setups, using fleet control buildings placed on the towers to have armed ships following the logistics vessels at the cost of increased power consumption and warper usage. 

Create fog bases in the dark between stars that must either be found through "their shadows against the stars" or when they destroy logistics vessels that pass near. 

Have a visible buildup within a given system as the fog build new seeds, have new seeds be guarded in transit by ships built along side them.

-Don't just instantiate new seeds the second a hive has been taken out; its annoying, frustrating and unsatisfying. 

have visible hives feeding much larger hives you can not see (possibly have some number of stars on system creation be blacked out by dark fog bases). 

Allow the creation of military logistics stations made in orbit of stars and launched to other stars (as a reflection of the fog themselves).

Ow boy, where to begin with this one?

If factorio is good speed mixed with some adderal, then I think this game can be best described as grade AAA+ exceptional quality, pure and uncut cocaine. Like the really really good high end stuff they use on wall street and costs a million for a few pounds but is still worth every penny.
If you feel you have too much free time on your hands that you want to fill, or feel like you're sleeping too much and want to sleep a lot less, or have a happy social/active life that you want to nuke into oblivion this is totally the game for it.

So like factorio, satisfactory, shapes.io, or mindustry this is a game where you control a character and have to start from scratch to build a massive factory. This game doesn't have any form of enemies or combat (yet), and honestly I don't think it needs any to be an engaging experience.
Where this game differes from its peers is the scale of things. You get a whole planet to exploit for resources to start with, and after some research, you can start exploiting the rest of the solar system. If that wasn't enough to meet the resource requirements of your ever expanding factory, you can eventually research warp tech and star exploiting planets in nearby starsystems.
It's never not going to be statisfying to see fleets of cargo vessels travelling between planets and delivering massive amounts of imports. And finally, you can not just exploit planets but even the stars themselves (the title kind of gave that away). You start by launching a dyson swarm (thousands of little solar sails) that collects and beams power to your planet to feed your ever growing need for energy. Eventually you can start construction on the dyson sphere itself. It is a truly massive undertaking and will required a lot of time and energy to supply the gargantuan amount of materials to speed up contruction to a decent pace. Depending on your preferred playstyle you may see this as a positive or a negative.  
I personally enjoy looking for bottlenecks and finding solutions to increase efficiency/production/throughput, and this game has that "Hmmm I seem to be low on advanced processors, ah we are not producing enough regular processors, ah, we don't have enough silicon production, then I'll need new smelters. Ow smelter production could be a lot more efficient if I upgrade the feeder belts, lemme do that first, etc" -feel that makes you go for hours and lose track of time. 

Another thing in the game's favour: It's damn gorgeous. The systems planets and stars are beautifully rendered. The buildings, while being rather low poly have a clear sci-fi aethetic that does not look out of place and are thematically consistent. The lighting in this game is top notch and anything to do with dyson spheres or swarms is just shiny (both literally and figuratively).

Stability wise I was pleasantly surprised in that in my 40ish hours (the steam playtime thing is wrong for some reason) I haven't encountered any bug or crash. 

Though being in early access the game is not without its issues.  While most of the text info on research is legible enough, some of it feels like a poor google translation and will have you scatching your head as to what it actually does. Trial and error are your friend.

The logistics system in this game is less in depth than say factorio, so a lot of time will be spent going between containers to pick up items you need for expansion (belts, sorters, miners, etc). This game could  substantially benefit from a logistics network where your character can request certain items to be delivered if he's within a certain range, say on the same planet. This would cut down on the hopping from container to container-time that makes up the least enjoyable part of this game.

An upgrade button would also be very very welcome. Currently if you want to upgrade belts/sorters/factories you have to first delete the existing stuff and then redo the upgrade stuff by hand. A simple "click to plan upgrade" button would be very welcome in this regard.

I also dislike the contruction bots mechanic. When you want to build something you place stuff as you would do in any other game, and then a drone lifts off from your mech, flies over, builds it and returns to pick up the next item. This is tediously slow, even with drone upgrades. It also only works if your standing relatively nearby the construction site. You are also limited in build range, for not real reason I could phantom. I personally would prefer either doing away with the drone mechanic entirely, or maybe having construction worker hubs that you can place and who go about building stuff even if you're not nearby yourself.

Also produce are cubes with a symbol on it. The symbol is often waaaaay too tiny to be clearly readable from the regular distance, and the cubes are all samey. I think having proper objects to differentiate the different product you make would make the game much more readable.

For the current price I can highly recommend the current build. While not as polished as it could be (because still a WIP), it's a lot more polished than I had expected it to be by this point. I'm happy with the amount of content already on the game and feel like it's a great value proposition.

Dark fog update edit:
The dark fog update is not great so far. It's unfinished and you can very much feel that. There's a lot of tools missing to deal with the space side of the fog. The only way to deal the the space component is to fly out to them and fight them yourself. Which feels like a big mistake in a game all about automation...
I think they either should have adjusted the way the Dark fog worked until they finished the full combat update. Or just put out the whole combat update at once.

The biggest plus is the developer has provided frequent updates since release listening to what the community wants and giving options based on player preference. This game is seriously worth a consideration despite not having multiplayer.

Keep up the good work!

Having finally completed Dyson Sphere Program's main progression line, I feel that I can now give an apt review.

Dyson Sphere Program is a factory management simulator, similar in structure to Factorio, but with a little twist. Instead of one world to build your factory on, you now have dozens. Your goal is to automate the 6 science matrices by traveling to other planets and star systems, ravaging their resources, and solving the logistical problem of "How do I get this stuff from here to there?"

The first 1/3 of the game takes place in your starting system, and primarily the starting planet where the first 3 matrices will likely be produced. The other planets have resources beyond your starting planet, but the first big challenge is organizing the resources to set up interplanetary logistics to produce the fourth matrix.

Once all that is set up, the real challenge begins. Interstellar travel and logistics will be required to begin expansion needed for the last 2 matrices, and the only way to supply enough power for all those machines is to begin work on a Dyson Swarm and Dyson Sphere. The Swarm is easy enough, able to be produced with trivial resources by this point; and its power output is more than enough for medium-scale automation for an entire system. The penultimate challenge is the Dyson Sphere.

Once your first Dyson Sphere is around 50% complete, its power output will dwarf the solar sails you set up earlier. You can finally begin proper large-scale production for the final matrix.

Dyson Sphere Program's main gameplay loop is very familiar to those who have taken on Factorio, and the new challenges presented by an interstellar network of factories is frankly a massive breath of fresh air.

Nearly every element of this game is just as satisfying and rewarding as its Factorio analog. If this is your first automation game (maybe Factorio's graphics weren't pretty enough for you), It is easy to understand, and has a faster early-game anyway. If this is your second automation game after Factorio, the just-mentioned fast early-game will have you more hooked than the first time you booted up Factorio.

The graphics are very pleasing, the gameplay is just as stellar (pun intended) as Factorio, and the new challenges to conquer are not only a good excuse to explore the stars, but also just plain fun to take on. It just wasn't the first.

Dyson Sphere Program (DSP) may be the best factory simulation / strategy that I've ever played.  I loved Factorio, and Satisfactory was decent, but there is just something different about DSP that sets it apart.  Part of it may be the theme and what a sci-fi game makes possible.  If the game was limited to just one planet I can see where it would stack up with others pretty equally.  However, the options of finding new planets with new resources, biomes, etc. is just amazing.  Like real life Earth, it is very possible to run your original home planet out of resources.  You have to get creative with power management and efficiency.  When all else fails, you can fly to another planet to start building new production infrastructures, mining colonies, and resource stockpiles.  Then you can build logistics ships that can transport resources back and forth between planets.  When your home system isn't enough, you can then warp to other solar systems with all new planets and experiences.  You can even equip your logistics ships with warpers so they can travel between systems.  Literally hundreds or thousands of different planet options out there in the galaxy.  I'm getting closer to 100 hours of gameplay and I feel like there is still a lot more I can do.  

I will warn you though - this game is highly addictive.  It is extremely easy to be so immersed in the game that you lose track of time.  Too many nights I've been playing and look up to see it is past 2am, and I have to be awake again at 6:30am. ;)  Great game overall!  And to think it is still in Early Access... I absolutely look forward to what new content they come up with for this game.  10/10 would recommend!

EDIT:  I just finished my 2nd play through of the game, and I can adamantly confirm that this is my favorite city build / factory automation game of all time.  I've spent 265 hours on the base game including my initial game, and then my latest restart with the addition of "The Fog" combat system.  I haven't even looked into mod content for the game because I haven't felt like it was needed.  While the combat system is still in its early forms; I did think it added another layer of complexity to the game. Early on I found it frustrating because it was something I had to constantly defend against.  Later in the game though it was something that kept the game interesting and encouraged me to do something to break up the monotony of the late-game grind.

The devs seem to really be in-tune with the player base and they are constantly working on new content for the game. I definitely look forward to what they come up with next! If you  haven't given the game a try in a while (or at all), I absolutely recommend you do so. Hit me up if you have any questions as well!

At this point, I don't fully remember what I went into this game expecting. Some mix of Factorio / Rift Breaker / No Man's Sky, without the polish or ingenuity of any of them. What I got, however, was magnificent. Dyson Sphere Program is many things, and it does them all shockingly well.

[h2]Factory[/h2]
First and foremost, DSP is a factory/automation game. The game loop will be familiar to followers of the genre: collect raw resources, smelt/refine them into basic components, and continually produce more and more complicated technology based on an ever-growing factory; balancing power demands, addressing bottlenecks in certain materials, and crafting a giant spaghetti mess is the basic cycle.

And within that genre, DSP is a top tier entry, even boasting a significant portion of the quality of life features present in Factorio (what I would call one of the most optimized and streamlined games in existence). There are very few things I wish I could do but can't, in terms of actually building. The game handles 3 dimensions very well; camera controls are intuitive, blueprint mechanics are good (some room for improvement there) (I especially appreciate being able to manipulate blueprint files directly in the File Explorer), and there is a nice mix of snap-to-grid and free placement where appropriate. Being able to raise belts vertically adds a welcome challenge to organization, and is mostly just cool to look at. It took some time to get used to the mechanics of making complicated belt arrangements (you can use a hotkey to change the shape of the belts while placing!), but it was quickly second nature.

[h2]Space[/h2]
But beyond factory/automation, DSP is just a damn good space game. The first time I hit the warp drive to travel to an entirely different solar system, my jaw dropped. The sound design, the visuals, even the weightiness of the mecha while flying, the entire experience is superb. I immediately thought to myself, "this is already far better space mechanics than Starfield..." Exiting warp speed is just as satisfying, thudding back to reality just in front of the planet, as the visual dilation of space returns to normal. It's small details like that that sell the reality of the game. Even the bright trail of your interstellar vessels warping through the night sky between systems is just cool. The logistics system in the game is great, and while it could probably use some enhancements to deal with precise configurations, it's in a great place as-is.

[h2]The Sphere[/h2]
The titular goal of the game, building a Dyson Sphere is a rewarding challenge that will take a lot to complete. It's also one of the most mesmerizing sights I've seen in my [i]considerable[/i] time as a gamer. A planet with rows of rail ejectors and node launchers shooting into the distance to a massive growing sphere is just... epic. I have a dozen saved GeForce replays for the times I simply sat in front of my screen, watching the lights zoom by in the sky. The glow of the planets, the blackness of space, the brightness of the stars (and the [spoiler]black holes and neutron stars are super cool[/spoiler]), the sunsets over the planets... I continue to be absolutely stunned by the visuals of this game. What an amazing job by the dev team (who seem like a great team in general).

[h2]Combat[/h2]
A game like Rift Breaker clearly focuses most on combat -- the automation aspect is minimal. A game like Factorio focuses most on... factories. The biters are there to pester you and make you think about safe expansion and perimeters. In DSP, combat is somewhere in the middle, though it's closer to Factorio. There are bases scattered across each planet that will grow over time, and attack you as your energy consumption increases. There's a central space hive that interacts with these bases and attacks your planets as you build a Dyson Sphere in that system. You can wield different classes of ammunition, place a handful of defense towers, and, notably, maintain a growing fleet of ground-only and space-only ships to assist you in battle. It's immensely satisfying to fly out into space to meet an approaching attack force and to have your own armada zoom in beside you to battle alongside you. The Dark Fog update is recent, and I never played before it; it's also been announced that number of improvements are coming here, specifically to space combat. I can't wait to see what they cook up, as I certainly wasn't expecting anywhere near the amount of polish the game currently has.

[h2]Improvements[/h2]

These are all nits/suggestions. Not ONCE in 175 hours did I experience a single bug (outside of a planet taking a second to render in my sphere system when warping in during the late late game), crash, or particularly frustrating moment. Well done.

- damage balance: it can be difficult to judge when your shield is holding strong; when it doesn't, you simply die instantly, as your health pool is completely negligible next to a decent shield
- materials balance: Maybe need extra tiers to particle collider (strange matter)? And fire ice is infinite from gas giants...
- Sphere building: unless it exists and I didn't find it, there is a frustrating lack of convenience tools in the sphere builder page. Don't get me wrong, it's already far more sophisticated than I expected, with tons of options to do things by hand -- which is what I did. I built an entire max radius sphere, placing each node, edge, and sail section by hand, packing the nodes as close as possible. This. Took. A. Very. Long. Time. It would be amazing to be able to copy and paste sections of the sphere, just like you can ctrl-C/V buildings on the ground. I'm sure the team has a huge list of TODOs, and I don't doubt this will happen eventually.
- QoL:
    - an easier way to view the demands of each PLS / ILS on the planet or system would be great. I spend lots of time trying to find the specific ILS that is doing remote demand or supply for a particular material (this could be solved by better organization on my side in some cases, sure)
    - a way to copy the supply/demand settings for a PLS/ILS to another existing one
    - the statistics page for production/consumption of a planet or cluster is difficult to interpret; are the production/consumption values close because the producers are in excess due to low consumption? Or is it because the consumption is bottlenecked on low production? Or is it because they're both working normally at similar rates? A straightforward solution seems to be to include information about a potential maximum production/consumption assuming perfect supply input
    - let us blueprint gas giant collectors, please!
- the announcer says "turrets" like "tourettes", this is really silly :)
- mech customization sounds cool, but seems like it's in a bit of weird place between functional and aesthetic without clear explanation; I never ended up using it

Honestly, the optimization of the game seems top tier, and the statistics page is great for identifying your own bottlenecks.

Some performance stats:
- hardware: 4090, 13900k, 64gb DDR5 5600MHz, 2TB NVMe SSD
- 185k hash/s, 12.5k white science/min, VU lvl 73, engine speed lvl 21
- about 15 systems fully colonized (dark fog wiped out, most planets used)
- sphere stats: at any given time, 25k sails attaching, 10k in orbit; 12 million sails placed, 520k structure points placed
- 60 UPS
- 15-20 FPS with sphere on, 65 off
- 75 FPS on a typical supply planet (couple hundred assemblers/smelters, 20-30 PLS, ~5 ILS)
- 110 FPS middle of space
- from stats page: 9.5ms total, 4ms production line; saving test: 400mb at 1.09s save, 1.45s load

All in all, this is an excellent game, and [i]very[/i] quickly became my #4 top played on Steam. I had an absolute blast and wholeheartedly recommend the game. I'm stopping now, at least until the next big updates, but I'm sure I'll be back. Maybe then it'll surpass Elden Ring. Maybe.

NOTE: This is only relevant for people without the US-Keyboard layout. Also once it is fixed I will change this review to Positive.

Overall DSP is a fun Game, just like Factorio its a very cool automation game. This game gives you a bit more of a challenge in terms of logistics and space as each planet has limited resources and space, also you have to move your items around from planet to planet. I really like this concept!

The only real bummer is the wrong display of the Keybinds... If you're using an US-Keyboard layout this will not be an issue, but once you use a different Key-Layout the Game shows you key binds to different keys. For example:

< is , on my Keyboard - Ingame it display < but i need to press ,
> is . on my Keyboard - Ingame it display > but i need to press .
| is < on my keyboard - Ingame it display | but i need to press <

This is confusing at the beginning and seems like a Game-Dev beginner Problem... (This is the first Game I've ever played with such a problem.)
It confuses new players which are not from the US and should be solved by now. Also when you want rebind keys it shows you always the US-Key. So you need to have a picture with an US-Keyboard next to you to see where what stuff is bound too or slowly learn the US-Keymap... I understand if they don't want to auto detect it, but is it so hard to give us a selection ingame for the Keyboard layout we use for manual selection?

Also some keys are not rebind able, why? (For example the E-Key - Open/Close Inventory)

While it seems like a minor issue, its really annoying as Non-US Player.

3D factorio with weird grid and space gimmick.

If you like ransacking planets and stars building factory, buy this.
Tech tree is fine unlike many EA game with super bland tech tree.
With graphic in mind there were less frame drop and lags compared to other factory game.
Late game logistic is way way cooler than any other games. They're very pleasing to look at.
There's no building that purely focus on decoration.(Statue/Monument). Anything close to that is your Sphere and Belts.

Only 2 things I dislike,
the Metadata system (use to skip tech tree in next playthrough) it's quite not renewable.
Second, the GRID, yes its spherical grid closer to the planet axis the tighter the grids are so It's kind of force you to have big build inside tropic area.(Or if you love your Italian pasta *spaghetti* You can place it anywhere)

*Just want to add that the Non-Euclid Geometry is a cool idea tho I don't think it is exactly spherical geometry (I maybe wrong lmao) does support the sci-fi theme but it is quite hard to build on.

Pros :
- Gigantic map (64 f***** solar systems)

Cons :
- Such a gigantic map would fit perfectly for multiplayer
- Can we have teleportation to avoid spending infinite amounts of time to inspect all the supply chain ?
- Faster speed would be appreciated : 1000 hours to build 64 Dyson Spheres. Is that really a game ?

I've tried a few different games in the vein of Factorio, but Dyson Sphere Program is the only one I feel that exceeds it in some ways. While the tech tree of Factorio is a touch more interesting, nothing quite compares to the visual feedback and the great sense of progression that you get from Dyson Sphere Program. 

The visuals are gorgeous from the beginning, but once you start getting your Dyson Swarm going as a precursor to the Dyson Sphere itself, they take on a new beauty. Seeing that distant cloud of floating solar panels passing across the glowing disc of the star, you get such a tangible sense of how far you've come. Later, when you start building the framework proper, it's just so damn satisfying seeing the star slowly becoming encased in a delicate stained glass lattice of your own design.
Delightfully novel and straightforward.

One of my favorite games of all time. If you like Factorio, you will probably like this, but it also has its own unique charms and mechanics. The developers are also continuing to update the game years after my purchase, so don't let the "early access" status scare you away -- it's very rare to run into bugs and the game feels polished and complete in the important ways. It's clear that the only reason it isn't fully released yet is because they still have a vision they want to complete for it, but you can easily sink hundreds of hours into the game right now. The only downside I can think of is that multiplayer isn't officially supported, but there are mods which can address this (at least prior to the latest dark fog addition).
It is fun and if you have ever played Satisfactory and liked it you will like this one.
Best in class. I like it more than factorio even, but a lot of that is personal taste.

This game is now one of my favorite games I own. If you have any passing fancy in astronomy or astrophysics, even without the math part, this game is insanely cool. Building your first Dyson Sphere is an amazing feeling because, even though the graphics on a small scale are not all that, large scale graphics like planets, stars, and of course your Dyson Sphere are stunning. When I first saw the lighting effects of one planet passing in front of the other I just sat and stared at it for 10 minutes. It's a little daunting for beginners to automation games, but if you watch a few guides it isn't that complicated. Just remember: Materials consumed per recipe * number of buildings making the recipe / the time to produce the recipe = materials consumed per second, and materials produced per recipe * number of buildings making the recipe / the time to produce the recipe = materials produced per second. Once I figured that out things became a lot easier. DISCLAIMER: IF YOU'RE NOT USING BLUEPRINTS FOR EVERYTHING YOU WILL HAVE A CALCULATOR OUT AT ALL TIMES!

This game is extremely nice, i bought it and instantly sunk in 400+ hours. If you like Facotrio and Satisfactory: this game is definitely for you. Modding community could be somewhat more active (more mods) and the Blueprint Site really needs a Comment-Section for BPs and a separate Section for GalacticScale-BPs.

[h1]Game got redesigned ruining it for the original audience[/h1]

Bought this game because I wanted a factory game not a turret defense like factorio.
Now this game came down the same path. The developers are calling their audience "casuals" if they don't want combat.
As if there was anything casual about the sort of logistics torture people willingly sign up themselves for by playing games like this.

Being called a casual aside, disabling enemies isnt a viable option anyway because they are now a core mechanic the game is balanced around meaning it's imbalanced and poorly designed if we remove an element like that. Bringing factorio back as an example, it's boring as hell without its enemies because too much gameplay depends on them. This is why I originally picked this game over factorio.

Screw this game for changing its target audience and thanks for nothing.
Great factory sim, a nice blend of Satisfactory and Factorio. The only thing missing is automated trains.

Clunky controls, awkward UI where everything takes 2x as many clicks as it should, and the English voice acting/translation is NOT good.

For a game that throws a bunch of technical concepts and numerical ratios at you to have basic grammatical errors in tutorials and help text is really not okay. Simple concepts are communicated in a pointlessly complex way and the help/error text often makes things worse. Good luck trying to figure out how many items per second a grabber can transfer, or what angles/distances are permissible when connecting conveyor belts to assemblers.

I never expected a game to be able to actually simulate building of a dyson sphere and purchased this basis various reviews and recommendations. The fact you can actually build it is mind boggling. When you see your dyson sphere building up in the sky after 40 hours of effort, you get the feeling that you can get anything done. Great visuals, amazingly optimised, has a learning curve, go for it if you like strategy and building games. Switch off the war aspect and scale-up the resources at start if you don't like conflict and want to play casual (Like me)
Great Game!
Progress is sometimes slow but the game only gets better
You can perform gravity-assisted interstellar slingshot maneuvers.  That's all you really need to know!
Phenomenal game. Better and more in depth than 90% of most games that have been fully released for years. This will keep you busy and loving it for quite a while

Where Factorio can feel like copy paste the game, and Satisfactory drives the 'one more production line' mania, DSP is...a slog.  You are constantly feeling like you are not making progress despite doing so.  The tech tree before leaving your first planet feels disjointed.  It needs some polish.  Core loop, inclusion of the combat (dark swarm) feels good, but still feels like someone needs to spend some time playing first planet a few times through to figure out how to make it not feel as miserable as it does.  That said, if you expect this, good way to kill some time.

Great automation game. If you're not familiar with the genre, this is a great place to start. Factorio can seem a little overwhelming at first and I think this game strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and complexity. For an early access game, its amazingly polished and in 400+hrs I've never once run into a bug or had an unexpected crash. Even once you get a dyson sphere built and have covered several planets in machines and concrete, the game still runs really well.

They could stop development tomorrow and while it would be disappointing, you would still be left with a stable and fun game that would feel more complete than most AAA releases.

I can recommend it as a good factorio like game. It has unique features, the space setting is interesting and cool to look at. For "early access" it is bug free and has stable enough performance.

The game lacks some polish and should receive it until it is finished. The end game stretches a bit too long, the combat itself has problems (why have turrets when you can't form a front? Most of combat buildings are useless at the moment). and the game needs some more information about your base. Filter and search function (or high lights) for your production facilities would be needed - it is hard to find your base on a sphere. 

Also some explanations are missing - some buildings are poorly communicated and I've understood some of them after trying them out - after I've researched and crafted them. Would like to see their function before.

Own a destroyer for planet defense, since that's what COSMO intended.
Four dark fog bases land on my planet. "What the devil?" as I grab my missile turret and combat drones.
Blow golf ball sized holes into the first base with missiles, it's dead on the spot.
Aim my combat drones at the second base, miss it entirely because they got distracted by fog raids and nail the ground units.
I have to resort to the plasma shots mounted on my mech. "Tally ho lads" the shot shreds two relay stations in the blast, notifying the space fleet to attack the planet.
Prime signal towers and barrage the last terrified base with missiles and drones. It bleeds all of its resources since there's no relay station to supply it.
Just as COSMO intended.

I've played this game for over 12 hours now (my playtime is lower than it says because of pausing), and I am very much enjoying it. It feels very well-balanced; the combat isn't super-demanding and is pretty fun to plan for and execute; the factory-building is very smooth and streamlined, with the ability to copy large amounts of buildings and settings for easy transfer; the movement around the world and between planets is nice; even keeping your inventory stocked with items can be automated. 

If you like factory building games, definitely play this one. It's one of the best, and fills the "top-down 3D' niche between Factorio and Satisfactory.

I love this game as much as Factorio and more than Satisfactory. It's a fantastic game all around and probably the perfect viewpoint. You're large enough to be able to get around easily and see everything, but the graphics are very nice and clear. Progression is smooth and the game feels polished. You can tell a lot of work has gone into making DSP. 

DSP is challenging at times, but I don't feel like I have to have a degree in engineering in order to play it well. I used two blueprints I found online for energy production, but one of them was only to save time building a Dyson Sphere Shell and the other just made everything less frustrating and more efficient. Managing power is a bit of a PITA, but a realistic and necessary one. 

I haven't fought anything yet, but everything I have done has been tons of fun and keeps me thinking. It's great to come across something I made in the early days and see how ungainly and poorly designed it is and see how far I've come, both in available items and finesse.

I have loved this game from the start, it just sucks you in and days go by.

I would have loved to have some planets with civilisations so you would have the chance to decide if you wanted to leave those planets in peace or be a conquerer and just send down your forces and pillage.

But I guess you can't have it all.

Loved this game since early development, followed it since early days of release and I've been a big fan for a long time.

The Dark Fog update ruins that for me. I got no problem playing with some type of enemy in the world but I still want to the play the game my way, at my pace.

The fact we can't change the dark fog settings ingame is the worst oversight i could of seen for this update. This is a single player factory builder - and the Developers are locking difficulty for new and old players alike. Without giving any indication to what the player might be dealing with in dozens (or hundreds) or hours into their save.

I just waisted over 15 hours on a new playthrough, for that exact reason. And posts I'm seeing online of other people having the same problem it's pretty common at the moment. Am i gonna bother to return to this game again after this? Probably not - (this is my 3rd return to try out the game as its been developed)

Bad decisions like this lose long lasting supporters, hopefully they fix this oversight - until then (or this review changes) go play Factorio or something better balanced.

For some strange reason, this game makes me think of Three-Body, hit novel series turned TV series (not the Netflix one, the [b]good[/b] one¹). This is kind of Three-Body's ideological opposite: while Three-Body is a story of holding fast in the face of a hostile universe, DSP is about fulfilling humanity's greatest dream, englobing and harnessing the full power of the stars.

In that vein, my favourite thing about this game is that it actually has a point. So many factory games are about nothing more than expanding your factory's expansion capabilities, but this? This has a [i]goal[/i]. That alone makes it actually playable for me. The sci-fi flavouring and epic scale of that goal is just icing on the cake by comparison.

¹ - Note to self: correct this statement if the Netflix series turns out good. Unlikely but possible.

I wouldn't have bought the game by seeing the videos, but a friend of mine told me that if liked Factorio I had to get this game, and he was not wrong. Same mechanics than Factorio, only that you can get out to space and mine other planets.

You start the game, you make mistakes, you progress, you unlock new technologies, you look back and see severe mistakes but it's working and you're afraid to change anything, you move on, slowly you create a factory with duct tape and pray power, you inevitably run out of power and the factory doesn't turn on anymore, you panic, the dark hive starts attacking your planet with lasers and drones, you slowly start to recover enough just to barely make it work, under pressure you find ways to increase power generation, you succeed and have way more power than you need, you progress further and gain confidence you actually know what you're doing, you push the darkfog out and you start building a Dyson sphere, you start cultivating more and more resources from other planets, you make back and forth trips to other solar systems because you keep forgetting basic stuff to start up a base.

Eventually you actually finish the game, looking back and wishing you would have done things differently.

100% would recommend this game, it's absolutely amazing!

As fun as the game can be I felt the game was just lack luster in the redundancy of certain elements. Spaghetti is hard to contain on your first world until you have reached a good degree of automation since the conveyor belts can only carry one item at a time. Another portion that got to me was being unable to set up a splitter in a sense. Where you could make 2 lines of belts from 1. The issue being over congested in some areas and being unable to divert slight excess amounts to areas in need of said basic resource. 

Once you reach the logistics drones though you can set yourself up with a district design that nulls out most problems. Just how a district manufacturing a specific resource at all times and you can copy paste it down as needed similar to factorio.

**REVIEW UPDATE Jan 14, 2024**
It's here!! Combat is finally here! 
I have been waiting these last 3 years for it and what can I say except that it's AMAZING. 
As with previous features, the devs have outdone themselves (again) and built into the game a full combat system where you battle the ominous 'Dark Fog' forces, both on planets and in space. 

Apart from that, the last ~36 months have seen many major improvements and some additions to the game, apart from combat. 
Things like buffing your belts by spraying them with 'power paint'. Extensive blueprint system. A complete new transport system that is accessible earlier and more readily than the transport towers. You can now use small transport drones quite early in the game instead of belts. 
And so much more.

I am fully hooked once more, the only downside I see is that the Dark Fog right now is kind of an automated progress check that scales with you. If you set the 'difficulty' too low, it will never be any real challenge. Would be great if the AI could evolve independantly from the player and come up with nasty surprises now and then. 
But hey, the devs already promised to expand on combat so I'm good!

Seriously guys, if you ever, anywhere, anywhen, played and liked any industry game, this one is a MUST BUY.



**Jan 26, 2021**
If Factorio, Satisfactory and Empyrion had a child, it would be DSP :D

You notice at every point in the game that the devs have extensively played other genre titles and added a LOT of stuff that was missing in the competition (and indeed, some of it still is), particularly if you don't like mods. Compared to the other games, DSP is polished and fluid right from the start.
I have never seen such a clean planetary (and later on, interstellar) supply network. The idea of combining splitter, sorter and prioritizer in one machine itself is nobel price-worthy. And there are so many of these seemingly small quality of life enhancements that sum up to a really smooth game experience - without sacrificing complexity!

Yes, this is Early Access. There is no combat (yet) and if you look hard, then you'll find some features that are missing. For example, there's no way to overwrite conveyors with other tiers so currently you have to delete it, then build anew. The supply network drones will, if forced through low supply, fly even for a single item so that could be improved because it's highly inefficient in terms of power consumption. There are also as of now no templates, so you cannot copy-paste sections of your industrial landscape.
But really, it's DIFFICULT to find clear signs of Early Access. 

I have only just started settling a 2nd planet and it's already so much fun! Get it!

Update Feb 16: I now have over 90h into the game and have stopped. Why? It's an AMAZING adventure but for me, longtime motivation comes mostly from being challenged externally. Building for the fun of it is definitely the biggest part of DSP now. I will wait for combat to arrive, then as sure as hell I'll get hooked again and never, ever be free :D

"Dyson Sphere Program" is a real-time strategy (RTS) and automation game developed by Youthcat Studio. Released in January 2021, it has gained popularity for its unique concept and engaging gameplay.

The game revolves around the construction of a Dyson Sphere, a megastructure that encircles a star to harness its energy. Players start on a single planet and gradually expand their reach to other celestial bodies in order to gather resources and advance their technological capabilities.

One of the standout features of Dyson Sphere Program is its automation mechanics. Players can design intricate production lines and automate resource gathering, refining, and crafting processes. The complexity and scale of automation can be both challenging and satisfying, appealing to fans of factory-building games.

The game's graphics and art style are visually appealing, creating a sense of scale as players build massive structures across planets. The soundtrack complements the futuristic theme and adds to the immersive experience.

While the game has received positive reviews for its innovation and depth, some players have found the learning curve steep due to the intricate automation systems. Additionally, there have been occasional reports of bugs and optimization issues, though the developers have been active in addressing these through updates.

In summary, Dyson Sphere Program offers a compelling mix of automation, resource management, and strategic planning, making it a recommended choice for fans of the genre. The game's ongoing support and updates suggest a commitment to refining and expanding the player experience.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Drop in a bucket, but this needs to be said.

Fair warning: I basically come from Satisfactory (and I love it), and I never played Factorio because the 2D world didn't feel inviting.

The horrible user experience I had during my two hours of gameplay was just too much; I had to request a refund.  For this I believe there are two main culprits: the extra step in constructing buildings, and keybind hell.

Unlike Satisfactory, here you don't just "craft" materials, you "craft" buildings!  Meaning, even though you may have all the materials for a given building, when you go to place one down, you'll be asked to go in the Fabricator and "craft" the building first, then place it down.  To me, a casual gamer who likes a streamlined UX, this was a rather big disappointment.

As for keybinds, I guess my problem stems from the added camera complexity of a 3rd person game.  In any case, I constantly struggled with the controls, and I'm sure this is at least in part due to my being a casual gamer.

Actually, another big problem I had which is related to keybinds, is the constant "double click" to place down buildings.  Maybe I'm just too used to Satisfactory and its custom toolbars, but having to constantly select a building type and then the actual building I want to put down, was a chore.

I mean, if you have all the time in the world you can take the time to get used to it all, but my free time sure isn't what it used to be, so I lost patience very quickly.

In conclusion, if you're a Satisfactory fan and not a Factorio fan, beware the stark difference in UX.  It might be even better for you, but it was way worse for me.

So this was my first intro to the factory game genre and little did i know the kind of grip this type of game loop could have on you!
For DSP the devs have been amazing with semi regularly releasing DLC sized updates while maintaining a rock solid engine, please give this a try!!!

This game is very addictive if you enjoy the survival game resource hunt, basically, find resource, get resource, build cool thing to get more resource, build more things, find more resources. The game even with this modest loop is enough to easily sink hundreds of hours into which is more than I can say about a lot of games.

The positives:
The gameplay itself is very smooth, the tech tree is pretty straight forward it's very obvious what needs what and what does what
Even someone with no real background can intuitively understand the basics
Just getting to a second planet is probably enough to get more than your value out of this game

The deltas or things I want to see:
Given the Developer is actually active there's a few things I sort of wish that they decide to do.
1. Co-Op mode. This may be complicated to do but it is very very worthwhile. The ability to play with friends and exchange resources would easily pump much more gameplay into this game. As it stands there's a lot of folks who will never try this game but would if their BFF was playing. I've played this with my partner but the lack of interaction even playing side by side makes it less of an interest for her.
2. Variability in planets - Right now there's planets which are akin to Biomes of most games, they spawn at a semi regular interval with differing characteristics which is neat. However every planet is exactly the same size and it gets to the point really quickly where the only thing you care about is setting down some miners and leaving. The home system you start with is honestly a pretty terrible place but unless you're keen on losing hundreds of hours of play moving elsewhere is simply not feasible. There's no way to really 'improve' existing planets, about the best you can do is pave over everything and turn it into a super dense building planet. Something as simple as smaller and larger planets would be so much more interesting. Also if we can build a dyson sphere multiple astronomical units in size, can we maybe build a planet? I'd love to be able to say, yeah my home system is shit but I built three new planets and now it rocks.
3. Variability towards the same end - As it stands there is no real variability which prevents certain ideas, want to have a cooler starting area than the original Terra world? Wana start on a lava planet? A Blackhole? etc. you can't really do a lot of this because of the gated nature of the game meaning you can't get key resources without which you can't really progress to the next stage or if you force it you're super hobbled for hours while you try to do something which is pretty easy otherwise. For example there's like 3 ways to get refined oil, there's like six ways to get energetic graphite. There's no way around the fact your planet doesn't have oil. Coal seems to exist almost everywhere (which is sort of weird). Meanwhile something as simple as Hydrogen, literally the most common resource in the universe (which we can make with water and two electrodes) can't easily be harvested for a ridiculously long time.
4. Please please give us factions. The dark hives are cool but I couldn't really care much about fighting them. What I would give for someone I could exchange resources with, an AI planet I can make friends with or even my own 'people' (whatever those may be)
5. Lastly a lot better tutorial, currently it's nearly impossible to get into the mid game without following a youtube tutorial, which great if you stuck around that long but if you didn't you're missing out a lot. A little bit of a guide on how to upscale your structures, how to prioritize next steps efficiently, how to design things intelligently or even how to make a dyson sphere (the name of the game) would be so nice. In the end I copied a bunch of people's blueprints cause the time sink to do this myself was not worth the payoff which is a shame. Much more importantly there's like a dozen different commands and shortcuts which are not explained ever in the game. The number of people who don't know how to copy paste a recipe, or settings, or auto fill with drones or ships is staggering.

Overall I would recommend you buy this game. My asks are just asks because I believe a whole lot more people could be playing this game and would play this game if the developer addressed them. I look forward to the future they come up with.

I have tried to like this game and revisited it twice but this game is not for me. Its in the same category as Factorio and Satisfactory (and plenty others) but its worse than both of them. DSP has some really neat features and it does shine at times, but I do not recommend it. If you really want 3D spaghetti go play satisfactory but if you really want to travel to space in Factorio then go play the space exploration mod (or wait for the DLC). If you want to play the game, just buy it. If you want a reason not to play the game, read the rant below...

[b]This is Factorio except...[/b]
... The buildings have a fixed size while the grid has a dynamic size, this is an absolute nightmare. The grid on which you place things slowly converges since in DSP you're building on a globe (like Super Mario Galaxy). This is a neat and novel concept but it breaks the game in so many ways. As you travel away from the equator the entire grid slowly shrinks but the buildings you place do not. When placing buildings back-to-back either there could be enough space in between for an entire powerpole while sometimes there is not. Sometimes even an inserter-tube wont fit and sometimes even the 2nd factory wont fit. This reduced me to tears several times. It is such a hassle to make nice orderly Factoies in DSP.
... Blueprints cant be used everywhere.  Blueprints can only be designed for (and used on) a certain gridsize. If you have the perfect factory then there is very little chance of being able to reuse it because you can only really paste that blueprint on the same latitude. Don't expect to be able to use it in any other location. This really defeats the purpose imo. 
... Blueprinting doesn't work for conveyors/ inserters. Disclaimer: this one could very well by my own fault. My factories are mostly modular, a chain of repeating segments. Need more throughput? Just paste another segment at the end. When pasting a new segment, but belts would never connect. If the existing belts would overlap with the blueprint the game would complain "unable to place blueprint" and when force-printing they would not connect the belts. If you place all the belts beforehand and then just blueprint the buildings over that, then the inserters wont get placed. In my experience you would always have to 'fix' your factories after you blueprint them. That is not how its supposed to work. The workflow should be design-build-copy-paste-paste-paste. Instead in DSP it was always design-build-copy-paste-build-paste-build etc etc. 
... Your character has a hunger meter. I don't know why this exists but you have to fuel your mech or the game will pushing you and stop you from playing the game. Alarms go off, the screen blinks red and you mech slows down and cant perform most actions. Trees count as earlygame fuel, you can build fancy high-density powercells later and you can build wireless charging spots so most of the time its fine. There is no upside to this mechanic, its completely trivial and if you run out of fuel while you're trying to deal with attackers your weapons switch off, you die and its game over. To me, this is not a good game mechanic! Please just copy what Valheim did!
... You have less than 10 logistics request slots. I mean, come on. You're gonna be handcrafting all day or flying back and forth to your mall the whole time. Both of these drain your energy, etc, etc,

The "next" factorio but with the new dark fog it has now added more Tower Defense to the game which has made the game more fun and added in an extra challenge. An excellent progression system that gives you something new to do as you expand, the sense of scale is well established. Unlike other base building / automation games, you can easily build a reasonably efficient base without having to watch hours of videos or do tutorials but at the same time there is a huge depth to the game if you really want to be as efficient as possible or speed run the game. 

Still in early access, more dark fog features such as better space combat, are coming. Updates for features, bug fixes and rebalancing are frequent and there are no signs of the devs slowing down. A game for any fan of automation, base building and tower defense.

If you like the automation genre (you like factorio), this game is for you. Don't let the initial "cheap/cartoony" look fool you (it still looks amazing, don't get me wrong, and I was proven wrong after some play, the machines look amazing), this game delivers. Intuitive, clean, responsive and fast gameplay that really builds on the genre. The recent combat update has added a ton of cool ways to play and a lot more to deal with, it's become as quality of a tower defense/borderline rts as it is an automation game. Don't skip this one, I almost did, and now I'm addicted after 200 hours of Factorio and 1000 hours of Satisfactory, it more than lives up to these games, it expands on it! I say again, DO NOT SKIP THIS ONE!!!

DSP is a charming take on the factory builder genre that builds nicely on its core conceit of spanning multiple planets and systems within a star cluster. The devs have continued to provide interesting goals to work for along with a fun variety of logistics as you progress through the tech tree. I stepped away from the game early due to performance issues but have been happy to see consistent work on that front and the game handles like a dream now. Between swarms of drones, personal energy management, and the ability to build a long queue of personal fabrication work that completes automatically alongside other tasks, the game provides a wonderful sense of being a massive, self-sufficient mecha. I haven't made a new save to face the Dark Swarm yet, but Let's Plays videos lead me to believe it will be a compelling parallel progression alongside the eponymous dyson sphere construction. I only hope to see a kaiju menace appear someday too :)

It's a pretty solid factory management simulator game.  As of the Dark Swarm Update, the game still needs some serious work but overall it's quite fun and I can't wait for it to be as fleshed out and polished as Factorio.

My Major Issues (as of 01/08/2024)
1. Dyson Swarms having a timed life means that they are essentially wasted resources from the moment you unlock them (early game) until tens of hours later after you can actually build the Dyson Frame.  A much more sensible progression would be to replace their timed life with an upper limit on how many you're allowed so the concept of maintaining and upgrading your Dyson Swarm stays relevant throughout the game and not just ignored until the end.

2. Grid/UI quirks.  So many quirks.  A blueprint designed at the equator should not randomly stop working if you paste it north 30 tiles.  Belts and sorters and their random contortions and refusals to behave consistently were by far the least fun and most frustrating part of this game for me.  

3. Proliferation needs a major rework.  As it stands, Proliferation is too cheap and easy to implement the massive returns it gives.  You also solve it exactly once and use the same "blueprint" for the remainder of your play through.  It Completely removes any potential interactivity with tradeoffs between efficiency, productivity, and speed.

It's a super fun factory game with honestly a scale I wasn't expecting at first. It'll start off like any other factory game, you'll be hand crafting a lot but the moment you start unlocking that first bit of technology, oh boy do things ramp up quickly. The new Dark Fog combat is also pretty well done, even the base turrets with basic ammo feel impactful at defending your bases, they are easy to keep fed with ammunition but the balance of what turrets should be used instead of just spamming as many of one is a great system. It's balanced through the ammunition supply you have so unless you practically dedicate an entire factory/planet to ammunition creation (which I have no doubt will be a thing I will do in the future), it's easier to have a few different ammuntions at play so every turret outpost you make keeps firing when the Dark Fog arrives en masse.
Production, resource mgmt, and optimization along with some pretty fun game-play loops and graphics. If these are what you're looking for, you've found the best game!

I was really excited about Dyson Sphere Program when it first came out as something between Factorio and Satisfactory just on a galactic scale. But 3 years later I'm kinda disappointed, and after playing a couple of sessions after the combat update I've been finding myself wanting to play Factorio or Satisfactory instead.

Part of the problem with DSP is the constant awkward interfaces and controls that make it harder to engage with the game, or the stilted awkward voice-overs that feel like they're being read by an AI, but a bigger part is that the gameplay doesn't feel that rewarding. 
Research is very bloated and uninspired so it's more tedious and time consuming than it should be, planets are all similar with only a few differences in resources so it's more annoying than anything to need to go to different planets, and there really isn't an overarching goal that you feel like you're building toward (besides maybe building a Dyson sphere around all 64 suns, which would take 100's of hours).

I really want it to be better, but it just isn't there and the changes made over the last 3 years seem to lean more and more into these same problems without polishing things up to make the game more engaging and fun.

Yes, yes, YES!! What a beautiful game. Some cons at the end of the review, but just buy it and try it, it's so good! A mix between factorio and satisfactory style logistics, the research tree and upgrade trees are interesting, the pulled back view of your factory(ies), being able to see an overhead view of many buildings at once makes it way less intimidating than satisfactory (for me). The pacing of new items and logistical challenges for routing belts and clustering certain buildings together feels very natural and enjoyable. The ability to launch into space whenever you want is really fun, I'm looking forward to further space exploration and setting up different planets. 

The enemies are rather lame at the moment, they'd probably be more interesting on difficulties higher than normal. Deleting items from inventory is possible but super clunky, deleting belts is pretty annoying, and realizing you can store hydrogen as a liquid is sorta....meh? I don't know why that irked me, but honestly, overall, an incredible game with beautiful scale and such fun, impressive logistic options.
Great way to lose yourself for a day.

I came back with the dark fog update (because I love a little enemy in my factory game), but the research tree being atrocious was a final staw ruining it (you can **often**, research things you cannot produce).

Enemies seem at this point to weak, but that is to be expected as they just added them in, which is probably the best way to add them, but speak to that this is EA and one should wait till farther along.

Would you like to spend an hour optimizing a production line? Would you then like to re-optimize that same optimization again for another hour? Would you like to spend more hours optimizing your optimizations? You might even optimize your review to maximize optimize optimizations.

The amount that's in this early access game a year ago was impressive, and adding combat puts an interesting spin on it, even with the combat needing to be fleshed out a bit. Absolutely worth a try if you like factory games.
