I like space games.  Which is why I bought this but haven't bought Factorio yet.  And this is pretty decent just as a space game -- where the biggest emphasis is on planetary and technological development. 

So why a good space game?
1. Fairly realistic distances.  This is one of my biggest complaints about some game which are fantastic in every other way.  Planets are points of light in the sky until you make a journey and not hanging in the sky like a menu to choose from.
2. Good variety of planets.  Would like to see more, of course.  But it was quite an adventure to come across a waterworld and figure out what to do with it.
3. It is good for a lot of play.  I mean what bigger project can there be than to build a Dyson sphere?  

Room for improvement?
1. Better automation with conditional elements to control operation of other elements.
2. More variety of planets including more size variations.
3. Should be a way to get water on an ice planet.  It even teases you with the visual effect of the ice melting under you but still doesn't let you actually get that water.

Space combat added, and it was done extremely well, with plenty of choices regarding how hard and how much you want the game dominated by these bad guys.

This is the best game of the factory genre no doubt, and one of the best games in recent years. It rivals AAA games. I am out of words.

Got a lot more playtime through Origin version of the game, and reached interstellar factory level. The gameplay loop of factory building here is fantastic. Visually more interesting than Factorio, this comes at the cost of getting an overview of your factory a little bit more difficult. The game provides plenty of tools to help of course, and the design challenges with the planetary grid you build on being segmented, such that blueprint builds can't be placed between them offers an opportunity to consider designating each to a particular purpose.

Of it's drawbacks, there aren't many. Controls to fly around in space are a little floaty, and eventually the desire for an autopilot technolgy to take you between planets is missed. The Personal Logistics tech feels like it's still missing an advanced tier, where currently each container with a logistics hub can only be set to supply or demand a single item. A secondary tier to this tech would hopefully offer the ability to maintain a certain content. (Such a feature would allow for chest with logistics to direct attach to an assembler and provide it all materials needed, simplifiying the build to provide all buildings via personal logistics)

All the same, the game as it is, is very compelling and worth the price today. Any future content added is a bonus.

Part of my holy trinity along with Satisfactory and Factorio.

What makes this game different are "technical visuals". A fact that you can actually see individual sails shot at the star at the specific position around it, while forming your custom-designed pattern around that star makes for truly spectacular views and feels. A lot of effort was put into that visual part of the game, WHAT player can see. Very well done by developers.

The same goes for effortless and fluid transition from planet surface to space. You can see and experience rotation of planets, tidal-locks, resonance (speed of rotation to speed of orbit around star) is really fun. I'm (very) amateur astronomer, so I used DSP many times as visual guide to explain space-related phenomena to my son, friends and family.

[b]Very cool game as factory builder, but also very interesting visual guide to space and planetary systems and mechanics of it all. DSP doesn't get enough recognition and credit in that regard.[/b]

Borrows heavily from Factorio, if you've played that game you will see the influence in this one without a doubt, but DSP expands in VERY different directions and in no way feels like even an echo of a clone of anything else I've ever played.  Sadly no MP mode.  The sheer scale of the game feels immense, seeing the planets in orbit in the sky around you, the dyson sphere slowly blotting out the sun in your sky, flying between stars and setting up interstellar shipping lanes, simply incredible.  Combat recently added makes for an interesting change, the game previously had no sense of urgency or tension, just sheer logistics.  Which had a merit of its own, but I find myself unwilling to turn off combat mode and somewhat enjoy the hostile company.

So if you are like me you are familiar with these factory games. You played Factorio for x thousand hours and after that tried games like Satisfactory and etc but nothing ever grabbed you like Factorio did that first time. So from that perspective...

This game is something else man, it is a breath of fresh air for the niche genre. At first you get the idea that it's like the others, cheap Factorio clone, but then you get a little deeper and you go wait a minute, this one is different. It's got a little bit of Anno in it too with the transportation routes. Think of the ships and how you would build trade routes in Anno 1800. I can see myself putting more hours on it over the next 5 or 6 years. 

I think the only warning I would have is that if you are not an experienced factory game player, you will likely find a lot of this a bit more difficult to pick up. The menus and UI are nice but weird, certain menus can be up with others but others must be open alone, the "what to do next" is not clear and the tutorials are huge lengthy word manuals, which, are introductions to mostly mechanics that are given a tutorial in games like Factorio or Satisfactory. But if you like a challenge and like Factorio you can't pass this one up.
Nothing beats the sense of achievement standing on a planets surface seeing the massive Dyson Sphere that you built eclipse the stars.

I wanted to like this game.  However, you need to be able to rotate the screen to see how to place production facilities, conveyor belts, etc.  In order to rotate the screen, you need a middle mouse button which most laptops don't have.  You can't remap the rotate key to a non-mouse key.  So if your laptop doesn't have a middle mouse button, you're SOL.  It's a major game design fail.  Requested a refund after trying for a few hours to adapt, unsuccessfully.

For a "space' game I didn't realize how down to earth this game was going to be. DSP is essentially a re-skinned version of Factorio. If you've already played Factorio and want more belts producing useless junk in your life then this is going to be a familiar game. If you haven't played the other automation games I don't see how I would ever pick DSP to play first.

I would say the main issue holding this game back is everything is centered around your view point. You can't view other planets you have factories on. You can't build warships to beat back the Dark Fog that aren't in your inventory. If you're not on the world every other world is just a chest that produces resources for you to collect. By the time you get to warp travel the game is mostly over. While this helps with running the game it limits the whole galaxy expansion feel for the game.

There are definitely good bones.  The structure is there, but the content is lacking and there needs to be a better tech flow.  As of this review,  

navigating the tech tree is interesting (in the it's buggy kind of way) as you have to figure out the techs required to produce the product you want.  

There is a basic flow for combat tech, but limited combat units.  

The automation is also kind of buggy.  It's the kind of buggy you can work around with a programmers mindset, but the point of the higher techs is that you shouldn't need to, and therefore rework your entire factory to increase function and production.  Currently that is unnecessary.

Needs balancing, lots of balancing.  Part of that can be done with the starting statistics but most of that needs to be done on the game itself.  There isn't even the basic archer < spearman < horseman < archer balancing system... yet?

However, the game is fun if just bones right now, and therefore functional.  I think the game could become a nice RTS for both creative players and ladder players if the game is built out properly, even just by copy pasting unit types.  I would also like to see more unique species/archtypes.  I think this game would benefit highly from an artifact tech tree that can be built on and added to the basic tree creating entirely new tech trees.  It would even be cool if the tech tree started vanilla and basic but still carried through to the end, but was better off by being added to with other micro and full races, dead end research and entire 'side plot' sections to research.  Not to mention the basic world devourer, Utopian, and balanced archtype tech trees.

DSP is tied with Factorio for my absolute favorite factory building game.

Still in Early Access, so there are a few rough edges with UI and quirks and balancing, but it's remarkably bug-free for an Early Access game. The devs are very attentive to player input, yet also have a pretty firm idea of what they want going forward, it seems. Currently my favorite factory game.

Here's what I said in February 2021: "Extraordinary - I've seen mature games with way less quality than this early access gem. The developers have a solid model and this could become a very remarkable game indeed. My first stint 11 hours uninterrupted - no glitches, no weird stuff, it just works. Buy this game."

After 443 hours I stopped in April 2021 to wait for the Dark Fog.

Now? Oh wow. Blueprints and so many sensible mechanics and Quality-of-Life improvements and a new strong adversary make the Dyson Sphere experience a must for automation addicts.

Buy this game. In fact, buy it again.

I actually very much enjoy the base art as well, with each structure holding a lot of mechanical charm. If I had any complaints at all, it would be that sometimes it's not clear what you need to do next, but the most minimal of guides fixes that, and there's no punishment for f*king around and finding out yourself (unless you have enemies turned on).

Unfortunately I have to write this negative review about a game I love. I have almost 1800 hours into Dyson Sphere Program. Really really enjoyed the game while I got to play it, but unfortunately something in the code or development of Rise of the Dark Fog is preventing me from being able to run the game. All of my PC's specs are over the recommended specs for the game, and I played nearly 1800 without any issues. I waited like many others for RotDF to come out and was ecstatic when it finally did, but since then, whenever I boot up the game to play, I'll be able to play for a short while, and then the game will freeze for no discernible reason. The freeze effects my entire system, and can only by ended by restarting the PC via power button. Many others on reddit have the same issue, and there isn't a fix for it. 

If you're able to play the game I very happy for you, but there are many who aren't. Can no longer recommend.

If you're into grand-scale empire-building, resource management, and a dash of strategic combat, Dyson Sphere Program is an absolute must-play. The developers' dedication to improving an already outstanding game is commendable and keeps me eagerly anticipating the future update on space combat.

From the moment I started playing, Dyson Sphere Program captivated me like few games have done before. It is hands down one of the most exhilarating games I've had the pleasure of playing. It's a perfect blend of Factorio's intricate resource management and Satisfactory's satisfying construction, offering an unparalleled gaming experience.

The epic scale of building your galactic empire is mind-blowing. Even before the combat update, this game had me hooked, but since then, it's reached phenomenal heights.

The introduction of the Dark Void as an adversary is a smart inclusion in the combat update. Its gradual ramp-up in challenge, synced with the player's development level, is a thoughtful approach. This pacing ensures that the threat it poses remains proportional to your progress, never becoming an overwhelming or existential menace that detracts from the construction experience. It maintains the core enjoyment of crafting your galactic empire without compromising it with undue disruptions from combat encounters.

Love this game. 
Recommended for strategy and base building gamers.
Great start for a factory builder with a unique twist. Hopefully with lots more to come.

With the combat update finally out, I can say that this is one of my top tier automation games.

This and Factorio are probably my two favorite factory/automation games of all time.  When you really start to understand the intricacies of this game, it brings a completely new level to the game of play that is truly great.

My first few hours started a bit slow, but once I understood blueprinting, and building things on a very large scale, it got to the point that I was dedicating entire planets to certain types of automation and operations.  In my last game, I even made an entire planet covered in factories for nothing more than science so I could crank out science on a massive scale.

The music is relaxing, the atmosphere is great, the graphics are beautiful, exploration is fantastic.  You can make the game very easy and it balances future rewards for things you're doing, or you can make it hard and get more rewards at the cost of as much difficulty as you'd like.

The new addition to The Fog adds complexity that requires you to really keep your head on a swivel in how you build your base for defense.  

At first glance, it may seem very much like automation can't be or isn't complex.  Once you get the understanding of large scale use of stacking and sorting, doubling, using the sprays, and all the other things that can be mixed in, you can have a very complex factory that works on a huge scale.

The game is very well optimized and runs smoothly, even at large resolution, and even with huge scale factories.  I have noticed with the new fog update there are times when the litter and huge swarms getting destroyed have caused /some/ slow down, but it's a new update, and just like the others, I imagine it will be optimized in no time.

So whether you want to just sit back and relax and make an interstellar factory and build a massive dyson sphere, or whether you want to build factories and play tower defense (and offense too once you get a fleet), there's honestly a ton to do in this game for those who love automation and factory building games.

The galaxy is really awesome to explore as well.  Sometimes it's fun to just warp over to a huge star and check it out, or go see a black hole.  Literally the only complaint I have which is more a feature request than anything, would be some added automation in the future to allow for logic choices on belts and sorters with a true/false, if, else, then statements of some type so things could be made even more intricately.

You may be the type who just wants to go yum spaghetti on your first factory or two, but once you pick it up and start playing with things on stacking, you'll find very quickly that you can make some awesome factories (or really large scale spaghetti :P ).

If that's not cool enough, you can even customize your robot, build up his armor to look cool, recolor it, and really go ham on that too!

It's also great you can export your blueprints to strings, share them with friends, etc.  Highly recommended if you enjoy these types of games.

TL;DR I have a few hours into it and it's a great factory game, now with tower defense and offense mixed in (if you want).

I'm torn about this developer.  The game is quite good and I am looking to see how it plays out when it is completed.
However, as a Chinese company it is mandated by the CCP to be subservient to any Governmental "requests" by the Chinese Government.  Sure this is just nonsense right?  No, I work in CyberSec and there is a war going on in the digital space.  China will, and is going after you if you are Western.

Keep in mind that at a whim your personal data can be provided to the CCP, and there is nothing stopping them dropping malware and other cybertools against you and your PC.  Unfortunately, there is nothing the developer can do about this even if they wanted to.  
If you must install the software, do so in isolation.  Run it on a clean PC that does not have network connectivity to any other devices in your household, and do not allow it to contact the internet.

I could gush all day about this game. It does so many things right.

It's an automation game. An automation game which does what every good automation game should: Building things. Building BIG things. Even better: sitting back and WATCHING as BIG things are built. DSP is very good at that. Automating a giant factory to make a gazillion hyper-advanced science cubes per second is fine and well, but you know what's even better? Watching HUNDREDS of SPACE LAUNCHERS and ROCKETS all coming together to put the goddamn SUN in a cage made of solar panels so you can squeeze every drop of energy out of it so you can do it MORE and BIGGERER but this time FASTeR until every star in the vicinity is yours

Now you might say "but this looks like something that wants me to use my brain" and you might have a point! Base building games usually feel like putting a logistical puzzle together, but if that's not your thing, fear not. Just paste some blueprints from the internet for the parts you don't want to do and you'll be good to go. Don't let anybody tell you you are playing the game wrong. Programmers copy code all the time and they still get paid for it

I regularly find myself stopping whatever I'm doing and just watching my screen in amazement. Be it the dance of the celestial spheres, my hundreds of drones flying gracefully around the factory, or my half-complete dyson sphere rising over the horizon. The game is absolutely beautiful

Framerate remains stable despite having several planets covered in poorly designed production lines. Flying (or warping) from one planet to another is as smooth as it gets. I kept thinking "hah i bet this will make the game start chugging" but it never happened. It's very easy to forget this game is made on Unity. Yeah

MOD SUPPORT. MECHA CUSTOMIZATION. BLUEPRINT SHARING 

You can even paint on planets if you want. That's right, write something crude on the surface of a planet in letters so huge its visible from space. You know what? Save it as a blueprint. Save the entire PLANET as a blueprint. That's right, the whole thing. Now you can make every planet look like that. Let them know who owns it

If you have been holding off on buying this then now is a perfect time to jump in. The recent Rise of the Dark Fog update adds combat to the game and an insidious robotic enemy which perfectly complements the slow-paced factory building, unlocks a sizeable new tech tree and gives you a purpose to your endless exploration and expansion. 

I've been a fan of the game since shortly after launch and dropped around 400 hours in it prior to this update. Honestly I was feeling a bit nervous about it, wondering whether they'd be able to pace it right or if it would interfere too much with the core of the game: I can only say that they've managed to implement it in a way which is perfectly in sync with the rest of the game. 

The Dark Fog mostly ignores you and grows slowly (and you can customise how fast and how aggressive they are before you start), but as you expand your factory the threat meter starts to rise. This mechanic allows you to see clearly how close you're getting to an attack and so you can plan ahead, which reduces frustration and gives an urgency to your actions that the game previously lacked. Attacks start off small and limited but each time they grow stronger as they adapt to you. Having said that at the moment the weapons you get really do make quick work of most attacks so it'll be interesting to see how the late game behaves, but there is the promise of some pretty spectacular light shows once you get the full force of the Dark Fog Hive on you.

It's a unique take on the factory builder genre. Building on a spherical grid with dynamic day/night cycles, a variety of different world types, and a growing sense of scale really set it apart. It's very satisfying watching they sky fill with the fruits of your labor, allowing you more energy to make it go faster. The devs have been actively developing it, keeping players in the loop for what's next for early access. The recent addition of the Dark Fog and combat systems feel well thought out, and not just tacked on to the original peaceful game.

By far one of the best factory/automation games I've played in the genre; Especially after the Dark Fog Update, a DLC-sized FreeLC which added adversity akin to Factorio's Biters or Satisfactory's Fauna.

One of the best games I have ever played. This game runs better than a lot of AAA games do and it's still in Early access . Never in the 210 hrs I have played this have I gotten a crash, heavy lag or BS glitches/bugs. Just goes to show how much a lot of big studios have lost the true passion of making an actual good and fun game that more importantly  actually works. Just a bunch of big wigs who couldn't care less about what they make and just want to  pump out the next cash sucking turd they can. While sucking the souls of the people who actually make the game out.  This is made by a small team of Passionate guys who have a vision and execute it perfectly.   The most recent Dark Fog update is such a change of pace and is a fresh reward for noobs and experienced players alike. The best part they gave this whole update to us for free to enjoy, no making it a packaged up DLC despite over a year of development. This is a game I will strongly support through it's development and would highly recommended it to anyone who like building, space and logical thinking. 

TLDR - pros and cons 

PROS

- Runs smooth as silk even in mid and surprisingly well even late game 
- Well designed worlds and fun and challenging builds 
- Huge blueprint crafting ability to greatly cut down on redoing the math/design of builds. 
- combat (if you enable it) is pretty fun and feel like it's in a good spot haven't played the combat side sufficiently enough to give a proper comment on it yet. (will edit soon)
- controls feel pretty good, space travel can be tricky but can be figured out over time but have improvements to be made.  
- I like that you have to craft special research cubes as a set resource feel like you really have to work at research. Can see it being a con to some people. 
- easily 100 hrs + of content to fully explore if you take your time and enjoy the game. 

Cons/things that may turn you off from it

- it's a brain heavy game, lot,s of logical thinking and math for load balancing and micromanaging is a core part of the game. For some this may be more of a brain workout the you want from a game. It has a sandbox mode but it robs you have the core fun of the game. 

- space flight from planet to planet can be tricky at first and very frustrating while learning and missing the planet for the 5th time getting launched into the void of space. 

- Some parts are really slow and you will have to just wait on production as you will have to manual craft a lot while you try to setup automation for certain things.  This is a long haul game with lots to do. 

- some production lines can be stupid long in later game 

- space battle feel kinda empty to me and has lots of room for growth. This update is new and they did a ton of great work but as it stands space combat is in need of some work but still fun all and all.

Good god almighty I'm not a religious man but this game has made me see the light of indie developers. 
DSP is good.  Like REALLY good if you're a fan of factorio/satisfactory or similar.  Yes you see that "Overwhelming Positive" rating on steam is there for a reason.  Well I am sufficiently Whelmed. 

DSP starts out as an interesting planetary factory building simulator, you can roam/fly around a whole little planet sphere (takes approximately 30-60 seconds) and set up resource collection, distribution, and fabriaction centers.  Once you get the hang of this and advance into a science tech-tree, it starts to open up and let you explore a solar system full of planets, then a local star cluster full of different stars.  

The main game sees you researching progressively more useful tech and managing resource chains across planets and star systems.  All of this becomes more power hungry, so you end up building a pretty beautiful and epic dyson sphere to collect the power from a star and beam it back to your base. 

While early on your bases may look like conveyor belt spaghetti, there is enough automation and management unlocks that your final bases will probably look like an interplanetary drone swarm.  There are a couple of interesting bottlenecks around sometimes handling liquids, sometimes handling solids, and getting to upgrade efficiency of systems in various ways.  The ability to lay down blueprints and terraform is greatly appreciated too. 

Combat adds a much-needed dimension to the original game that sometimes felt lonely.

Overall fun factory game with interesting planetary/space elements. Like Planetary Annihilation + Factorio. This review is from the first planetary phase of the game.

The good:
- Space elements are top notch. If you enjoy space stuff in general, the experience is a fun one to just look around and explore in.
- Game improved 10 fold with the Dark Fog update. Having enemies really helps the pacing/excitement.
- Getting around is easy. This is compared to Satisfactory where it takes 50% of the playtime to just get between factories. 
- Distribution drones are amazing.
- I'm sure there is more cool stuff that happens at the interplanetary stage as well.

The meh:
- The translations sometimes have mistakes in English (its early access, can't really be mad at that)
- In-game guides and tutorials sometimes make the game more confusing instead of more clear. It's worth it to watch a video of someone playing/explaining the game before you start.
- When playing with Linux + Proton there are sometimes issues with the audio. (light static that happens maybe once every 20 minutes of gameplay.)
- The music doesn't really fit the theme, so I usually pop on an audiobook or the interstellar OST.
- You have to start a new save each time an update comes out if you want to play that updates content. I know there's no way around this, but would be nice if you could opt-in to new content in your existing save.

I can't state enough how great of an experience this game is.  If you like Factorio, this will feel conceptually similar, but with very pretty graphics.  Despite the more complex graphics, they are just as easy to read and parse at a glance.  You trade trains and circuit logic for grander logistics networks (with robots very similar to Factorio's) and the challenge of building on spherical planets.

The exploration side of the game is what separates this from Factorio.  By default, you spawn on a moon, and its rotation and orbit around a planet are always accounted for.  You can look up in the sky and see not only the sun, but the planet you orbit around.  Pretty soon, you can fly around your little moon and experience the day/night cycle, but soon enough you will fly to other planets in your solar system -- when their orbits come close enough to yours.  Eventually, your solar system will feel small and you can venture to others.  It is a very satisfying sense of progression, and the planets are chillingly beautiful.  You will never forget the moment when you first land on another planet.

As an avid fan and long-time player, I'm absolutely thrilled to share my experience with Dyson Sphere Program, especially after the Dark Fog update. This game is a masterpiece of engineering and space exploration, seamlessly blending complex resource management with awe-inspiring cosmic construction.

First off, the core concept of building a Dyson Sphere around a star is not just ambitious, it's breathtakingly executed. The level of detail and planning required to harness the power of an entire star is both challenging and immensely satisfying. You start small, mining resources on a lone planet, but soon you're orchestrating a galaxy-wide logistics network, a testament to the game's incredible scale.

The graphics are a treat - the planets, stars, and the vastness of space are stunningly rendered. Watching your automated drones and factories at work against the backdrop of the cosmos is a sight to behold. The day-night cycle on planets, the intricate machinery, and the smooth transitions between celestial bodies create an immersive experience that's hard to step away from.

Then came the Dark Fog update, which took the game to a whole new level. The introduction of the mysterious Dark Fog added a layer of intrigue and challenge that was missing before. Navigating this new obstacle while expanding my interstellar empire added a fresh twist to the gameplay, making it feel like a whole new game.

The update also brought quality-of-life improvements that made the game more accessible without sacrificing its depth. The developers really listen to the community, constantly tweaking and improving the game based on player feedback.

In conclusion, Dyson Sphere Program, with its Dark Fog update, is a gem in the space strategy genre. It's a game that challenges your planning skills, rewards your creativity, and constantly surprises you with its depth and beauty. For anyone who dreams of conquering the stars, this game is a must-play!

I'm updating my review since the newest update. Holy, crap, has the game gotten so much better!! I thought this was going to turn into a game like Command and Conquer where if you aren't seasoned with controlling units in an RTS game, then you were not going to enjoy the game, but this doesn't feel like a traditional RTS game. There is plenty of time to build up your resources and get some defenses in place to fend off the first batch of enemies. They take a good minute to detect you. 

The new combat also adds a bit of urgency when it comes to building, but the fighting is really fun. Also building up giant space weapons that can shoot rockets into space is so cool!! The new update did a lot of great things. I usually run away from games like this, but I've been playing all day today once I got all the updates. It's done nothing but get better. I can't wait to see what the bigger battles are going to be like. At one point you can see the evil ships and space station flying just outside of the globe you start on. I can't wait to fight up there!!

Can Not Wait For 1.0 Release Of The Game

This game is not even close to as good as Factorio or Satisfactory.  The gameplay feels incredibly clunky.  The lack of good default keybindings AND the inability to set them on my own means that I basically have to play the game with a mouse.  I don't have F keys on my keyboard, so I can't access anything in my hotbar.  It's just simply not ready yet.  The UX of this game needs a serious once over because there's really no reason this shouldn't copy more from Factorio UX, like item picker, hotbar and inventory screens.  Fabricator has too many buttons to build things, should just be left/right click on items.  This kind of stuff needs to be sorted out before you add more systems to a game.  I'll try again on 1.0 I guess.

Edit after dev response:

From what I can tell, you cannot rebind the Function keys required to access items on the hotbar in the games settings.  I would much prefer a customizable hotbar instead of a static one that requires two button presses to get to what I want.  At the very least I'd like to see it be the same keys, like 1 to open power then 1 to select the first thing in that bar, not 1 to open power then Fn1 to open the first thing in that bar.

Additionally, the fabricator is too slow to interact with, it needs fewer clicks as well.  Left click to build one, right click to build five.  No need to fiddle around with the +/- that can only go up to 10x anyway.  Additionally, just combine inventory and fabricator into one screen (inventory already shows anyway) and then you can use the other keybind (e or f) for something good.  

Another example: the keys to move belts up and down are the arrow keys by default, which means I have to remove my hand from my mouse to select the level then go back to my mouse to place.  This is a terrible default keybind.  Scroll wheel would be much better in this case.

These kinds of things are what I mean when I say the game feels very clunky.  If I'm incorrect about any of these things please let me know, but right now I don't believe the game's rebinding is sufficient to fix these problems.

For players new to the automation genre:
Everyone is talking about Factorio, should you just buy that instead?
Dyson Sphere Program is single player, Factorio is multiplayer.
If you are not aiming to play with friends, this game is half the price, and infinitely more beautiful. The scale of the end goal dwarfs Factorio and building towards it is incredibly satisfying.
Dyson sphere a slightly easier, slightly grindier, and more satisfying than base Factorio. Unless you are extremely limited for funds and are looking for a forever game, play Dyson Sphere Program.

To Factorio Vets:
Should you get DSP? 
Do you care about better graphics, and have you always thought the rocket was the most lame end goal and wanted something much more grand? Get DSP.
Are you all about system complexity and just wanting to solve the next production puzzle? Stick with Factorio mods.

Dyson Sphere Program is a true masterpiece for construction and space exploration enthusiasts! This game is an exciting journey towards galactic conquest, where creativity merges with strategy in a vast and stunning universe.
The initial learning curve can be quite steep for newcomers to the genre or those less familiar with construction and management games. The complex mechanics and amount of information to absorb can be overwhelming at first, which may turn off some potential players.
The beauty of the graphics and the immensity of the space are breathtaking. Traveling between planets, stars and solar systems is an incredible visual experience, where each location offers new challenges and opportunities.
Finally, although the gameplay is challenging and complex, it may not be the ideal choice for players looking for a more casual experience, as it requires a significant time commitment to explore and master all the mechanics on offer.

 3.[strike]There is no any challenge at all apart from electricity issues. No enemies, no structure checking, no structure decaying, simply nothing.[/strike] Added.
 4.[strike]At the late stage of the game I felt like microprocessor designer. Only issue is how to route things from one part to another (generate buses) and how to improve efficiency of the "clock".</strike> Now with enemies it is far better.

This game is wonderful. The scope of this game feels limitless. It is almost as robust as minecraft. You get too set your own pace, so you can spend all of your time micromanaging factories and not worry about *having* to do something. On the other end, you can be very messy and unlock all the tech and have tons of toys to play with, worrying about organization *later*. 

Now that they have added a combat system, this game is a pure masterpiece! There is so much to do in this game, you won't ever feel bored. Exploration, defense, factory building, planning, mass exploitation of resources, they have it all!

The UX and graphics could be improved, but for an early release version, you will be more than impressed!

TLDR: Game is too simple, better get Factorio or Riftbreaker


Played again after ~1 year, nothing has changed in the basic QoL or coding system.


- It still uses an older builder system than Factorio did 10 years ago: you actually have to craft the base material manually every time before you can build the building, instead of it being done automatically by a simple click on the building in the build menu.

- If you have crafting orders set, new items added to your inventory will not be read by the current crafting orders and keeps on produce stuff your already own...

- Items don't have their own output for transport lines, but instead require this stupid additional output... (I think the developer couldn't create a better output than this simple one)

I spent almost a hundred hours in this game before the Dark Fog update, and I loved the chill automatization and optimization routine, but it felt like something was missing... in the end, to reach the end goal I barely touched the Dyson Sphere itself, just jammed a bunch of particle reactors and made a pocket sun, slooooowly but surely grinded the needed resources, and there was that.
However, with the new update, it brings the SPICE that was missing before. To be able to defend yourself against the armada that is going to inevitably assault your base, you'll need a LOT of guns. And to operate those guns, you'll need a lot of resourses, and what's more important, a B*TT TON of energy. And where can you get such amount of energy?That's right, you build a freakin' Dyson Sphere!
You can customize how fast the Fog builds and how fast it becomes agressive  towards you, so you'll have fun either way. But the game feels like it's... complete now. Although the end goal of accumulating Universe Matrices is still a bit... underwhelming. I'd prefer if it was something like "Destroy the core of the Dark Fog", if you're playing with the battle mode enabled. 
Still, With this update Dyson Sphere Program became one of the best building/automatization games I've seen. Looking forward to future updates!

It took me a few attempts to get into, but it really is a great game once you make it that far.
It's not that the entry is "difficult", but the sci-fi nature of the product chains makes them appear quite random and uninteresting at first. But there is some theme and logic to them, and the basic factory builder/exploration gameplay loop works well.

Fittingly for a sci-fi factory game, it does feel like you're starting right in the late-game of other factory builders. Blueprints, drones and flying are available early and conveyor belt management is greatly simplified with the easy availability of stacking and drone transport.

Nonetheless, there are very rewarding milestones  beyond that. The first expedition to another planet, interplanetary logistic, and then once more for travelling to a new star system all feel great.

Restarting is also quite rewarding. Other than in titles like Satisfactory, you do not have to do a lot of grinding and exploration to get back into the fully developed late game. While it's many hours of fun tinkering to get there at first, blueprints and experience will let you easily get back to that stage on a new savegame.

Finally I do quite like the comfort features, although there are a few drawbacks:
+inventory management is quick and easy. I spent much less time micromanaging my inventory, and you can automate almost all of it quite soon into the game! You will probably manage it a fair bit in your first attempts, but it's quite fine even then.
+belts have few restrictions and are fun to work with
+blueprints are quickly available and mostly fun and easy to use
-blueprint creation and use can be a real hassle near the poles of a planet due to the curved grid (fortunately you can play around this by building your larger production facilities near the equator)
-editing blueprints is very limited out of the box. You cannot keep the filename/name/description/icons of a blueprint while re-reselecting its buildings.

Overall I'd say 7/10 for general audiences and 9/10 for people who like factory builders and are willing to overcome the initial drag of dealing with the rather unintuitive product chains.

Prettiness:
DSP >>> Satisfactory >> Factorio
DSP is by far the prettiest factory game and it's not even close. 
Satsifactory is pretty, but not close to the DSP level.
Factorio is ugly as sin.

Logisitics Complexity:
DSP > Factorio > Satisfactory
DSP allows spaghetti belts with low overhead, but interplanetary + interstellar is complex
Factorio is 2D and you can't just make anything go anywhere.
Satsifactory anything can go anywhere.

Tech:
DSP > Factorio >>>>>> Satisfactory
You can REALLY feel DSP scaling 
Factorio feels "normal"
Satisfactory feels unnecessarily grindy.

Power systems:
DSP >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Factorio/Satisfactory
You'll find out why.

Downward pressure (enemies/etc.):
Factorio >>>>>>>>>>>>> Satisfactory > DSP (...FOR NOW...)
Factorio has the smog system, which is excellent.
Satisfactory has basically ignorable nonsense.
DSP has nothing ...yet.

Resources:
DSP > Factorio >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Satisfactory
DSP scattering unique resources across the star systems is EXCELLENT
Factorio is solid and you have to get to/provide defense for resources
Satisfactory has infinite resource wells defended by near-ignorable enemies

Personal opinion:
DSP > Factorio >>> Satisfactory
DSP is GORGEOUS and the scaling is so satisfying, the end game is amazing. A+++
Factorio is COMPLETE and the mod scene is WILD. A+
Satisfactory is pretty but grindy and I just don't care about it? There's no... Push? B-

Overall Score: 9.25 / 10
Story: TBD
Gameplay: 10 / 10
Graphics: 8 / 10
Sound: 9 / 10
Multiplayer/Online: N/A
Additional Features: 10 / 10

Story: TBD
The story is being actively developed so I’ll hold off on assigning a score to this. The premise is solid though. I don’t really play Dyson Sphere Program for the immersion but the gameplay in the context of the game’s story wouldn’t break any immersion.

Gameplay: 10 / 10
I find the game to be the perfect combination of resource management and idle automation gameplay. The progression is perfectly paced. Even if your system is efficiently automated, there’s always something you can go do. Figuring out more efficient methods of resource production and accumulations scratches an itch in my brain and Dyson Sphere Program is the perfect delivery system for that.

Graphics: 8 / 10
Space graphics are excellent. Flying around the solar system and passing by the sun hits a certain sci-fi vibe that is fairly rare in the genre. It’s reminiscent of games like Elite Dangerous in terms of space scenery. It’s well executed. Planetary graphics are where the improvements can be. Although this is likely a moot point as planets become industrialized and concrete/metal replaces the original scenery.

Sound: 9 / 10
The soundtrack for Dyson Sphere Program is perfectly suited for the game. It’s atmospheric and upbeat tune makes it extremely easy to listen to and likely facilitates getting lost in the sauce. I will say that the soundtrack is not an essential element. This is a game where you can kill the music and have something else playing in the background like a podcast or audiobook. The only room for improvement that comes to mind would be getting Hans Zimmer to score the soundtrack.

Multiplayer: N/A
No multiplayer at this time. The game doesn’t need it but doing this with friends would be interesting.

Additional Features: 10 / 10
I haven’t touched modding, yet. However I will give high marks for the community and dev’s making it extremely easy to get mecha customization files and blueprints. The dev’s have also been pretty solid with communication and setting/meeting timeline expectations. Next week a pretty big content update should be rolling out and I’m looking forward to it.

SAJAHAJAWO, SAJAHO BING CHILLING

Dyson Sphere program is a fine factory style game... I'm sure most know that, as its been out for several years now. I cant help but compare it to Factorio however and I consider Factorio to be the Superior game.

Dyson Sphere Program has a few nit-picky flaws that hold it down.
-Space flight between planets is awful.  If you miss on your first pass it is almost impossible to steer yourself back to the planet you wanted to land on.   Face-planting into a planet just where ever you happen to be pointing so you don't miss.  Then spending 2-3 minutes flying around the planet to where you actually would have wanted to land in the first place is obnoxious.  The game should either allow you to steer more precisely.  Or provide a "landing pad" style structure you can simply select to fly to and land on each planet.

-Ore collection is just Ugly.,,,  a ring of collectors with belts coming out all sides and merging together is just sloppy.   The game should provide a structure that completely covers the ore deposits and  provides outlets on all 4 sides.

-Some of the production chains and available tools for routing items in the early to mid game are simply just obnoxious. The game opens up and improves in this aspect once you reach logistic bots.  However coming from Factorio I would appreciate  a better system in the early game for routing supply chains that work together and continue on into the mid to late game instead of ripping it all out and rebuilding it all as soon as bots are available. 

-You start with construction drones which is a nice upgrade form Factorio, however you also cannot hand place anything which is a huge down grade from Factorio.  Meaning you rely on a few bots to construct everything, even if you feel like your mech is standing right there and could easily plop the building down.  This actually seems to slow down and extend construction throughout the entire game.

-Soil Piles are obnoxious in the early game. Foundation should work to level the terrain without additional need for an arbitrary resource, that can only be gained by lowering other terrain... 


-upgraded sorters could use an upgraded range to pull from belts or buildings more tiles away.

-spliters could use an updated hitbox to be stacked tighter together.  should not need an empty tile in "bus systems" between belts just to fit splitters in.

-There are no resource transport systems like trains in this game.  You get belts and bots and that is it. Which is fine, once you unlock bots/cargo ships/etc the game opens up and trains would not be necessary.  however in the early game it translates to a horrible painful experience of belt spaghetti that all has to be redone as soon as bots are available.  It makes you want to just abandon your starting planet and start over on a new planet instead of continue to add on and improve.  In Factorio for example your starting base stone smelters feed with coal could easily last and continue to work into the late game, only really needing to be phased out at the mega base stage.  However in DSP almost everything you have built before unlocking Planet and Inter-planet Logistics is trash and needs to be rebuilt ASAP to proceed onward.

-I understand that planets are spheres and that it is impossible to make a grid system work with a sphere 100%.  This game does an great job of shifting the grid around and making it work out.  Building east to west is generally fine and works out not causing to many issues.   However when, mostly in the early game, you are forced to build north to south, or run belts north to south, things get odd and ugly. This is coming from someone with OCD who is possible also diagnosed autistic, but the odd left and right jumps when the grid system has to change heading North and or South is jarring.  I feel like there could at least be a more pleasing change to avoid such sudden shifts in what would other wise be a straight line. 

-Mech walk speed is so slow.. Even with upgrades it is painfully slow.    flight speed is equally slow for moving around a planet.  Even with upgrade this speed is to slow.  There are no other options to quickly move around a planet.  Space flight is to fast and to uncontrollable to be used well on a planet level.

I enjoy complicated logistics and supply chains however when the game does not give you the resources at each research stage to accomplish those chains and logistics in a logical and neat manner it can be very frustrating.  The solutions that are built should be able to last into the end game without having to be completely redesigned every step of the way in order to be mess of belts.

I came at this game after playing Factorio, Satisfactorio, shapez.io, and many other colony sim/factory style games.  And still my experience was frustrating.  I can only imagine that if this was your fist factory game that you would give up way before having a change to experience what the game really has to offer.

-No steam workshop mod support that could have easily and safely added mods to adjust the game to fix a majority of these issues.

It is just what I was looking for. No stress, just build travel and modify. Easy going yet complex. 10/10 and it is just an early access.

EDIT:  I can't wait for the Dark Fog update!  DSP is one of my favorite games of all time and none of my gaming friends know about it!  Every person I ask "Have you played Dyson Sphere Program yet?"  They answer "What's Dyson Sphere Program?" and then I have to shoot them dead and fire up the wood chipper.  No, but seriously, DSP is the best game out there that "nobody" knows about.  I've been playing PC games since I owned a Commodore 128 back in 1986, and I was playing games on PET computers before that.  DSP is easily one of my favorite games of all time.  If you like building giant factories across multiple planets, this is the game you want.  It got a 97% approval rating overall and a 98% approval for recent reviews.  That should tell you just how good this game really is.  $20 is a STEAL for how much work has gone into this game and amazingly all of it works!  You will easily rack up hundreds of hours of play time before you are done, and right now the game is 60% done.

EDIT:

In a nutshell, DSP is a great game.  I leave the game running for weeks at a time with zero crashes and zero bugs.  These guys are doing it right.

I think we can safely say that there are at least 3 factory/base building games now that will really put people's logistical skills to the test:  Factorio, Satisfactory and now Dyson Sphere Program.  I've played all 3 games to max level several times and it doesn't matter which of these games I play the experience is FUN!  Say goodbye to the rest of your steam library.  These 3 games will kill thousands of hours of your time.

The main differences between the 3 games are as follows:

1) Factorio is a 2D game with all of the sprites angled at 45 degrees to make it look 3D.  Because everything is procedural, base sizes are nearly unlimited.
2) DSP is a 3rd person builder and everything is 3D.  DSP takes place across multiple star systems and planets.
3) Satisfactory is a first person builder where you are the character.  (Also 3D)  Satisfactory only has 1 game map but it's a HUGE map, and all of it modeled by hand.

Honestly, I can't believe that they are selling DSP for $20.  That's a steal for how much game time you'll get out of this.  I've got more game time out of this one game than games that cost over twice as much.  If you like building things and mental and logistical challenges, this game will more than satisfy that need!

FACTORIO:  "I am the best building game ever made."

DSP:  "Hold my beer..."
Satisfactory: "Hey wait!  That's my job!"

Sooo, 2,000 hours into game (I leave it running 24 hours a day) and I've been letting it run for at least a couple of weeks now on my second play through.  This game is DEEP.  I've finally managed to research all the techs to the point where I understand how everything works, and that just shows me how badly I've been planning!  I don't want to lose this game when I'm so close to the finish line (I'm not good at math...) but half of me wants to just scrap it and start over.  Here we go again!

EDIT:  My second play through went much better.  

Hint: remember where you put things or you'll have to go looking for them later.  Not fun when you are working with multiple star systems each with multiple planets.  I suggest keeping notes on what planets you have been to and what you built there.  Unfortunately there's no way to quick view inhabited planets, you have to remember which ones you colonized.

Note for next time:  ramp up warper production to ludicrous.  Every single interstellar station needs them for each ship departing.  UGH!  Huge amount of resources to make that happen.

I may sound like I'm complaining, and I am.  But it's damn good fun getting lost in all this.  

Definitely got my money's worth and this is only 60% done? Damn!

Did I mention this game costs $20?  If you have any inkling that you might like this game, buy it.  You will not be let down!

Man I know everyone and their mother loves this game, but there's something about it that makes me lose interest fast. I've tried getting into this game like 5 times and inevitably drop it a couple hours in after getting annoyed with how slow the early game is. As soon as I want to start expanding into a larger factory I have to wait minutes for 3-5 slowass drones to place conveyors one by one. And your own run speed is just. so. slow. Get a planet with coal and stone on opposite sides from your starting area? Prepare to run for 60-120 seconds from one to the other.

The tech tree needs to be more streamlined. Take Factorio as inspiration and feed in new buildings and recipes one after the other rather than all at once in a shotgun blast at the start. None of the research is even properly gated behind the different tiers of research cubes. I shouldn't have to dig through pieces of the tech tree that I can't even begin to research because I haven't yet researched the required stuff yet.

Don't get me wrong, there's a lot of things this game does right too. I still remember how awed I was the first time I booted this game and was flying through space to the starting planet. The sheer scope of the game and sense of wonder in slowly expanding across the galaxy is a big plus. Factory building and maximizing efficiency is great too. I just wish it wasn't such a slog to get there.

Most people like this game, so don't let my single opinion dissuade you from purchasing. Just figured I should add my own two cents into the pile.

It's an amazing game, which adds something new and fresh to the 'Factory' game genre with not just one planet  but an entire Galaxy to utilise and extract resource's from to achieve your goal of creating a Dyson Sphere to power - The Supercomputer.  

  Pros / Reasons to get this game :-
 - Easy to understand and play from the off, ingame instructions are excellent.
 -  You always feel like your advancing with upgrades/ abilities at a regular rate. No mid game mountain to stall progress
 -  You can zoom close in or pull back the view and the factory system remains distinct and easy to understand.
 -  Fly through space ! 
 -  Create transport drones to deliver resources through your network of planets and drones to keep your Robot Ai supplied 
 -  Everything works in a simple to set up manner.
 -  Despite the gigantic scale and multiple systems at play, there's no slowdown.

    So can totally recommend this game although there are other excellent Factory games - Like Satisfactory and Factorio, Dyson Sphere Project manages to be it's own unique spin on the factory genre, and stands out from the crowd as a result.

No but seriously an amazing factory builder. If Factorio is pure distilled factory building this is factory building but with multiple planets, interstellar logistics, and beautiful views.

Dyson Sphere Program seamlessly blends the addictive factory management mechanics of Factorio with an expansive space exploration setting, offering a polished experience even in its Early Access stage.

I've never played factory games before this one and it is amazing. The design, gameplay, artstyle and optimizations are perfect and it is incredibly done by a small team of developers. Congratulations to them, enjoy the experience.

This game has me hooked.  I can't put my finger on why it resonates more for me than other production line games, but it does.  There is something so satisfying about setting up a great late-game chain, flying to another star to set up some additional supply sources for vital materials, and coming back to your home system to see just how far along your Sphere has constructed itself while you were away.

The game is technically in Early Access, but you wouldn't know it other than the 3 small techs that say "in development" on them.  It's stable as hell and seems to run quite well, no matter how many planets are churning away and sending supplies back and forth.  If the devs said "no more updates" tomorrow, I'd still have 0 regrets in buying and playing this.  

Well, I guess I would have 1 regret; the hours I lost myself in this game could probably have been better spent doing something productive.

Edit: 2 1/2 years later and I still highly recommend DSP.  The additional buildings and the tweaks to ratios have made the game even better.  Looking forward to the Dec 15th release of the "dark swarm" patch, when combat is being added.  I enjoy the game without an antagonist, but the addition of enemies that want to destroy your supply planets will introduce conflict for when I'm in the mood to feel like I'm fighting against something

If you love resource gathering / colony building games, you'll definitely want to give DSP a try - honestly feels way too good for a $20 game, even in Early Access - it really does deserve that Overwhelmingly Positive rating :)

There's a definite learning curve to figuring out sorters, conveyor belts, drones and the other automation tools, but once you do, you'll find that you can fully automate everything if you have the research and resources for it.

>> Protip: Sorters have enough reach that they can carry resources over other conveyor belts, meaning you can use them to "bridge" intersecting conveyors without risking traffic jams, or pull resources from a distance if you have multiple conveyors with different resources in parallel and you need to draw from the conveyor that's furthest away.

You can also stack storage buildings and research labs on top of each other, which makes transporting resources to them a lot less cumbersome..

Here's some screenshots if you need a visual guide -

"Expansive, Ingenious, and Addictively Engaging: Dyson Sphere Program Delivers a Galactic Masterpiece"

Rating: ★★★★★

Embark on a mesmerizing journey across the cosmos with Dyson Sphere Program (DSP), a game that brilliantly combines strategy, automation, and exploration into an addictive, out-of-this-world experience. Developed by Youthcat Studio, this game is a testament to innovation and creativity in the realm of space simulation.

At its core, DSP challenges players to harness the power of automation and logistics to construct a Dyson Sphere—an awe-inspiring megastructure designed to harness the energy of a star. The game offers an expansive universe to explore, brimming with celestial bodies, resources, and intricate systems waiting to be exploited and optimized.

One of the most compelling aspects of DSP is its sheer scale. From humble beginnings on a single planet, players progress to harnessing entire star systems. The sense of progression is immensely satisfying as you meticulously plan and expand your industrial empire across multiple planets, each with its unique challenges and resources.

The game's mechanics are elegantly designed, offering a perfect blend of complexity and accessibility. Whether you're a seasoned logistics expert or a newcomer to the genre, DSP provides a gentle learning curve while offering depth and intricacy for those seeking a challenge. Building intricate supply chains, optimizing production, and automating processes using a plethora of machines and technologies are incredibly rewarding endeavors.

Visually, Dyson Sphere Program is a treat for the senses. The stunning, vibrant planetary landscapes, coupled with mesmerizing space vistas, create an immersive and breathtaking experience. The attention to detail in the design of structures, machinery, and celestial bodies is commendable and adds to the game's overall appeal.

Moreover, the soundtrack complements the gameplay perfectly, evoking a sense of wonder and grandeur as you delve deeper into the universe. The atmospheric music enhances the immersion, making every discovery and accomplishment feel monumental.

The community support and developer engagement further enhance the experience. Regular updates and a passionate player base contribute to a thriving environment where ideas are shared, strategies are discussed, and the game continues to evolve.

In conclusion, Dyson Sphere Program is a triumph in the realm of space simulation games. Its blend of strategic depth, captivating visuals, and addictive gameplay make it an absolute must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're drawn to interstellar logistics, complex resource management, or simply exploring the vastness of space, DSP offers an unparalleled and immensely gratifying experience that will keep you engaged for countless hours.
It's a intergalactic factor game.

[h2]A must buy for fans of automation and management sims[/h2]
Dyson Sphere Program checks all the boxes for a successful Factorio style automation game, and does an excellent job of setting itself apart from the pack. All of the traditional elements are here, conveyor systems, assemblers, component stacking to create higher tier components. However, the multi-layer building possibilities make for some stunning layouts, or messes of spaghetti, but it's entirely player choice how they want their factories to look. Beyond that, you have a miniature galaxy at your disposal to harvest resources and set up supply lines between worlds.

The progression in Dyson Sphere feels very fluid and meaningful. New components and modules become relevant as soon as you research them and challenge you to reconsider your layout and re-prioritize resource allocation. As you research new upgrades for your mech suit, you'll be able to travel into space and utilize resources from other planets in your system. Further on this expands to other systems with their own planets with rare resources that can used to replace entire manufactured components. Recipes will occasionally have multiple combinations of ingredients that accommodate these rare resources, allowing you to create components much faster. In the late game it can become difficult to remember which planets and factories you have made to create a certain resource or component, but the game does give you the ability to name planets and has menus that show your operations on other worlds, something I should make better use of.

Dyson Sphere Program has nice looking graphics and reasonable system requirements. The art style, while not especially groundbreaking, is coherent and fits the atmosphere nicely. There is also customization for your mech suit allowing you to create your own designs, though I will admit, the editor was a bit over my head and is basically a cut-down 3D modeler. I found myself more interested in building my factory than what I looked like, but this is personal preference. There is a gallery of player made suits you can download online as well if you're not inclined to make your own. Over all the customization and aesthetics of Dyson Sphere are very nice.

The negatives of Dyson Sphere Program are honestly few and far between, and very minor. There are some localization issues with the English tutorial narrator and text prompts, but nothing bad enough that you won't understand what's being talked about. If you stop playing for several days and come back, it can be a bit daunting to remember where everything is or what you were doing, but this is true of any automation sim. I have experienced a handful of crashes and memory leaks after playing for several hours at a time, so save often, but no bugs or issues I would consider game breaking.

This is over-all a fantastic addition to your game collection and is one of the most polished and feature-complete Early Access titles out there. Definitely worth buying at the incredibly reasonable price of $20 and is a no-brainer, especially if you catch it on sale.

Now if you'll excuse me, it's been a while since I constructed a Dyson Sphere, and writing this review has given me the itch to play again.

Dyson Sphere Program is a factory building game, but instead of building in a single space, you build on multiple planets.
Whilst the game is good for what it is, it does suffer some drawbacks.
Pro's
- Easy to pick up and play
- Just the right amount of challenge in standard 1x resources mode
- Plenty of community made blueprints available
- Upgrade path is easy to understand
- Tutorial guide spells things out for you
- Hopping from planet to planet is seamless*
- Dyson Sphere
- Mods are allowed
Con's
- Whilst mods are allowed, a lot of them are out of date or don't work correctly. BeltSpeedEnhancement, for example, doesn't work correctly.
- Alongside that, blueprints are severely out of date, or are big for no reason. I often find myself building a planet blueprint, only to realise to my horror an hour after completion that it just doesn't work, or despite having 2x the required RAW input, it's not making the advertised xP/M because they literally made you build 20 smelters for 1 line of ore, but only 10 get filled at any one time due to belt speed limitations
- Speaking of planet builds, lag is a common occurence. Even running with a 3080 and an i7 11800, placing a planetary blueprint will tank the CPU and GPU
- The performance issues can be addressed by giving the player the option to turn off building previews after the blueprint has been placed. This is the leading cause of lag.
- The game can sometimes suffer errors and bugs that will tell you Meta data isn't sync'd, thus disabling achievements. This is a known bug and hasn't been resolved yet.

Whilst I do enjoy playing the game, the issues listed make for a very frustrating time during end game when you're building planetary stuff.
Overall, 7/10.

Truly amazing game. 9/10. I believe this is the most beautiful game I've ever played graphically. Watching the sunrise and sunset from the planets is like nothing else.

For context I would rate base factorio a 7/10, and space exploration Factorio a 10/10. If you like automation, and like space, you'll love this.

My only qualm about this is the lack of extensibility from mod partners and lack of a circuit network. If there was a greater modding community like there is with factorio, I think this game would result in overhaul mods that would be the best experience I've ever had.

I also wish there were more difficult automation puzzles like there are with Factorio space exploration. I've never been as overjoyed as when I automated my first cargo rocket. I wish ILS and PLS in this game had the ability for granular control, and that ability was necessary for some stage of the game.

Overall, with a more feature-rich release, I'm sure I'll update this to a 10/10. Would recommend buying immediately though.
space factorio

It's a factory game. I know you addicts out there need no more info to be sold on it. It good. You buy. 

If you're not an addict and want to know more, Dyson Sphere Program factory game with a mix of traditional factorio stuff, simplified/streamlined you see in Satisfactory, with some interstellar logistics and power generation on top. Not as ugly as factorio (sorry babe still love you) but not as pretty as satisfactory. It's 3D and you can use verticality in your logistics but it doesn't get as vertical as Satisfactory. The research tree is bigger than Satisfactory but smaller than factorio. I know I'm comparing it to those two games a lot but those are what I consider to be the 2 pillars in automation games and I'm guessing if you're looking at Dyson Sphere, you've played one or both of those.

Factory games usually leave me with an urge to replay one of those 2 games, but not Dyson Sphere. It has elements of the best automation games out there, while also having its own personality and take on the genre. With the more futuristic feel and added logistics of ships going between planets it really scratches its own itch. It's really high quality and really easy to pick up. Tutorials are helpful, the user experience is pretty great, and the difficulty curve of the game is pretty easy going. There's really almost nothing negative I can say about it. The devs care a lot and content updates are consistent and meaty (they're adding combat soon). This is not even to mention the cool community stuff they have like designing power armor and a giant galaxy map showing the star systems with the highest power generation. There is a ton of depth if you wanna get really really nerdy and generate insane numbers, but you can also just play it like a regular factory game where your goal is to just complete the tech tree. 

This game is addicting and stimulating its own special way, so much so I would consider it to be the third pillar of automation games. If you're into to factory games at all I think this is a must play.

Very impressive, especially for an early access title.  The aesthetic is pleasing and relaxing, there is always a sense of discovery as you progress, and there's endless tweaking of production efficiency available for those who want it. Ships warp in and out and fly from planet to planet, transporting materials and building your massive dyson sphere a little at a time, and all enabled by your own hand piece by piece.  It's really a treat to watch.  Highly recommended.

Das Spiel in sich selbst ist Genial gemacht. Es bittet viel zu tun, und man kann es auch öffters neu Anfangen, weil man immer wieder Versucht bestimmte punkte im Spiel schneller zu erreichen. 

Leider hat das Spiel ein paar Negative aspekte. 

Mein PC ist nicht der schlechteste:

CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 5700X (Wassergekühlt und leicht Übertaktet)
RAM: 32GB Corsair Vengeance 3600Mhz
2 TB Samsung 970 Evo (Game drive)
GPU: NVidia GForce RTX 3080 10GB

Nicht mehr das neuste aber spielt noch fast alles. Ich spiele das Game auf einem 1440p (QHD) Monitor also 2k. Die Grafik ist Schön, simpel und Genial, das Problem bei Dyson Sphere Programm is die CPU. Das Spiel ist Unglaublich CPU Lastig. Wo meine GPU max 30% Last schafft, ist die CPU ab einem bestimmten Punkt im Spiel fast dauerhaft zu 80-90% Ausgelastet.

Das größere Problem, die Entwickler werden wohl nicht viel dran ändern können da die CPU Belastung von den Logik einheiten, den Drohnen und sdonst was kommt.

Meine Empfehlung, wenn ihr keine gute CPU habt verzichtet auf Logistik Drohen und Logistik Bots, die fressen ne Menge CPU.

ADer rest? Nicht viel zu sagen. Nach 200+ Stunden mein 5ter run in DSP (Dyson Sphere Program) und es macht immer noch undglaublich viel spaß.


Cheers~

A very chill factory/building game that you can play through at your own pace. Has beautiful graphics.
Do you like losing days of your life to maximizing the efficiency of your factory? This game is for you. Highly recommended.

Stands out among the other factory builders in many many ways; unique setting with interplanetary transportation and travel,  VERY elaborate conveyor belt logistics that are in my opinion better than than in other games in this genre that I've played before are some of the highlights. 

Main gameplay loop is similar to Factorio; collect resources, build and expand, research, work on endgame goal - but the setting and intricacies are completely different in a positive way, though both games are great in different ways.

Game is still being developed and receiving major content updates but is already extremely good.

The only issue I have is lack of officially supported multiplayer, but I had no problem using the multiplayer mod to play with friends so far.
And I suppose the fact it's making me stay up late at night is also a bad thing.
Fun factory building. Looking forward to the combat patch.

Is anyone else a little annoyed that Elon Musk had the audacity to put Starlink satellites in orbit that ruin astronomy?

https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2020/1/7/21003272/space-x-starlink-astronomy-light-pollution

If so, you ain't seen NOTHIN' yet!  Before too long (give it another 500-2000 years), earth will be the proud child of a sun that we can no longer see, because it will surrounded by a gigantic sky-enveloping Dyson Sphere!  No more solar eclipses... it will be eclipsed all the time.

And this future - this is what you get to build in Dyson Sphere Program.  Doesn't that sound neat?  Except in this game, you are apparently a lone robot in a desolate lonely solar system, with no other people or life - apparently some civilization sent you here to build up their Dyson Sphere for them to help harness all the stars' energy in the Milky Way.  This civilization is well on its way to becoming a Type 3 civilization - capable of harnessing all the energy in a whole galaxy!

You can read more about the Kardeshev scale here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale

You start out the game with nothing.  Apparently your mother civilization that send you here is leaving it to you to figure out how to research all the technologies to convert the planets you find yourself on into the end product.

Because there are no hazards, you can take all the time you want.  But making things more efficient is really the name of the game, as you don't want to wait exponential time for things to get finished.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3047524848

WARNING: This game will NOT play on a laptop mouse pad.  That part is the worst - I have to go sit at a table with a mouse.  However, another program called "VoiceAttack" allows speaking commands that would normally be issued via the mouse - and this works around the problem, although it's a bit clunky and not as fast as using a mouse.

Other than that, the game plays very much like Satisfactory or Factorio - you know the drill.  Build bigger and better factories while finding resources.  Only this time, some of the resources can't be found on your home planet - you'll have to fly to a different planet to extract them.

It's still in Early Access, but it plays quite clean so far.  I have had some very minor hiccups where I wasn't able to fly, and I think it was related to running out of fuel but the ALT key still had to be hit to free something up.  These minor issues should all be fixed eventually and this wasn't a big deal.

If you only ever played one factory game - this is the one!

Update: I enjoy just painting the ground on planets.  It's very relaxing.  It can also help make it easier to find where I am on a planet.
I built two spheres. I greatly enjoyed my time in this game and will probably reinstall in the future, to build another sphere

Finally gave DSP a go, after playing all the holy trinity (Factorio, Satisfactory & Oxygen Not Included). 

I rank it at the 4th place between those because, Factorio is the king of the genre, Oxygen not Included offers amazing gameplay and the most elaborate puzzle solving of all, Satisfactory is incredibly beautiful and scales up quite nicely for it's size.

Placing DSP at the 4th place doesn't mean that it's bad, in fact it is equally great but it doesn't quite offer the Factorio scale up although it holds on it's own at some parts, especially logistics. However it has the least puzzle solving from all these games and while it's a very pretty game, it's not even remotely close to the Satisfactory world in terms of beauty.

DSP has to offer the amazing goal of building Dyson Spheres, the interplanetary and inter system travel and logistics.

It will be tons of fun for sure, but I'd recommend it after you've done with the rest.

I find it difficult to get my head around where my inefficiencies are. The game doesn't do a great job informing you when something isn't working, or is stuck. There are alarms that you can manually turn on, but as a newcomer to the genre, I had no clue when it was a good idea to do that. This might just have been my issue and learning experience. 

If you've never played a factory game before, this might not be the best starting point for you. 
HOWEVER: Personally I found other options a bit intimidating, and the theme of this one is just too good. If you agree, cannot recommend this game enough.
If you don't care about space, or the idea of a Dyson Sphere, then I think there are better factory games out there for you.
If you like other factory games and get super invested in the logistics, then this game might bother you a bit, I've read that this game does have some odd number mis-matches in the factory chain, so everything doesn't work perfectly all the time. But if you can overlook that, and just accept that your factory will be at least a little inefficient, (or a lot inefficient, if you're not an actual engineer) Then this game's theme brings so much to the factory genre that it is just one you cannot skip.

Dyson Sphere Program (DSP) a nice great challenging automation game.    Each step of the way getting more challenging than the last while building one earlier knowledge.   DSP will require heavy use of number crunching and lots of note taking, but will have fun doing it.  Progressing is smooth, you can get through very quickly or take your time and study each technology or upgrade as you unlock; highly reccomend the later on first playthought.

The UI is outstanding, building is intuitive, there seems to be quick way to do everything need edwith a couple keystrokes or do using only the mouse if that is preferred.   Information is presented in very usable form.   The Blueprint system is great and useful as you build bigger and bigger things.    The progression from local, global, solar system and interstellar is smooth and makes sense.

I have only owned the game for a week but have 100 hours playtime.   When not playing seem to be thinking how I count have done the each build better.    The ONLY short coming I see of DSP is that it is not coop multiplayer.
