[h2] Why should you play it? [/h2]
Do you like the [b]freedom[/b] of being able to build factories in any way you like? This game offers countless of ‘node’ like structures that work interdependently, and by using your most powerful tool, [b]your imagination[/b]; you can accomplish any systematic factory with the tools offered, that is what this game is good at, [b]giving you the freedom[/b]. 

[h2] Rewards, rewards, rewards! [/h2]
Do you like [b]rewards[/b]? Who doesn’t? This game [b]consistently rewards you[/b] for, well, almost anything really; it appreciates the work you put in! So naturally, it will give you rewards – Right besides that awaits a [b]massive skill tree[/b] for you to invest your earned points into; gosh, it just can’t get enough of rewarding you; but here’s the important thing, [b]it does it right[/b], it doesn’t spoil you, but it also doesn’t give you useless rewards, it’s right in the middle, it gives you [b]balanced rewards[/b] based on where you are in the game.

[h2] But oh, the complexity :( [/h2]
The game can get [b]complicated[/b], maybe that’s what you like! But it [b]doesn’t properly guide you[/b] through the game; they do indeed provide text-based guides, but not everyone likes that. It’s hard to neglect this factor, because this game is all about learning & advancing, which is hard to do without any guides; here’s what should be improved, it should provide visualizations on the different mechanics & how each & every structure can be used, with examples; but in the meanwhile, you’ll have to [b]“Youtube your way through success!”[/b]. 

My Final Rating: 9/10

If the answer to any of the above is yes DO NOT buy this game.

https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197975006184/screenshot/1795226463388799306/

[h3]Pros[/h3]

+ Dyson Sphere Program is an exceptionally solid purchase even at full-price if you enjoy automation games (e.g Factorio). Achievements and built-in aspirational goals encourage multiple playthroughs.
+ "Early Access" is laughable in the most positive way. The game feels feature complete with multiple end-game goals, achievements, etc. Solid buy in the current state.
+ Quality of life for factory building and logistics is high. For example, conveyor belts can be raised or drawn around corners. Logistics (local, planetary, and interplanetary) is also a simple supply and demand system.
+ Interplanetary logistics is a core mechanic and required to complete the game, setting itself apart from other automation games. Interstellar logistics is highly encouraged due to higher resource density and rare resources that simplify production chains.
+ Dyson Sphere has more interstellar exploration and mechanics than Starfield. Feels amazing when you use the gravitational mass of a star as a slingshot to increase your speed. Feels terrible when you pass your destination at 2000m/s then run out of fuel and drift aimlessly into space. At least you feel something.
+ The Dyson Sphere is not a required for game completion (to my surprise!). You can start the Dyson Sphere/Swarm in the mid-game and progress as you expand research and production.
+ Completing the Dyson Sphere requires so many resources it's more of a "end-game" or "mega-base" victory. This gives more casual automation players an reasonable conclusion without too much investment, but more dedicated players have a concrete, aspirational goal.

[h3]Cons[/h3]

- Many mid-to-late game components have room for improvement. For example, some have long production chains of intermediaries with often two but occasionally only one use. Alternative uses with new content or more efficient recipes would increase the value.
- Navigation within a planet is challenging in the late game. I frequently found myself flying in circles around a planet looking for that one production line. However, Foundations in DSP can be colored to help organize production lines, and there are some other tactics, like segmenting a planet by longitudes since north and south poles are always defined. One feature improvement would be an intra-planetary indicatory similar to what already exists between planets.

[h3]Verdict[/h3]

Buy. I can't believe this game is in early access--it feels complete.

I saw a content creator play this and thought I'd pick it up on sale.
Started playing it for little bit and after a small learning curve, got sucked in.
Stopped for a while and then picked it up again after the updates and it has turned into one of those 'I'm just going to drop a few miners on this planet' and a couple hours later you have a full mining planet.

The graphics are beautiful, especially when you launch into space to check out your Dyson Sphere for the first time.
The music is soothing and calming.
The math can be challenging (but not necessary to enjoy the game)

There are very few bugs and they have made a ton of quality of life improvements in the game. And after you have built out your factory on a planet, you can have the pleasure of going back to optimize everything.

This is one early access game you will not regret if you're into factory games.

Dyson Sphere Program is a game that will make you feel like a power-mad god, tripping balls on stardust. As you build your Dyson Sphere, you'll harness the power of stars to create a vast and complex industrial empire, stretching across the cosmos like a psychedelic spiderweb. It's a game that will test your sanity and your engineering skills, but if you're successful, you'll be rewarded with a feeling of power and accomplishment that is truly mind-blowing.

The game's procedurally generated universe is a never-ending source of wonder and amazement. There's always something new to discover, from bizarre alien planets to exotic resources that defy the laws of physics. It's like a DMT-fueled journey through the multiverse.

The automation system in Dyson Sphere Program is a work of genius. It allows you to create incredibly complex production lines that can run without your intervention. This is essential if you want to build a truly massive Dyson Sphere, but it's also a lot of fun to watch your automated factories running smoothly. It's like watching a symphony of machines working together in perfect harmony, like a giant cosmic ballet.

Dyson Sphere Program is like a cosmic acid trip. It's challenging, rewarding, and mind-bending. If you're looking for a game that will push you to your limits, then Dyson Sphere Program is the game for you.

This game is the video game embodiment of crystal meth. I'm not even kidding.

The first time you try to play you have no idea what the fuck is happening but the more you play the more you get locked onto it. Minutes turn into hours that just disappear in the blink of an eye. You start focusing on conveyor belts. You start thinking of ways to set up massive space factories.

Then as soon as you think you're done you unlock the next step and do it all over again. And again. And again.

You're going to get scattered like a junkie scratching at the furniture as your home planet looks like an absolute mess.

Then you're going to look back and hate yourself. You'll tear it all down and promise to do it properly next time.

So you do. You'll spend 5 hours pulling apart everything you've done and you start again. What was previously a mish mash of conveyor belts everywhere now turns into carefully and meticulously planned logistic systems. Your planet has sections dedicated to individual materials.

You have become the alpha crystal meth addict.

And you will love it.

The human race has achieved technological singularity and consciousness exists within an information cloud. Without the biological and physical constraints of existing in actual space, the only thing we need to thrive is energy... and we need a lot of it.

Your consciousness is uploaded to an Icarus, a construction and prospecting mech, and you are assigned to a cluster of actual space to harvest that energy and channel it into the singularity.

DSP's gameplay is essentially inspired by Factorio but across a 32 star cluster in space connected through other clusters in the cloud.

The game is great for early access. With some serious QoL improvements it could be a worthy successor of Factorio.

Unfortunately right now there are quite a few severe QoL issues, the biggest ones:
* blueprints basically only work if what you copied and what you're pasting were at about the same latitude. Even the simplest ones like "two belts and a row of smelters" refuse to work if you paste them a bit too high or a bit too low
* and if you don't use blueprints, placing large number of sorters is a huge much pain. If copying/pasting machine settings also copied/pasted associated sorters, that would remove 90% of this pain. Either that or reliably working blueprints, right now the game has neither.
* in-game help is obviously machine translated from Chinese - early game it doesn't really matter, but late game things like ray receivers, Dyson Sphere etc. are "explained" with some machine translated gibberish
* space travel is very unintuitive, and not really explained anywhere, and you can find yourself overshooting your target and lost in space with no energy to turn back and having to reload save. Or stuck on gas giant with no energy and having to reload save. Gotchas like that add nothing to the game, it really should just be "point at planet, press button"
* there's a bunch of other things like for example it would be nice to have Factorio "logistics trash slots" for small things you pick up every time you rewire some belts, production summary could also include imports/exports, and so on, but such minor potential improvements don't cause problems the ways ones above do

And for non-QoL issue, single item "modular" builds with logistics stations are too good, and their alternatives (belts, bots, more complicated factories) too weak, so by mid-game everything looks the same - logistics station, some belts out, one or two rows of factories, belt back in, and maybe some extra lines for proliferators and warpers.

And to "win" the game, you need to produce 4000 white science, which takes forever, but you can't really speed it up much, so the game is pretty much asking you to leave it running for the last hour or two, while you watch Netflix on another screen. If you plan to continue playing beyond "win" message, then there's definitely stuff to do, but this is not great. Before that "win the game" tech, tech tree is quite nice.

If you're willing to overlook such issues, and early access Factorio had them as well, it's a great game. Expect something like ~50h to win the first campaign. Hopefully it will get even better by the time of its full release.

Highly addictive game. If you're interested in both factory simulators and the vast beauty of outer space, this game is without a doubt for you.

Despite how hard I try to veer away from this game, it's almost impossible to get bored, even when you're in the late endgame—there is simply too much room for growth and scaling your factory to make more science, more Dyson spheres, more everything.

There is a sharp spike in difficulty—(I'd call it a learning curve)—between red- and yellow-science, and an even sharper one between that and purple/green-science. Be prepared to plan, don't forget about resource costs, space, or power. Just like any other factory game.

Still this one maintains a personal preference above others, simply because there's so much awe in exploring new star systems and planets, or watching your interstellar logistics highways soar across the star cluster from a distance. Or simply admiring the enormous scale of stars and gas planets as your home planet orbits them. Both a factory game and a sightseeing experience. Worth more than what I paid for it.

I'd say that this game can land somewhere in the middle between Satisfactory and Factorio, which are both more expensive but stronger games. 

DSP lacks the polish in it's approach. While you're using belts, you do not need scale, most of the tech tree you pass with mere couple assemblers and you just upgrade them to faster versions. There's no explosive growth as in Factorio. Mostly, you are forced to move to logistic systems. However it is not because of throughput, but because of lack of resources on starting planet, some of them just do not spawn here. At the same point, game forces you to carry some resources manually couple times from other planets since you need those to build ILS, which is really inconvenient and points more to Satisfactory. You also can build belts on multiple levels which is closer to satisfactory, but production buildings are still mostly are flat. Would be way more fun if you could stack them as well, producing different products on different floors.

ILS itself feels too bulky for the time you get it and overall, but rather powerful. It even feels a bit OP.

I guess overall the game points you at extensive scaling, but it does not really require that, so at some point you just feel plucking a single building to produce one product and think: why? If I needed million items of this product, yes, I could scale, but for most of the products coupe assemblers is mostly enough. There's way too much overhead with ILS/conveyors per output required.

The final goal is really unclear. You just progress the research tree, pluck more production buildings, but rarely need to review or scale earlier parts.

Planets are all same size and I'd say they're on the borderline of claustrophobic compared to the building sizes. Wish different planet sizes (build-area related) were available.

A minor gimmick: wish it had more physics in the game. DSP points at cool sci-fi project, but there's more fantasy in the game than I'd like, unfortunately.

You have an option to scale up, but it's more optional post-game than mandatory and/or organic part of gameplay.

On the good side is nice graphics, neat production chain, smooth progression regarding the main character (not so much overall). Game doesn't have enemies, but if you want some meditative eyecandy experience with no bulkiness of Factorio, this game would be a really good experience even in current state, just don't expect too much of it as of yet.

If developers maintain the same smoothness of gameplay down the line when adding enemies and add a bit of reason for scaling, this can grow into a great title.

This game is worth every penny.

It's a sandbox game in the engineering genre. Sure the default game mode makes you work for it, but there isn't any threat in the game. I've "completed" the game in my opinion, I've built a Dyson Sphere shell and fully filled it in, I've also filled out the tech tree and gotten atleast one point in each of the infinitely repeatable tech nodes. Having said that, I'm glad I've completed the main objective of the game. I had gotten to a point of maintenance mode to where I could just let the game run and do its thing and me interacting with it would have only gotten marginally to the end goal only slightly faster.

In the end, it's worth playing, but I'm glad I'm done playing it. I was getting bored, but wanted to meet my goal for the game, so I pressed on. I don't see myself coming back to it any time soon. Trying to improve would only put in the tier of fanaticism or obsessive expansion. 

Putting it up against the two other games I've played in its space: Factorio and Satisfactory.

1) Factorio was my introduction into this genre. I don't think DSP got me as hooked, and I haven't been as compelled to do DSP's achievements as Factorio's. Factorio, though has its quirks, just feels more polished and the need to keep expanding in Factorio is stronger for me. The bit of aggro from combat in Factorio adds a more interesting element to the game. Expansion in Factorio has to be planned more due to threats, DSP has no threats so expansion is more of a getting what you need, warp there, setup a basic gather setup and ship it back.

2) Satisfactory also feels more polished then DSP. It also has far more mechanics than DSP. The mechanics of Satisfactory are also far more interesting. Death is always looming in Satisfactory on just the horizon, you as an engineer have to be clever and good to survive. Eventually, you feel accomplished in having reduced threats to minimal in Satisfactory though, but it is still there. The blueprints is far more polished in Satisfactory as well.

DSP is a good game, I do recommend it. If you are trying to decide between DSP and Factorio or Satisfactory, pick one of the latter two first. Then once you need a break from those two give DSP a try. I was disappointed to find no combat in DSP, but for some that might be a draw to it. Blueprinting in DSP can be annoying to deal with, laying out a design can break at different regions because of grid issues. I researched several tech nodes that I never saw a need for. Why would I want to stack more things on a belt when I can just move it faster? Why would I want to increase efficiency when expanding is just easier?

DSP is a good game, I liked it, but I didn't love it. It didn't hook me like other games in the genre.

One of the least annoying resource management/city builder games out there. Fairly easy to learn but lots of complexity. Placing conveyors, connecting things ect, is really easy to do, its a pleasure to build stuff. Very chill, no pressure to build something by a certain time and you learn as you go.  Lots of cool little things like all the planets in your solar system are visible in the sky and are to scale based on distance.  Eventually you will travel to those planets and moons searching for more resources to send back to your home planet to feed the research machine.  Eventually with enough technology and 100's of your real life hours killed, you can colonise other solar systems.  Right around this point you will have most of the good tech and start to realise you didnt do the best job designing your first planet, you were still learning after all.  This is your chance to build a masterpiece with all the technology and materials you acquired on your home planet.  Plays smooth regardless of how big you build. This game is very well done

This game is all the best things combined between Factorio and Satisfactory. The logistics system is excellent with the planetary and interstellar towers that you unlock quite early (relatively) in the tech tree. The exploration of the solar system and star cluster feels earned and super fun to execute. Most recipes feel balanced. I really like the ability to change the viewing perspective as I prefer the top down view you get in Factorio. I tend to exclusively stay in flying/hover mode above my planets while I construct my factory. And yet I also really enjoy the 3D aspect similar to Satisfactory. When I do touch down, I love to change the camera angle to look at the stars and planets through my factory skyline.

Above all, this game is GORGEOUS!! Flying through my dyson swarm from planet to planet, or even looking at my dyson swarm lit up from the planet surface never fails to make me smile. The construction of the dyson sphere/shells is also extremely satisfying as you can watch all your hard work slowly come to fruition.

I am reviewing this before the update that will introduce combat/ enemies, but as I don't plan to play with enemies enabled, I don't think it will change my opinions of the game.

This plays exactly how it looks, between satisfactory and factorio. Unfortunately, it fails to solve many of the issues of satisfactory's 3d building while it simultaneously cranks the required infrastructure up to factorio levels.

I could go into detail about everything, but it boils down to setting up your factory is slow and tedious. 
-Everything takes multiple clicks to set up. Inserters, assemblers, belts, everything. certain parts can be clicked and draged, but not everything. It tries to be smart about belt placement but fails.
-Z height stacking belts feels necessary for throughput but is a pain to deal with, as you cant directly move items vertically, and need to bring belts to ground level for many buildings. Additionally the UI for doing so is just generally not great.
-you cannot place buildings normally, and your bots are limited in number, slow, and chug your mechs power. This makes the already arduous task of building things at scale even more painful
-The nighttime sucks and you cant see anything at all. Kick your feet up lol!

Actual playing hours: about 240 (It's the kind of game I will leave open until I come back from whatever).

This is my favourite game of the last 10 years. Every time I come back to it, I get addicted again for several weeks during which, when I'm free and not in the game, I'm thinking about it or reading its reddit space. Anything I say about DSP will not make it justice, but it's about time I post a review, so here goes nothing.

I love Cities: Skylines, Oxygen Not Included and sim games in general, and I love sci-fi, so this was a predictable match. Still, this game unexpectedly offered me what No Man's Sky could not: The feeling of grandeur, of massive space exploration, of getting lost in space to slowly build your way up to conquering it and moving in it as if your home is everywhere. The landscapes are awe-inspiring, both the natural and the ones built by you, with amazing graphics.

But that's not the game's core. Its core is [b] automation [/b] , and the freedom on the speed to approach it is fantastic. Some people start automating everything away, crunching numbers and even making spreadsheets to find the most efficient factory blueprint. Some others, like me, were doing some things manually up to the point of getting tired and automating some of it, slowly but surely building our way to massive factories that nonetheless work like a charm. Except now that I expanded my processor factory, suddenly I'm not producing enough silicon...

DSP doesn't push you out of your comfort zone until you want, but you have to in order to advance, and it rewards you with that pride that only us creators know well. Making your factory work is quite easy. Making it beautiful, or bigger, or efficient in space or energy or resources, or whatever you want, that is up to you. And the 3D of it all just tops it off. You will feel all your other sims' maps too flat after this. You know you are in a sphere, and you want to.

This is by no means what you'd expect from an Early Access. I have been playing this treat for a year and a half, and it keeps getting better.

I would absolutely recommend this beast, 10/10 as it is now, even without the [b] upcoming optional combat update [/b]. With the update, though, I'm afraid I will need higher numbers to rate it. And holidays.
very good

Gotta be honest, this is by far the worst of the big three factory games at the moment. This, Factorio, and Satisfactory, This is much closer to Factorio though, and even with taking Early Access into account, Factorio just seems the much better option.

Logistics just seems off, movement and controls never feel quite right, and because of this not being a native English speaking team, reading tooltips and your AI companion is a chore in itself. The Create function make worthy of factory expansion heavily. Did that read like nonsense? That's what a lot of lines end up being like. This probably will be fixed through full release but it makes playing the game now way harder. 

UI is my biggest issue probably. Some stuff is listed in per minute amounts. Other, per second amounts. You have to manually convert back and forth and it's just so... not good. And when you get to the complex logistical chains, it becomes way too much. Early game - or at least what feels like the early game, I'm close to unlocking the 4th level of science - the chains you have to deal with are far more complex than even what end-game Factorio has.

Early game Dyson Sphere puts you into Oil production. Oil production as a base creates two products, including leading right into Plastic which has no real way to spend until you get a few more upgrades on the tech tree. But then there's converting purified oil into acid for other things and the hydrogen atoms are needed for these rockets and... 

It's basically like, if you aren't already a near expert in this genre then you're just going to be boned. And this is before Combat becomes a thing. Once it does, how does that factor in? Factorio already ties combat into your normal production line. One of the science actively uses military pieces, so if you make it that far without a proper ammo production, you'll make one just out of a need to create science. Any extras at that point become offensive and defensive tools.

How is this going to tie into Dyson Sphere? I already feel like I'm being pushed to the limit. You have to set up interplanetary travel just to get required resources and it's just... too much. Complex, hard, and a chore to understand. I was hoping to enjoy this while I wait for Satisfactory to finally see full release some day, but I feel like I'll just be suffering if I do play more.

At the very least I could have hoped it did something unique, but it truly just does feel like Factorio but harder to understand and just plain harder.

Edit: So unliked, this is the first ever game I've tried to refund. Naturally was denied due to the slow burn of factory games surpassing 2 hours but... well, I tried.

Doesn't help that Factory Game players also seem to be the absolute most toxic people ever. It's a single player game and yet people love to be toxic.

While locked into the details of creating a gigantic, galaxy-spanning logistics base, the game surprises over and over again with beautiful outer space landscapes from the barren moons with pools of sulfuric acid to the lush Mediterranean worlds rich in organics. Over and over, especially when the actual Dyson Sphere is being assembled, I stop and just watch the logistics network operate with the beauty of bright solar panels streaming towards a blue-white star with a scaffold of sphere components and logistics ships launching then streaking away in a faster-than-light jump.

I get there because the game play is smooth, consistent, and easy to learn with depth that reveals itself as the network grows more complicated and requires new combinations and interactions of resources and manufacture. It's so smooth that there are times that the interface can disappear, and I'm able to imagine what I want to do and just do it.

This is the next generation of Factorio, although the logistics don't have the hyper-optimization that Factorio lets you create, with newer, more impressive visuals akin to what the original Kerbal Space Program creates as a routine part of just playing the game.

Finally, the developers are improving the game constantly. I return every few months to do a play through, and each time, the interface is just a little more polished, there are new ideas that can be used in the logistics network, the graphics are just a little sharper, and there's some detail like a new world type or new element in the tech tree.

Enjoying this a lot and I keep coming back to it.

It is massive.  The scope of the game is mind boggling, which mean it has longevity. 
It doesnt tell you what to do or how to play, but, it does offer useful guidance along the way.

The concept is ambitious. It is open so you don't feel like it compromised because it was going to be a console game or not (no idea, if it is or isn't) but the quality says it was designed to be the best it could be by a bunch of folk that wanted it to be the best it could be.

It is.  The way you can move between planets seemlessly is a joy.  The variety and imagination of the technologies you can research and the ways you can configure your production are a joy to behold.

It is a lot of fun and yet, very relaxing while being enormously addictive.

It is almost a god game.  It certainly has that perspective but it centers on a mech avatar figure.  The graphics put me off a bit at first. They are well drawn but I wouldnt call it beautiful.  But, nor do they impede the experience. I think a good balance has been struck here. Especially considering the vast scope of the multi planetary epic. 

It runs well. Not had a single crash or issue. Whether zoomed right out or close in, even with lots going on, no slow down and no glitching.  Another point of note is that unlike some other games, the game saves almost instantly, exits almost instantly for the same reason.  Not sitting there waiting forever for a save to finish.

The sound is ok. If there is one area of the game which feels a bit bland, this is it.  The music is nice but the atmospheric sounds and so on could have gone further. However, this is a minor point as the overall audio does not impede things. I just think it could have gone further.

Eminently re playable but it is unlikely you will exhaust your first play through as it is so satisfyingly massive in scope. 

A very welcome game.  It has the sort of massive scope and vision that has been sadly lacking for a long time.  We are talking interplanetary done with depth.  This is a masterpiece of a game. 

The tech tree and progress keeps drip feeding you progress and you have to think about your objectives and which to prioritise.

It does all this while being very addictive and yet extremely relaxing and enjoyable to play.   More please.

I love this game. The learning curve is there, but not daunting either. This was my first attempt at a factory style game and it has me hooked.
Zero issues or bugs. This is an amazing game!

The game itself is not very realistic way to explain how the future of humanity will work and live in space. I don't see any Tritium. And you are robot (or at least inside robotic suit). You're alone in the star systems. Even-though their is no enemy to kill you, the base development to put game forward is really challenging. Maybe because of their music, when I finally travel to another star system and land on Earth-like planet, I feel in love of the space travel, they simulate...

This game is, along with Factorio, my absolute favorite factory automation games.

The strength of this game compared to Factorio is in its ability to create the feeling of massive scale, having production lines between planets and warping both yourself and goods literal light years. The Dyson Spheres you can design and build are also just awesome to behold and I love that you produce and physically launch rockets and solar sails to build them.

The game runs well and the gameplay and QoL is good for a early access title, although the tutorial narrator and English translations definitely need some work. There are also some frustrating elements regarding multiple outputs of materials that can cause clogging in some production chains, I feel there should be more ways to deal with stuff like that. I also feel that the concept of soil to fill concrete on water can be frustrating.

I still highly recommend this game to anyone that like Factory games, this is one of the very best ones.

But in all seriousness, DSP is by far and away the most polished ambitious EA title that I have ever played. The sheer scale and complexity are made easy by easy to learn concepts and innovative ideas. 
Despite being an incredibly ambitious concept, DSP on launch was effectively COMPLETE, as the entire gameplay loop was finished and one could finish the entire game as it was advertised and intended. Everything that has been added past release has been been sweet icing on an already exceptionally tasty cake.
Planet-sized factories, gorgeous graphics, zero crashes, utterly outstanding interface.

Even though this game is still early access, it is pretty polished from a gameplay standpoint.

Some of the translations (and actually voiceovers) are a little rough - and even missing in some rare occasions, but so far have only been for situations where it's obvious what the English would be.

At a high level, it's in the same genre as Factorio, but the scale is massive in comparison.

Played a good bit in Satisfactory before I picked this up. First pass, I played about 25 minutes and put it away for months. It was too big of a paradigm shift. I tried again twice, and after putting in about 5 hours I really started to enjoy DSP. It takes a while to get into the right jam for this game, but if top-down builder games are your vibe pick this up. If not, give it a shot and be willing to put a few hours in before reserving judgment. 
Content is fairly wide but not very deep -- that being said, "wide" has thus-far been 20 hours and I am only a third of the way through tech tree. I feel 60 hours to achieve "success" or close to it will be realistic and for any EA game, that's a great start. I am interested to see where the devs take the game. 

I would also offer to help the devs with their English translations -- while fairly good there are some prevalent incongruities that, in some cases, seems to detract from the experience. 

Overall I give Dyson Sphere Program 7.5/10, and will gladly update this to 9/10 if the devs level-load their updates :)

I'm an old gamer, my first PC games were on Radio Shack TRS-80 back in about 1979. So I have witnessed the entire PC gaming evolutionary history.

After building my first few Dyson swarm guns, I sat back and watched it populate the night sky. I was awestruck, thinking back to how much the very simple games of the late 70's and early 80's has progressed. I could sit back and watch the Swarm forming in the night sky while standing on my planet. Beautiful sight.

It has been awhile since I have had such a "wow!" moment in a game, but I have had a few such moments over the course of gaming in the past 4 decades. Those games become unforgettable.

This game is of course very similar to Factorio, so if you liked Factorio (as I did) you will like this. But the scale of the game puts it above Factorio in my opinion. Very addicting. 

There is a combat update coming later this year (2023) which will complete the experience I think (It is promised you can toggle combat off if it is not your cup of tea).

This is an excellent game BUT it has a steep learning curve. There's no tutorial and it's extremely frustrating to have to constantly TAB out of the game to find info on how to do everything. Games of this complexity MUST have a robust tutrorial and perhaps even beginner missions. Getting to another planet was hugely frustrating and end with me giving up on the game and writing this negative review.

As I said at the start, the game is wonrdefully crafted and engineered. There's a huge tech tree to research and tons of things to do. A lot of thought has gone into the logitics and physics of the simulation. This is where the deverlopers shine. Graphics are decent although I personally do not like the earth curvature aspect. 

My time is too valuable to be constantly in frustration mode trying to figure out which key does what. A lot of the commands are NOT intuitive. Some buildings provide an automatic conveyor connection while others require what is called a sorter even though it's only picking up an item from the conveyor belt to the building. Belts don't alwaysd line up with the input/output ports of the buildings so the sorters don't fit and you get "angle" errors. That's all part of early access of course.

If you'rew willing to sufferstruggle through the learning curve and like like industry/settlement simulation building games then you'll love this game, esapecially if you find it on sale. BUT, I believe getting past mid-game will require a lot of time invested OUTSIDE the game learning how to play it.

Love this game!!! The colors, the smoothness, flying through space!!! The next update with the FOG ((the "enemies")) Looks to be pretty amazing too!! and with the ability to opt out I'm sure it'll still bring changes for everyone!! 

My biggest complain would be that there is NO multiplayer!!! Unless you do a work around with a few other programs... which is kinda annoying!!! If they would just do it themselves that would be pretty cool!!

All in all if you enjoy factory building games, I do recommend adding this one to your collection!!!
Like Factorio but with awesome scale

Simply the best game I have ever played! It has kept me engaged without a minute of boredom for 160+ hours.

I am a big fan of big budget franchise games (StarCraft, Half Life, CyberPunk, etc), and I was desperately looking for another game that would give me the same level of enjoyment as I have experienced in the past. I found that in DSP and much more.

The esthetics of this game are simply stunning, the vastness and possibilities are mind-blowing. The game play is well thought of, and the attention to details is impressive. The ambition is quite unique as you will be managing a civilisation from level 0 to level I, and then to level II on the Kardashev scale.

I absolutely loved the game play. It's a complex game with a somewhat long learning curve to get to understand all its features, but the learning process is just a pleasure. The game play is served at a pace that makes it easy to learn each next feature, you never get overwhelmed.

With DSP you are going to start with humble beginnings as a robot tediously harvesting wood and minerals by hand on a small planet. By the end, you will control and manage fleets of intergalactic drone vessels that will ship resources for you at a grand scale. One of the most interesting part of the game is how the whole game experience changes as you gain in technology and energy production capacity. At the beginning you are stuck on a small planet trying to get by. But one day you have enough resource to attempt your first exploration into your star system, and that’s an amazing experience. The views are absolutely stunning as well.

Big kudos to the developers of DSP. I haven't experienced any bug; everything works flawlessly as it should. This is impressive considering that the development team has been working on a budget compared to big gaming studios. Even the music is excellent. Always appropriate, focus-driving, and never boring.

DSP is amazing, I just cannot find anything to complain about. I am just eagerly awaiting the upcoming upgrades and game extensions. I can imagine how this game could evolve so you end up controlling entire galaxies as per the theoretical level III of the Kardashev scale. I just can’t wait what the developers have in store for us. In the meaning I will keep playing!

Don't be fooled by the "Early Access" tag on this game. It's a complete game, and anything else they build after this point is just going to be icing on the cake.  It's also remarkably bug free, very detailed, and deeply engaging.

If you enjoy factory/process games like Factorio or Satisfactory, you'll probably like this one. It hits a sort-of middle-ground between them in that it's 3D, but not first-person.  

It's peaceful in that there are no enemies (they'll be coming in as an option later, as I understand it) so you'll be just playing to figure out the best way to do things.  It can be as relaxing or as stressful as you want... I found it to be a very relaxing game to get into.  Designing little segments of factory to streamline my production processes was quite pleasant.

In short... start on a planet with a mech... mine some stuff, build some stuff, research some stuff... set up a small complex to do all that automatically... then expand that to include new technologies... then spread to other worlds... find rare elements and incorporate those... and you can go from mining iron to make ingots, all the way up to antimatter storage containers and artificial suns.

You can set up quite a complex logistical system involving conveyor belts and drones. Surface drones, AND interplanetary drones. Mine on one planet and ship to another, etc.

The ultimate goal is to build a Dyson Sphere to power the civilisation that sent you to the galaxy.

You can 'end' the game by researching to an end-goal... or you can build to complete your sphere... or you can just set yourself a goal and keep going until you've achieved that.

Your factory can scale up an extraordinary amount. I was really amazed with how much could actually be happening with this game, and my (mid-range) PC wasn't slowing down at all. 

The game is very pretty... and seeing your Dyson sphere/swarm rise above the horizon for the first time is epic stuff.

There are a few quality-of-life things missing, but not many. I would've liked the ability to set up holographic signposts to remind me where things were, for example.  Trying to find the SINGLE factory you've got building 'x' component, when you've got a whole factory making stuff, can be annoying... but it's not game-breaking.

I finished this game in 123 hours by completing the research tree. I still only have my Dyson sphere at around 40% completion, with some research left to go on that to allow me to build it... so I could keep going if I wanted to. (I likely will).  I'd say this game has quite a bit of replayability.

Very-much recommended.

Nearly at the 50 hour mark so now is as good a time as any to make an early review of the game, although I'm absolutely certain I'll be back to update this as I learn more. To be clear I started one save file and have stuck with it, this is made possibly only because of how accessible the game is to letting the player make mistakes, I'm still not actually sure you can truly 'waste' resources on anything as yet either, most of what is produced goes to another use or will be later on.

Where do you even start when all the other reviews covered all the key points? For one thing the game refunds all materials if you deconstruct stuff so you can feel free to rip apart entire lines of production and build it back more efficiently.. and believe it or not that is one of the most fun things thanks to the almost instant building mechanics. Huh?

Let me go into further detail, you don't actually partake in building yourself as such. Your character sends out drones that do it for you almost instantly and it strongly encourages the player to tear things down and build it back up, you don't really lose anything except some minor production time in the whole process either, though I suppose you could just build a makeshift simple conveyor to keep things running while you fine-tune the process.

The game does building on a planet which is obviously circular but then it wants you to build in directional patterns, with this in mind it is nothing short of impressive that the developers made such a silly looking concept work. It is barely noticeable too! Don't get me wrong I wasn't thinking it would be extremely awkward to use when I heard about it but I did have some reservations about how it would affect sprawling factories in the mid and late game and now I'm here to say at the early mid game it hasn't changed much if any of my original building plans so +1 to the developers on this.

Honestly this game draws me in with the allure of something that might be possible to build in reality in the far distant future and lets me glimpse what it might be like now, there is almost no other games in my library where I can say the same thing about them and it fills me with a bit of excitement to think that I can not only build a Dyson Sphere soon but I can gaze upon it. 
Adding onto the above let me just say building a ring of solar sails around the sun and gazing up at them is one of the most beautiful and breathtaking things I have seen put into gaming, no I don't speak of graphics or anything but rather the image you behold seeing them swirling around a sun is just.. I never get tired of looking at the ring I placed and it is truly impossible to put the pride you feel into words seeing it set up and functional.

Also what isn't shown on my account is the amount of hours I spent looking up what Dyson Spheres actually look like, what purpose they might serve, what the need to build them would be and many many other things that were nothing shy of the most fascinating reading material I ever read, on par with the marvels of science today I daresay. At least a few hours were spent just taking it all in, there's barely any other games that have given me the desire to go and look things up and provided me entertainment value outside of the game itself, it explored and introduced so many things I would have never read and I feel better for it, maybe part of this is because I know my generation will never see a Dyson Spere in reality.

Absolutely recommend this game if you're interested in factory building, I paid almost full price and I feel like 50 hours in I am still scratching the surface in some regards. The sense of wonder hasn't disappeared and the expected desire to restart is nonexistent, I feel like I could break from this game all month and still return and get up to speed with where I was previously, after of course I had a short walk of my factory and took inventory of everything.

The game also has absolutely brilliant storage and really makes me happy to be able to carry around so many things with me at once, there's no weight system in place so you just bolt things into slots and place them when needed. 

Almost at the end of my review but I must give praise to the recent logistics introduced at the end of september, the developers have given us buildings to place onto storage that will deliver to us the player or to other buildings after we tweak some simple settings. In the most simple terms this is a very effective and viable early, mid and even late game addition that lets us build anything within very generous range and have it hand (drone) delivered to us on demand, of all features I've seen this has to be the most genius thing about the game I've seen, I really appreciate this devs!!!!

That's all I have to say right now, I will likely tear this review apart later on and rebuild it better next time.. in the spirit of DSP ;)

I couldn't get into factorio or satisfactory because it was missing the space element. This covers everything I've been wishing for.
I've only played ~90h so far and I can tell you I'm taking my time and discovering every little exciting mechanics in this game.
You can customize your mech pretty much as much as you want. Some people have crazy custom files that you can download to have yours looking like a Gundam or anything you want.
The space element is so awesome you can warp to other systems as much as you want as long as you have the resources to do so.
You can build small and slowly to research technologies (and there is a lot of em) or you can just build entire planets with dyson swarm and spheres as much as you want.
The game runs soooo smooth it's insane too.
I had this game on my backlog for so long and tried it when it first launched in early access but now we're almost at 1.0 and WOW.

If you're like me and you like space games with really good UI and graphics, customization and a lot of fun without feeling stressed by time limits and factories then this game is definitely for you!

Buy it you wont regret it.

It's an easy recommendation from me to anyone who enjoys automation style games and space/sci-fi/future themes.

PROS:

+ Visually spectacular
+ Cleverly executed sci-fi elements
+ Laying out factories and automating is great fun
+ Exploring the galaxy is great fun
+ The quality and usability of the UI is mostly extremely good
+ You get to build a freaking Dyson Sphere

CONS

- Some of the translations into English are ... real bad, like they just fed everything into a machine translator, but that is understandable while it's in Early Access.
- Sometimes the grid system on planets can be a pain in the butt to work with, like conveyor belts doing weird jinks and blueprints that work in one place but not another. But there will always be trade-offs like that when you're trying to use a rectangular grid system on spheroidal worlds.
- Some tedious tasks cannot (currently) be automated, like putting down orbital collectors on gas giants.
- The tech tree layout doesn't quite make sense, there are a few hidden dependencies that can be frustrating, like you can research Strange Matter, but you can't build the machine to actually make Strange Matter until you have researched this other technology from a totally separate part of the tree.

Quick Description:
-Dyson Sphere Program is a top tier factory building automation game inspired by Factorio.  This game absolutely rocks and still hasn't tapped it's full potential.  They have some pretty interesting plans this year, as they enter their third year in early access.  I found this game to be more accessible than Factorio or Satisfactory and has a gorgeous visual style.  It doesn't have the depth of complexity that Factorio offers, but it does a pretty damn good job competing w/ the juggernauts of this genre.  

Consensus:  
-Excellent Game (Tier 2 and makes up 25% of my reviews).  This game has the potential to be just as challenging, engaging,  and addictive as Factorio.  Even now, just two years into early access, it is a well polished, incredibly fun automation game that can easily give players hundreds of hours of fun.  This year, the devs plan to introduce some sort of weapon system, enemies, or some kind of danger that will add a much needed layer of challenge and stress to this experience. Dyson Sphere Program, developed by Youthcat Studio, is an ambitious and captivating space simulation and management game that takes players on a journey to harness the power of a Dyson Sphere. With its deep complexity, expansive gameplay mechanics, and vast scope, Dyson Sphere Program offers an immersive experience where players can explore, automate, and expand their interstellar empire.

Boundless Exploration and Construction:
Dyson Sphere Program invites players to embark on an intergalactic adventure, exploring a procedurally generated universe with countless star systems, planets, and resources to discover. From humble beginnings on a single planet, players will advance their technology, research new technologies, and build an intricate network of interstellar infrastructure.

The game's construction mechanics are nothing short of extraordinary. Players can design and construct factories, assembly lines, and logistics networks to automate resource gathering, processing, and manufacturing. The level of complexity is immense, allowing for creative and efficient solutions to maximize production and expand across the cosmos.

Technological Advancement and Resource Management:
Dyson Sphere Program offers a vast tech tree, enabling players to research and unlock new technologies that drive the advancement of their civilization. From simple power generators to advanced machinery and robotics, each technological milestone brings new possibilities and challenges.

Resource management is crucial in Dyson Sphere Program. Players must carefully plan and balance the extraction, processing, and distribution of resources across their sprawling empire. This requires strategic decision-making and optimization to ensure a steady supply of materials for construction and development.

Engaging Challenges and Exploration:
As players progress, they will encounter various challenges and obstacles that test their problem-solving skills. From hostile alien forces to complex energy management, Dyson Sphere Program constantly presents new and engaging hurdles to overcome. Exploring different star systems, uncovering ancient ruins, and encountering unique planetary conditions adds a sense of wonder and excitement to the gameplay experience.

Visually Stunning and Ambitious Sound Design:
Dyson Sphere Program presents a visually stunning universe, with beautifully rendered planets, asteroids, and cosmic phenomena. The attention to detail in the game's graphics creates a sense of immersion as players traverse the vastness of space and witness the intricate machinery and infrastructure they have constructed.

The sound design complements the visual experience, with a mesmerizing soundtrack that captures the grandeur of space exploration. The hum of machinery, the crackling of energy, and the ambient sounds of the cosmos further enhance the immersion and create a captivating atmosphere.

Modding Support and Future Development:
Dyson Sphere Program features modding support, allowing players to extend and enhance their gameplay experience with user-generated content. The modding community is actively engaged, creating additional features, optimizations, and expanding the game's possibilities even further. This support ensures a continuously evolving and exciting experience for players.

Conclusion:
Dyson Sphere Program is a remarkable space simulation game that immerses players in the grandeur of galactic automation and exploration. Its vast scope, intricate gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals create an immersive experience that rewards strategic thinking, resource management, and creativity. With the potential for endless expansion and modding support, Dyson Sphere Program offers an epic journey into the depths of space and the wonders of technology.

Dyson Sphere Program is a game that manages to combine the intricate mechanics of resource management, automation, and logistics planning with the awe-inspiring scale of galactic exploration. It's a deep and rewarding experience that offers countless hours of gameplay.

The game starts you off on a lonely planet with the task of building a factory from scratch. As you progress, you'll find yourself expanding to other planets and even other star systems, laying down thousands of conveyor belts, assembling machines, mining rigs, and power plants, all in the name of resource collection and automation.

The game's voxel-based graphics are beautifully rendered and the user interface, while complex, is intuitive after you get the hang of it. The visuals of constructing and observing your interstellar factory are stunning. There's something uniquely satisfying about watching your little drones buzz around, carrying resources to where they need to be.

The sheer scale of Dyson Sphere Program is impressive. You are not just stuck on one planet but can travel and harness resources from different planets and star systems. The eventual goal of constructing a Dyson Sphere around a star is a massive undertaking and a testament to the game's ambitious scale.

The game is not without its challenges. The learning curve can be steep, particularly for those new to the genre. But the community is supportive and there are numerous guides and resources available to help you get started. Additionally, the developers are actively working on the game, releasing updates, and communicating with the community.

In conclusion, Dyson Sphere Program is an excellent choice for fans of automation and resource management games. It combines a grand sense of scale with intricate and rewarding gameplay mechanics. Despite its complexity, or perhaps because of it, Dyson Sphere Program is a game that can offer hundreds of hours of enjoyment. I highly recommend it to any fan of the genre.

This game is awesome. If you like Satisfactory and Factorio, I think you'll like this game. In this game, you can travel to other planets for different resources you may not have on your current planet. You can send resources (later on) automatically to the other planets in your system to automate the production of some resources. If you want an extra challenge, you can turn on limited resources and set the resource amount lower. 
While initially it may feel like you don't know what you're doing, it is so satisfying when you have finally automated the production of one vital resource and can then turn to automate another. The only downside to this game that I have noticed is the logistical nightmare that can form if you don't properly plan things out. All in all, this is a fantastic game, and I love every second of it.

I’ve always felt optimization games were missing a goal. so when I saw this on a friend’s game list I knew I had to try it. 

It’s an early access game so for those you usually have to take the good with the bad, but honestly even with a few complaints it’s more polished than many released games at the moment. It feels like playing a classic game of planetary annihilation without the pressure of competing with an AI that can put optimize and out micromanage you. Instead the focus is on building an engine of pure consumption. Everything can be broken down, everything will be used as some production input. Flying across the world and seeing my massive field of oil refineries churning out graphene and deuterium sparks joy. I can’t wait to actually start shooting shit into space, and mining clathrates from gas giants as I have just completed my second trip back from my first interplanetary colony. 

There are a number of things I would like to see improved before release. There needs to be much more information exposure. The tutorial videos included are borderline useless and linking tooltips a la paradox games and an in-game reference would go miles towards opening up the information space. This is probably the most important change that I’d like to see.

On a related note, what bothers me most about the game is the absolutely terrible English localization. A lot of games by foreign developers have a few mistakes here and there but in this game I genuinely have a problem understanding the tutorial write ups and voice overs. It harms my ability to grasp the systems I’m trying to build. I would love to see a significant improvement in this, because I need to know if my factories may pre-house the seamy side volitation. 

Aside from these few frustrations I would highly recommend this game to people who are interested in futurism and mega-engineering, people who loved Total Annihilation and its spiritual successors, people who want to feel like they are colonizing the galaxy, and people who like to relax by optimizing production lines. I really feel like if we managed to combine this game with Elite Dangerous, I probably wouldn’t play anything else.

When you start it seems like a mini factorio in 3d but with limited options, however the game is much more than that, it just takes playtime/work to unlock the games true potential....

First somes negatives....

Bare with the game... in my first 2 days I was thinking it was getting boring fast/research was unlocking tons of stuff that I had zero use for and I was just expanding a basic base with "blue" research aka green research in factorio, then red research 2nd and waiting. All these useless tech do become useful later.

Then I found the oil problem, found an oil seep many hours into the game, and had too little hydrogen/way too much refined oil and no idea how to get rid of it, assumed it was a balance issue but it's not... you will discover later on that this issue resolves and almost swaps around by purple research stage.

Then the last negative ... a lot of the items require silicon ... or later on titanium and I can only get those from manually mining rocks or a painfully slow rock to silicon smelter on the start planet.

Now the major positive.... you can leave the start planet and settle elsewhere.
If you bare with the game, later on you unlock the ability to fly to other planets, and build entire bases on them.. my first was a rock planet abundant in silicon, the second abundant in titanium. So I could manually fly back/forth and collect all the resources I need to make what I needed. This does start to get tiresome flying back/forth, if only there were a better way...

Later on... the game opens up a logistic trade transport system that allows shuttles to do this job for you, and you turn your secondary planets into mini factories for the hard to obtain resources on the home planet.

Then there's the dyson sphere, and inter galaxy exploration, and more... what you see in the first few hours is just a taster of what is to come, this game is already a masterpiece and it's still pre-release. I'd definitely recommend it and would love to see where it's going in the future - I bought factorio as a beta and it has grown constantly since then, can see this doing the same.

Update: I'm now over 350 hours into this game, which sounds like a lot, but honestly there are times I just leave it running for a couple hours while I go do other things and let it just run through a bunch of queued up research or something. This game is, by far, my favorite of the genre. Placing buildings in a nice grid is easy, flying around between planets and solar systems is fun, everything tells you how quickly it can make or transport something, so it's very easy to just do some number crunching and get everything working perfectly. When I play other, similar games I find myself comparing it to this one and before long I want to come back and start a new game. I do find that this is the type of game you can sink a lot of time into and then once you get everything to a certain point you're basically done and might take a long break to play other games, but I have a feeling at least every few months I'll come back for more.

Previous review follows:

I've now played this game for over 150 hours, so I guess I like it, lol. The game has evolved quite a bit since I first got it, and things that I initially found frustrating have since been resolved, and I also better understand how the game works.

If you haven't played a factory game before, they are not fast-paced, high action games. Sometimes I will actually just walk away with the game running so it can build up a backlog of stuff I need, or do a bunch of research I have queued up, while I go do yard work or grocery shopping or something. Other times I sit there and admire what I've built, or break down a whole section of my factory and try to rebuild it in a more efficient way. The buildings tell you their production rate, so you're able to figure out exactly how many of each building you need to keep everything running smoothly.

I've stopped and restarted playing this game several times since I first got it, and there is a newer feature, I think they are called logistics bots (they look like flying fidget spinners) that has completely changed the game for me. No more mess of conveyor belts all over the place. Now with these short-range drones that fly things around (in addition to planet-wide and interstellar) I can make little hubs that just focus on one thing and serve that thing up to wherever it's needed. I used to resort to manually crafting a lot because I didn't want to deal with trying to work something new into the mess of my factory, but now I just pop down some storage containers, tell them what I need, and make a little hub for crafting just that one item. It's great.

As of this writing, the game is still in Early Access, but it doesn't feel like it. There used to be areas of the research tree that weren't available, but I think it's all available now (or, at least, everything currently in it is now available). The game has never crashed on me, and I can't think of a single bug that I've encountered.
Awesome game!

DSP is a really good game, where it does most things right, with only very minor setbacks. I'm a bit of a noob when it comes to automation games, I played some satisfactory and factorio, but both only for 5 hours or so, so consider this review about the game from a noob standpoint considering these types of games:

- What is DSP? It's comparable to factorio or satisfactory, but with its own unique aesthetic. If that doesn't mean anything to you: This is an automation game, where the goal is to build a factory (efficiently) with the eventual goal of building a Dyson Sphere (duh); a mechanical structure around a star which can harvest its energy. 

Pro's:
- The game is small in size (about 3gb) and was made in the Unity engine, which makes you impressed by what people can do in an engine like that (plus this game was only made by 5 people. Like, what the actual f***. Wow.) 
- It's a beautiful game. The soundtrack fits the theme quite well and never gets annoying or overwhelming, and seeing your factory build a sphere is just quite a sight to behold (look up some timelapses of people building dyson spheres on youtube, pure spacegasms). 
- The gameplay is fun. It can be a bit overwhelming at first, but once you get the hang of autmation, the game offers you enough creative freedom to build your factory as you see fit, while providing enough of a challenge to keep you on your toes. It takes quite a chill approach, given there are no enemies (yet), but you're kind of fighting the planet itself for resources, as they eventually run out and you'll have to come up with new solutions to difficult problems as you go. 
- The game can both be enjoyed in chill mode where you just build whatever you feel like, or you can go really hardcore into building the perfect efficient factory. It doesn't force a certain style on you, play as you wish (I like taking this game chill, but hardcore is out there for people who want to, you can set your own goals). 
- Progression feels natural and rewarding, because the quality of life in-game improves along the items you automate. For example, after my first 5 hours I thought it would be perfectly fine to just handcraft storage-boxes without automating them (not too big a deal, right?), until I had some resources left and decided to automate them; and boom I've now created a complete mall where I can easily pick up all other world items from the storage boxes I've created. Point is: I never realized how much I needed to automate them until I did. The game's design is smart like that. 
- The sense of scale is well done. From realizing you have an entire planet, to realizing you have an entire solar system, to realizing you have an entire star cluster to explore is a true inspiration that can let your mind wonder on all the possibilities you have for building. 
- So far the amount of bugs is very minimal. The optimization of the game is very well done. Runs smooth as butter. 

Cons:
- After your factories get bigger and bigger, more cpu memory is required. My first planet is now almost completely covered in buildings, and sometimes I experience frame-rate drops (although it's still stable between 45 and 60 fps, and I'm working with i5).
-  The tutorial/in-game guide is not really helpful. It tells you how mechanics work, but doesn't tell you anything about efficiency. Some youtube tutorials might be required. I threw away my first playthrough after realizing I made a complete mess and had to organize everything on a different scale, after being already 10 hours in. Not necessarily a complaint, as the game doesn't do any hand-holding, but if you're a noob to automation games like me, sometimes you might get stuck and it might be better to complete start over, rather then re-organizing everything. This can be a bummer :p
- The game can get a bit repetitive at the start, when you're automating all your basic materials. It's not too grindy if you automate things, but building your first factories can be a bit tedious. 
- Building a dyson sphere can take quite long (I'm 37 hours in and I'm only halfway through the ability-tree). Prepare to sink time into this game. 

In  other words; much more pros than cons. A cool automation game for both veterans and noobs of the genre, with a beautiful aesthetic, soundtrack, and general fun times. Highly recommend it to anyone who either likes games about space, or crafting games. Definitely worth it's price! 9/10

Revised review.

"Awesome, cocaine like gameplay loop for the first 20 hours, then I realise that I am on a boooring sure track to victory, it was only a question of time." Was my first gripe. It's not so boring anymore, even without the coming alien threat. Although some problems remain...

1) (FIXED)"The game needs challenge, be it enviromental hazards, aliens or something else. Something to keep me on my toes. Even a growing human population to keep hooked up to energy, so that I actually had an earlier incentive to start with the Dyson Sphere Itself." I can now challenge myself with minimal resources and have to think efficiency in everything I do. Well that's how I feel atleast on current playthrough.

2) (FIXED) "I started the game with 0,8x resources, and boy do they seem plenty! So plenty in fact, that I doubt beginning a new game with 0,5x could sort this problem. Starting planet could easily do with 0,2x resources. Make resource rich planets small, add different basic resources so that they could be dispersed on different planets." Minimal resource option seems like a good thing, but we still need more basic resources.

3) "I don't get solar sail lifetime. I suppose this is the only difficulty inducing element in the game, and it is nonsense. And it is not even actually difficulty, it just adds tedium, in that no small factory can accomplish the program. So the game forces to go big, but only for the sake of going big." I guess this is still there, but oh well...

4) Awful English. Although it probably kinda makes sense, I wouldn't understand anything in a real Dyson Sphere Program either.

5) Other solar systems too late in the game: Warp drives are at the very end of tech tree. I didn't actually ever get to interstellar travel, although I dont see I would never had needed to get to another solar system to finish the game, as all the resources are present in starting system.

TLDR:
While still having problems, the game has benefited from many changes and my review goes from negative to hopeful positive.

This game has a lot of features even when it's in early access. It has a modding community which is pretty neat, and even though progressing is hard, it's fine because it will challenge you into thinking much more efficiently in your builds.

The Nebula Mod is when multiplayer happens, it is phenomenal on how far the modding community has come. However, griefers and hackers may be in your game and ruin your experience. But since this game is small, you may expect to find these kind of people less often.

If you need help on this game, many people will help you in the Dyson Sphere Program discord server. Many people from this community will not only help you but share blueprints and give you tips.

Overall, this game is a total success, and I'm looking forward to the combat update and to implement modding and multiplayer straight to vanilla.

It's like factorio but in space, or at least moreso. Building a dyson sphere/swarm is incredibly satisfying and the issues of transporting materials from distant sources is made easy with planetary logistics, so you can essentially just have one planet produce all the materials and outsource them to your main base. Overall i give DSP a 10/10. Also not having to worry about enemies and pollution is nice, although i hear that they're working on a rival to fight soon so that will be fun :)

This sim game is quite different from other sim games IMO. It feels like a combination of factorio and planetary annihilation (without the... planetary annihilation part) where you slowly build up a factory on your starting planet, extracting and converting resources into usable products, and expanding outwards to other planets, obtaining new and rare resources and further expanding into other star systems in your local part of the galaxy. All to create dyson spheres around your stars which power your planet-sized factories to... make more stuff and add to the galactic power generation! Yes, this has some aspects of multiplayer where you are contributing to a global power generation with others who are also creating dyson spheres. There is also a multiplayer mod on Overwolf (a third-party application) which allows you to play in the same session with your friends if you want to play that way. There's also some form of player customisation which is mostly aesthetic but also contributes to your mech's combat power (more on that below) which requires certain resources to ceate, based on what you want to apply to your mech. There are blueprints for different designs which you can create and share with others too.

It's pointless to explain every aspect of this game because you just have to play it to understand and there's a lot to explain. It has a lot of QoL features compared to factorio and other similar games and it has been getting consistent updates since its initial Early Access release on steam. They are also planning on adding combat to the game, which is thankfully opt-in (because I already stress myself out enough with trying to get factories and ratios right, I don't want to worry about killing aliens too!) and your combat ability will likely be directly tied to how you apply different parts to your mech.

There are a few things which contribute to poor performance but those are being ironed out by the dev team and you can even dynamically change some settings like logical calculations vs. graphical calculations to balance things out. Overall, I recommend this sim if you are into factorio or other similar games!

And just today I was still having a blast with it even though I had completed most of the tech tree and upgrades and my most ambitious dyson sphere was well under way around a distant star with a good energy bonus, and then like a light switch I realized I had pretty much seen everything the game has to offer but could either continue to scale up for the sake of scaling up or stop there and I closed the game and will probably never play it again. Its weird how it goes from one extreme to the other so fast, maybe that's just me. Still highly recommend if you like automation games.

Initially, I was blown away.
The intro is well done to show you the scale of the game that's to come, and the added tutorial helps you get started on this amazing journey that's ahead.
It starts so humble, mining things by hand, and it grows to massive scale as you grow into the late game.
While the game can be intimidating at points (looking at oil specifically), it gets really rewarding if you continue playing and optimizing. It's like Factorio on steroids. Where Factorio 'ends' with a rocket, here it's just another step towards building the vast megastructure called a Dyson Sphere.

The translations do show that it's not developed in native English, but you can always discern what the game is trying to tell you, and it gives a cutesy indie game developer charm.

If you like industrial games and endlessly optimizing your factory, Dyson Sphere Program is definitely worth picking up!

UPDATE: Not content with a lack of support for remapping of all controls, the game actively reverts any external changes made by config file edits and mods.  That is, if you do manage to remap the controls, the game will overwrite your edits at the next launch.  This goes beyond not supporting control rebinding and actively works against it.

I'm a programmer and I've worked in software engineering environments.  I get that you have to prioritize what to work on.  I can understand that having most keys rebindable is enough for most people, even if it is very frustrating to those of us who really need the remaining keys to be configurable.  The problem is that this took *extra, deliberate work* to make it harder for us to work around the problem.

Normally I keep an eye on the games for which I've left a negative review and if they fix the issues, then I'll revise/remove the review.  However, this speaks to an attitude on the part of the devs that seems (to me) to be actively hostile towards those who just want to rebind controls.  I'm not sure that fixing the rebindings will be a convincing reason to change this review from negative at this point.

Having said all that, the reason why I'm so irritated about the keybindings being incomplete in this game is that I really want to play it and I've really wanted to play it for a long time.

ORIGINAL: I don't recommend the game at this time because some controls are still hardcoded.  This is a PC game and I want to be able to change how I control it.

I look forward to playing DSP and updating this review once the issue is resolved.

I'm aware that this is early access, but most keys and functions have been remappable for over a year.  It's a combination of a key I want to remap and a function that I want to remap both being hardcoded that I object to here.

I'm aware of AHK, reWASD, and other similar software, but they all have drawbacks that I don't want to deal with.
