This is for Factorio players thinking about picking this one up. Short version: it's Factorio+Space Exploration lite-but-3D. It's definitely not ready for release, but polished enough to be worth your money at this stage.

[b]Some things are better than (unmodded or SE-only) Factorio:[/b]

Actual in-engine 3D space. Planets are spheres and have real orbits. For some buildings, it matters where you build them (on the equator, poles, etc.).
You get to design your Dyson Sphere and it being larger or smaller than a planet's orbit has real consequences. There's a clean and natural progression of walking->flying->interplanetary->interstellar.

Because this is done natively by the game, you also get fully-fleshed out interstellar logistics out of the box.

You start with a personal roboport.

You can copy a building with its "inserter" (sorter) setup on it. This makes it super convenient to build assembly lines.

[b]Some[/b] buildings are stackable. This is a much nicer way of "upgrading" them than crafting them into mk2, mk3, etc. (and looks cool, especially labs). On the other hand, a lot of them aren't. Unstackable assemblers are a missed opportunity, but on the other hand stackable containers are not really needed for anything yet they exist.

The buildings are more varied in shape and have "connection points" that limit where you can place "inserters" (sorters). This is not as artificial or annoying as Big Pharma, but it will provide a little variety in your designs (very little - assemblers are fully connected on all 4 sides).

There's a building that's an [spoiler]entire mining outpost with its built-in roboport[/spoiler]. That makes [spoiler]expanding to new ore patches[/spoiler] a lot quicker and more convenient. [spoiler]You can even have it drain unreasonable power to make it mine faster to get rid of those last few nodes in an ore patch.[/spoiler] Nice.

There's some kind of a New Game+ (metadata) where you can early-unlock some sciences with points gained from your earlier playthroughs. I'm not there yet but I imagine it would help skip some early-game unlocks that would be annoying to get to normally when you've completed the game multiple times already.

No horrible UPS-destroyer fluid and pipe mechanics! Fluids and gases are items that can go into a special high-capacity tank and otherwise belted normally.

[b]Some things are different but I wouldn't consider them better or worse:[/b]

Belts are trivial compared to Factorio. 3D means you can always get from point A to point B by going above/under/between things. Belts do not have near/far sides, and there's a built-in item stacker, making sure you'll never need more than one belt for anything, even at endgame throughput. There's a built-in universal throughput-unlimited balancer item for up to 4 belts that also acts as a loader from/to chests (something the game never told me, only the patch notes! You build a chest on top of a splitter).

The scale you're building things at is much smaller than Factorio. This doesn't take away from enjoyment, but it does make things lean a little more towards casual play. Having [spoiler]6-8 of most[/spoiler] buildings with only a few exceptions will comfortably get you to endgame. The crafting chain you need to win is also simpler than Factorio's (and in a different realm if you compare it against SE, but this is a good thing).

Flying-robot logistics are nerfed compared to Factorio, but at the same time have three different tiers that don't obsolete the others and you'll be using together.

Landfill (foundation) mechanics work like Cities: Skylines for some reason: you need to take away high ground somewhere before you can plug puddles and lakes to build on them.

There's no combat. The devs have stated that this is the #1 item on the roadmap, but I don't feel that the game is somehow incomplete without it. There will be a peaceful mode so all players will be able to pick their preferred game mode.

The blueprint system is worse, but I don't consider this a negative, because due to the smaller scale and trivial belt mechanics you simply don't need them as much. In Factorio, I have multiple blueprint books ready to go, some of them containing even more books. Here, I copypasted [i]some[/i] smelting and assembly lines to widen them a few times. It was definitely worse but not enough to be an annoyance.

[spoiler]"Modules" go on your items and you have to keep making them. This adds a little extra production to counteract what's missing compared to Factorio. Speed and production modules are one and the same (proliferators) and efficiency modules don't exist because why would you ever use them?[/spoiler]

[b]Where DSP is definitely worse:[/b]

Combinators are completely missing, and there are some in-game recipes that really want you to use them. As an example, [spoiler]one of the outputs of oil processing is hydrogen, and there's a secondary process to enrich hydrogen. You can't run it always or you'll have too much, but you have to run it or you won't have enough. You can work around this problem in multiple ways, but all of them are silly and require you to build far more elaborate designs than you would otherwise need[/spoiler]. Even the most basic automation (if there are >X things in that container, stop this belt) would provide enough functionality to solve this properly.
The closest thing you get is a belt throughput measuring device that can alert you but not do anything else. It's useless.

Actually designing your Dyson Sphere is a chore and not explained well. There are premade blueprints on the internet that you can paste in to skip this, but some UI work (let me build a closed polygon in one step and repeat it!) could make this less annoying. There are mods aiming to improve this in particular.

Speaking of the UI, this is one of the most common complaints in other reviews that I can see along with the controls. While it's worse than Factorio's, no contest, it's also not that big of a deal because you need to interact with it way less due to the smaller scale of everything. I only found interfaces related to Dyson spheres to be annoying (including the basic [spoiler]rail ejector[/spoiler], and those are a small part of the entire game despite its title.

Still UI: the tech tree is bad to navigate. Some pieces of tech need another to be researched first that's not visually connected to unlock, and there's no search function to find the thing. Furthermore, there are two tech trees on two separate pages.

The localization is bad. Things are often in broken English or rarely, Chinese. For Early Access, this is OK. The lines are understandable enough, but weird and unnatural. The Chinese fragments are rare and minor, understanding them is not required.

The modding community is a lot weaker than Factorio's. This is not directly the devs' fault, but the game is apparently more difficult to mod than Factorio, which plays a part. Mods are mainly QoL. There are no significant conversion mods like Bob's/Angel's, which is a huge blow to replayability.

The game sometimes decides to randomly quit. This seems to be common enough that it's handled - next time you start you'll get a warning that you might want to load an earlier save in case the latest is corrupt. I'd suggest reducing the autosave interval to at most 5 minutes, and manually saving whenever you finish building or upgrading a block.

This is not a comparison to Factorio, but I'll still complain about it. I had an absolutely beautiful scene of my moon's planet moving in front of its sun, and was eagerly awaiting the ensuing eclipse... that never happened. I got magic sunlight instead. Eclipses are a missed opportunity for free advertising, that would've been a YouTube-worthy "so cool" moment.
Early gameplay loop is super satisfying, 6 hours went by in the blink of an eye and I expect to play a lot more since I haven't even left my first planet yet.  Recommend already.

Here is what I like/Dislike about DSP

Good things I liked about DSP:

Amazing gameplay: The game starts easy and gets harder as you go, so it's good if you like games that challenge you.

Pretty graphics: The game looks really nice with lots of bright colors and cool designs for a game in early access. 

A fun story: The story is about humans exploring space, and it's interesting to see what happens next.

Sandbox mode: You can build and test with different things in sandbox mode without any rules holding you back.

Lots of ways to customize your gameplay: You can make your structures and ships look how you want them to, which is cool, you can also design your own mech which I find cool as well

Some Minor things I dislikes about DSP:

Difficult to learn at first: The game can be confusing at first, so it takes time to get used to.

Lots of micromanagement: You have to keep track of a lot of things in the game, which can be overwhelming.

Can be repetitive: The game is about gathering energy, so it can start to feel the same after a while.

Overall, it offers a unique and satisfying gaming experience. With its sandbox mode and extensive customization options, players can create their own unique gameplay experience and explore the vast expanse of the galaxy.

Alright, lets talk about Dyson Sphere Program for a moment.

When I initially picked up this game, it really didn't hit off for me. I definitely had a preference for Factorio. I came back to it once or twice, with about similar results occurring the next two times. The 4th time however, something about the game just clicked; it became an incredibly complex game of ambition for me.

When you start off, the game feels quite slow and repetitive, very much like early game in Factorio. Eventually however, you get to a point where you're starting to enjoy creating new designs for your factories, starting to utilize blueprints on unprecedented scales. Something about transporting items from planet A to B becomes intensely satisfying, and your endless want to complete a Dyson Sphere starts to become an endless ambition. It starts with one simple Dyson Sphere. But why not utilize all the layers? You then build out all the other layers, despite one layer being more than enough. Then you turn your eyes to other stars. It starts to become an all consuming ambition that extends itself more and more, with your gathering of resources becoming more frantic and your transport networks becoming quite intricate. Where you once built everything on a single planet, single planets start getting dedicated to single resources; entire systems get dedicated as transport hubs, dyson construction sites, or energy collection for your other planets. It becomes a well oiled machine, one that once fueled the construction of a singular Dyson Sphere now extending to build multiple at once.

Welcome to Dyson Sphere Program.

It's incredible. DSP is early access but has a fleshed out progression tree. It could use some more late-game techs. You'll unlock techs super-fast after you automate a new science cube color. Then you'll spend hours using those techs to build a product supply line to manufacture the next science cube color.

It's a beautiful game lending to fantastic screen-shots: gas giant rising over the horizon; solar sails populating an orbit around your sun.

DSP vs. Satisfactory: DSP wins for the better tech tree (at the moment). Both have different scale and both are awesome at showing off how small you are compared to your factories and supply chains. Satisfactory has more beautiful maps (fully hand drawn, but not infinitely variable). DSP has beaten out Factorio as my favorite factory game.

Quick hitter review (I will update it as I get deeper in the game).

So far this looks very solid. It's a blend of Factorio and Satisfactory. Its easy to see the influence of both. The difference here is the scale of it all. Imagine your Factorio factory linked to space shipping lanes to supply and drive a whole universe!! The scale is awesome and a bit scary to be honest.

The graphics look very nice up close though, like Factorio, being zoomed in close is an early game thing. Later you will be looking at planets in the way you used to view a basic mining/smelting setup.

For early access, this has a very polished feel. The English translation is actually pretty good as well. 

I plan to update this review as I delve deeper, but from what I have seen of game play videos and my experience in the game, this is an EASY game to recommend.

UPDATE 4/14/23: Ok, after a couple more hours in (200+ more). Nothing has changed. If you like this type of game, its easy to make it a member of the three must have games: Factorio, Satisfactory, and now Dyson Sphere Program.
Es ist sehr cool!

Dyson Sphere program is an incredible industry simulator. However, do take note that there is no economy in this game. In Dyson Sphere program, it is assumed that the interstellar market is nonexistent and that energy production and resource acquisition are the main objectives of civilization. I personally love this format, as it allows you to focus on industry without the need for negotiation or item valuation. If you are enamored with the idea of a Dyson Sphere (The hypothetical megastructure that captures the solar energy of the sun) or even exponential industrial growth (Which the game does beautifully via blueprints that promote GSRF(Guided self-replicating factory) creation), this is literally the perfect game for you. factorio has character and battle limitations, and Satisfactory has no way of building machines with other machines. I enjoy all three of these games, but this game is undoubtedly the most industry-focused and therefore my favorite. in short: if you liked the industrialization in Factorio and Satisfactory, but didn't like the economy or difficulty, play this one! 
WARNING: take the game off of an external drive if you get to endgame, it will lag a LOT. also, if you have a slow PC it will also lag a lot in endgame. however, for the first ~100 hours you will be fine, even if you make a lot of machines. Even the steam deck can handle the game relatively well.

Maybe the devs want to add a full game experience beside building a dyson sphere (I am talking about the upcoming patch with the dark fog or something like that???) and then fix all the little things?!?

I've really enjoyed it so far, I mean this first run through took me 120 hours of Gameplay plus YouTube videos plus blueprint hunting. 



Some suggestions:
 
There really should be a small amount of blueprints in the game.

The tutorial should also be reworked because there are a lot of blind spots where I didn't know what to do or how or why.

There should also be a consistency on how the belt works with the different buildings. Sometimes you have to connect it directly to the building, sometimes you have to use an inserter, sometimes the belt goes through the building. I'm talking about missile silos or artificial stars or rail ejectors, ray receivers, splitters, automatic piler (should be renamed), tanks, and so on and so forth.

I get it for the construction part e.g. Assembling Machine but for the majority of the other buildings it feels like just stupid (Ray Receiver have an in and output "door" for the belt, this should be on all buildings like rail ejectors, rocket silos, artifical star etc.) Setting up such thing would be much easier if you don't have to use an inserter, an the mentioned building even look like they meant to have an belt input instead of an inserter.

The hole dyson sphere, swarm, mecha look system is terribly overly complex. They need a rework, specially for the mecha look and the dyson sphere editor.

I don't like how the foundations work and that you always have too few or none at all.

Inventory and logistic screen needs a little love as well. Items stored in the logistic row don't count for building which means the game thinks you are out of specific item when building even though you have enough in the logistic row. But that is most likely a bug.
Also, more automation regarding crap and auto sorter inventory.

Upgradeable PLS to ILS. ILS Stations need also some love, that's not perfect for how they work at the moment. I would like to determine where I get the resources from or where they should go. Also include logistic bots, many of them and make them faster.

Tanks or storage should be set to let items disappear in the void, if needed. Looking at you hydrogen :D

Oh and navigation is horrible. I'd like some improvements like locking the north when opening the map (M & V) and navigating, there seem to be a button top right but this doesn't work at all nor does it seems to do anything. You really get lost on your planet, plus the other planets in you starter system. I'm not even talking about the mess with other clusters/star systems. We really need some sort of system to not get lost. A good start would be some (on and off switchable) Signs in Map Mode for everything you like to add a sign to. For example I automate assembling belts and building, let me put a Sign on there so I know where to find stuff when flying around. Also in V Mode, Signs for Clusters or Planets maybe with text for you to find stuff you set up 10h ago...

There are a lot of thing I can't remember right now but there are a lot of cool people with suggestions on the reddit sub.

Dyson Sphere Program is a great addition to the factory-building genre of games. If you enjoyed games like Factorio and Satisfactory, you'll definitely enjoy this game that expands the scale to multiple star systems.

As an Early Access game, it's receiving fairly frequent updates, and the developers seem to be committed to improving and expanding the game. While it doesn't have multiplayer, it's a great singleplayer experience that can provide hours of engaging gameplay.

Overall, I highly recommend Dyson Sphere Program to anyone who enjoys these types of games and is looking for a fun time-sink.

A nice, epic feeling factory builder with the additional "gag" of building across spherical planets and not flat space. 

However, there are two negative points, one of which could likely be solved during EA:
- The game has you looking at spheres (i.e. at least half of your planet is always out of sight) without providing you great organisational tools to manage it. Combine that with lackluster visuals (compare this to factory which put lots of effort in letting you know if you're looking at a smelter or oil refinery or nuclear centrifuge) and you'll have lots manual searching and a general feeling of disconnect to your factory.
- The tech tree is all over the place and unnecessarily detailed. You'll often end up unlocking buildings or products where you'll still need to unlock the raw materials.

tl,dr: Game is good, have been enjoing it for something like 45 hours by now, but it still needs some polish (e.g. this is what Early Access is meant for)

Dyson Sphere Program is an absolutely incredible game that offers a truly unique and immersive experience. From the moment you start playing, you're thrown into a vast and beautiful universe filled with wonder and discovery.

One of the game's standout features is its deep and complex resource management system. Players must harvest resources from planets, asteroids, and stars to build a Dyson Sphere, a massive structure that harnesses the power of a star to provide energy to their civilization. The game's resource management system is both challenging and rewarding, requiring players to carefully balance their resources and make strategic decisions to ensure the survival and growth of their civilization.

The game's graphics are also a major highlight, with beautiful, detailed worlds and stunning space vistas that are truly breathtaking. The attention to detail in the game's art design is impressive, and each planet and star system feels unique and full of surprises.

Another standout feature of Dyson Sphere Program is its deep tech tree, which offers a wide range of upgrades and research options for players to unlock. The game's research system is well-balanced and rewarding, giving players a sense of progression as they unlock new technologies and expand their civilization's capabilities.

The game's automation and logistics systems are also incredibly satisfying to use, allowing players to create complex supply chains and automated factories that run like clockwork. Seeing your factories and logistics systems in action is a sight to behold, and the game's user-friendly interface makes it easy to create and manage these systems.

Overall, Dyson Sphere Program is a truly outstanding game that offers a unique and immersive gameplay experience. Its deep and complex resource management systems, stunning graphics, and well-balanced tech tree make it a must-play for fans of strategy and simulation games. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you and keep you engaged for hours on end, look no further than Dyson Sphere Program.

This is an all-round amazing game, with beautiful visuals, solid performance, and enthralling gameplay loop. You start out with just a single mecha, harvesting resources by yourself, then you make machines, then you make more machines to make more machines, until you've built a giant interstellar industrial empire. I absolutely love how scale works in this game: how you spend the early stages looking up to the stars, knowing that one day you will visit them. I've played through it three full times, and still amazes me.
Very smooth learning curve for how complicated it gets later on.

Factorio but in 3D and with interesting multiple planets concept.
It really changes your perspective when you upgrade your tech and see something what was once inaccessible, becomes within reach and even some time after that, you don't even notice how you struggled for it, while you try to expand your base to reach even further.
I love the scalability of that, where you can manage your factory on every level- starting from choosing your transport belts location, through moving resources across planets, and to hauling everything from all corners of your cluster to build your own sphere.
Technically its also well done and can run on modern potato-end computers.

The only downside is that even after around a year when I was last time playing it (cause then devs updated the EA and my save was broken), there are still THE SAME issues with placing things (ie. these damn conveyor belts and the tricks you have to use to save space).

At first I thought it would just be Factorio in space, but it turned out to be so much more.
Unique and interesting automation and logistics problem solving a-plenty, paired with the satisfaction and surprisingly stunning visuals of seeing your (custom designed) mega-project Dyson spheres come to life just feels real good.
Music is on point. Has some good mods. Runs nice and smooth and no bugs or crashes so far..
Translation is imperfect, but close enough to get the gist, plus the in-game info is enough to figure things out without ever really being lost or confused.

This game is a great resource management time sink. I love it and the devs are responsive and communicate with the community in the discord channel. 

There is a roadmap on development which includes an in game enemy, which will make it much more interesting to protect what you build, as you spread out amongst the stars. There are also a host of mods available, including a multiplayer mod, that is rather well polished.

Great game that is now reaching similar levels of depth as Factorio. Similar game mechanics, but this time you're playing across a galaxy or solar systems with multiple different worlds to work with. Exploration is key with unique and varied resources across different planets.

The devs have kept up with great improvements with each patch; the addition of a detailed blueprinting tool was essential and its addition has really improved the game.

It's still Early Access, but from a gameplay perspective, it's pretty complete from a sandbox perspective. There's a few minor glitches here and there, and the end-game Dyson Sphere construction UI needs to be improved as it is quite confusing at the moment. 

I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes factory builders - if you own Factorio or Satisfactory this is an essential purchase. If you are new to the genre, and prepared for the inevitable addiction, this is a great place to start.

Dyson Sphere Program is a game that exceeded my expectations and took me on an incredible journey across the universe. As a fan of building and factory games, I was amazed to discover that this game allows you to construct on multiple planets without any loading screens. It was a dream come true!

The seamless, real-time transitions between planets create an expansive and virtually limitless map, making it one of the most immersive games I've ever played. Although the primary objective is to build a Dyson Sphere, I was pleasantly surprised to discover that there's much more to the game. With the ability to travel through multiple solar systems, you can create more than one Dyson Sphere, and the scale of this game is truly awe-inspiring.

Moreover, the developer has announced that a combat system is on the way, and players can choose to play with or without enemies, depending on their preference. This adds another exciting dimension to the game, and I can't wait to try it out!

Overall, Dyson Sphere Program is an exceptional game that deserves to be played. Its seamless transitions between planets, multiple solar systems, and upcoming combat system make it an exciting and unique experience for any fan of building games.

If you like factory-building games, Dyson Sphere Program is a must.

I really enjoyed Dyson Sphere Program.  The concept is fun, with a huge scope.  It's really amazing to see how large the construction gets as you go along.  I've not really beat it yet, though I guess there may be different takes on what wins the game.

It's a beautiful game.  It can be slow starting up, but progress becomes steadily more and more rapid.  If you like building games, this will not disappoint.  I in particular like building monuments and large projects in building games, and being able to see your sphere gradually take shape over time can be very entertaining, along with the scale of freedom in what sort of sphere you wish to build.  Only downside is that, since my PC is right at or possibly just below the minimum requirements, I do suffer from lag and other issues.

Thank you for allowing me to join. Before I give you honest review and opinion, which is extremely positive let me start like this. 

I've been been on space games since StarCraft late 90s version. X2 and x3, Eve, star citizen, elite dangerous, no mans sky etc. So I wanted a game based on space where I can just chill and enjoy the visuals. That's when I ran in to Astro colony. Love it to this very moment, but something's was still missing for me. Not taking anything from it, however not being about to go on a full planet had me thinking what if?

So in my related section DSP was there. I bought it and tried it. 

I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS GAME!!!!! TO THE FACT THAT IT'S SOUNDTRACK CAN LIVE IN MY HEAD FOREVER. THE COMPLEXITY OF THE TECH TREE IS SO ENJOYABLE, I SAID ILL PLAY AND FIGURE EVERYTHING OUT AND IT'S A BLAST DOING SO.

Great factory game with space and physics heavy atmosphere.

At first I thought this game is just like a factory. Basically a copy but a different take on a genre defining game. But man, how wrong I was.

The start felt similar. I built my belts, factories and I was the best italian chef on the planet. Research was going well and the new technologies were comming faster than I could process them. Then I reached a point where the game told me : To continue you have to get the resource from another planet because the starting one does not have it.

That took, if I may say, a stellar turn.

Then I had to visit another planet, started to mine ores and bringing them manually back. I looked for a automatic solution because those trips were nice but my inventory capacity was not enough. Then I implemented interplanet transportation. I felt like I am participating in Civilization Beyond Earth intro movie. It felt like a new civilisation was born and now lives amoung starts. It was magnificent.

This went for a while and I saw my power generation went down. Naturally I looked up what exactly is this Dyson Sphere. Oh boy. Oh boy. Oh boy. There goes my holiday.

DSP was my first personal foray into the world of the spaghetti belts. While I haven't played others like Satisfactory or Factorio, I've spent a good bit of time learning the mechanics and watching streams & TY vids.

Pros:

 [b] 1. The Graphics [/b]

SPACE!!!!! ^_^
That said, the thing that has impressed me the most about DSP is how beautiful the graphics are. Sometimes I'll hop on just to fly around and look at the views.

 [b] 2. Tech Tree [/b]

The Tech tree as you progress into the game shows all the progressive unlocks as you work towards your goal of building the dyson sphere and strip mining the galaxy! As someone who loves the feeling of progression and knowing what is required for each step along the way, the tech tree is implemented well!



 [b] 3. Small Dev Team [/b]
The dev team is fairly small and significant updates are few and relatively  far between in early access, yet  the dev team always delivers quality updates that are enjoyable & that are fairly bug free. They also care about their fan-base and they are great about not only communicating about the game, but letting us in on fun little things from their personal lives!

Cons:

[b] 1. No multiplayer [/b]

[b] 2. The tutorial  [/b] 

The tutorial (mostly just tips here and there as you play), while semi helpful feels very incomplete and is a bit of a barrier to players brand new to the genre. Love the assistant's voice though!


 Overall, with the upcoming release this year of combat into DSP, I would 10/10 recommend this game for anyone who loves the genre!

So, picture the scene:  dozens of factories all in motion, stacked conveyor belts going everywhere, resource towers reaching to the clouds, hundreds of drone ships flying low level taking supplies from one resource tower to next, multi-coloured glowing research towers humming, interstellar ships flying off to different star systems to collect rare materials, dozens of rail guns shooting solar sails, 1o or so large rockets launching every 4 seconds heading towards the sun with materials to make the Dyson Sphere, a sphere which you can see in the back ground consuming most of the sky. Yea this is an awesome game. 

Prepare for a chaotic mess, no matter how methodical your intentions are. Prepare for some bemusement with the broken English which to be honest was part of the charm…what the F$% am I supposed to do with a miniature particle collider? Hats off, one of the best games I have played this year and a nice and relaxing one after Elden Ring. Nothing in this game is trying to kill you apart from time itself.
The game is everything you've ever wanted. The learning curve is low, and the automation a dream. Super peaceful and less numbers than factorio, but still some.

Great game. Turn off music immediately for better enjoyment (I recommend SomaFM ambient radios instead).

After all these hours playing it, my one biggest wish is that I'd have some kind of waypoint system or location markers to easily navigate back to where I was building.
While I'm planning out something more complex, I then often have to divert from whatever I'm doing to sort some other logistics issue, and especially in the late game when my planet is covered in industry, it can get a bit tedious trying to find back to what I was doing, and I spend far too much time just flying around searching.

Of course it helps being organized too, but if I could set custom waypoints, and hit a button to bring them up quick, that would be perfect, while also avoiding cluttering up the view.

You start as a machine. You mine resources, use this resources to make machines to mine resources. make machines to refine resources. Make machines to use refined resources to make other resources. Make machines, that make machines that can make other machines. Automate everything, and eventually Dominate the local solar systems star and make it power all your machines. Then expand to other solar systems and automate the galaxy.

Wonderful automation game. Pace feels just right, depth of features feels just right. I love that they've provided the option to have large, relatively expensive logistics systems for when you just cant figure out the compact way of doing something :D.

Played from beginning to current endgame in one run, really enjoyed going back to my early automations to see what a fool I was!

Highly recommended, will be replaying all the way through when the next big update comes out.

My only minor complaint is that the lack of steam saves make it impossible to play on cloud gaming services like Geforce Now, my machine is aging and starts lagging when bots really start flying around. Would be great to offload to Geforce and turn up the graphics settings!

All in all a great game. If you're looking for resource management, and building factories to automate production while taking over planets, this does it very well.

The first 15 or so hours are pretty slow, and it does take a hefty amount of time getting used to everything (unless you've played Factorio/Satisfactory, etc), however I think personally it's worth investing into. 

Get the game if you have time on your hand, and if you've been itching to build-- especially if you have a fascination for "space wonder buildings" like the dyson sphere. Seeing yours come to fruition will be worth all of the effort alone.
It makes you feel smart and better than others (:
I have really enjoyed the 7 hours I have spent with the game so far, most of that was just digging into the mechanics. I am waiting for a full 1.0 release to fully explore the game.
This is one of those early access games where it's fun to pop in and build for a weekend, then take a break for 6 months or so while they add some more.
If you like Factorio but thought that dealing with enemies was kinda annoying and wanted prettier graphics, this game will bring lots of enjoyment for you.

I have played a bunch of "factory" building games, Factorio and Satisfactory to name a couple that I have completed the last stages on them.  However Dyson Sphere program to me is another level, while I haven't played since the addition of the "enemy" I have to say this game is amazing, great detail and it can be relaxing, exciting and frustrating all in a 5 minute span.

Fly your Icorus in the solar system, and do a low level fly by of the sun only to realize you don't have enough power to get away from it and now you are stuck so you have to load a save.  Such beauty in the game I love it.

Where is it lacking, creatures on the planets, there are none, although this is a HUGE ask but even some minor ones signs of life.  Also your destruction...at the time of my last play through you couldn't die, this needs to change, you can't go stand on the SUN or fly to a black hole and not die, even if it causes a "Game over" screen and you have to reload your last save that would be great.

Anyway, I am preparing for new play through to see the "Fog" I can't wait.

If you enjoy Factorio and Satisfactory, you'll more than likely be into DSP. I had no idea what to expect upon purchasing but it turned out to be amazing. The logistics are complex with many tiers of upgrades. You have the freedom to setup your resource gathering, production, power generation, etc. as you see fit.

I've only had to reference the on-line wiki once, to figure out how to setup one of the systems that allows you to produce more items or produce them faster. Other than that the in-game tutorial and guide has provided all the into I've needed.

26 hours in and I have about 3/4 of the technologies unlocked, with three more research tiers to go. It keeps getting progressively difficult to unlock the higher tiers which adds to the challenge. Which is fine because there are currently no enemies, CPU players, etc. to deal with. Just build and go at your own pace.

I get overwhelmed with factory games.  I wanted to like this game but I dropped it at least 4 times.

I don't know what changed, but one day I was like "I feel like trying Dyson again.  But this time, I'm not going to be OCD, I'm just gonna go with the flow."

Best thing I ever did, this game is so incredible for me now.  You build so many factories that you just learn naturally what works best, making the OCD problem at the start completely pointless.  It's such a satisfying feeling to see your factories span larger and larger across the planet, multiple planets and ultimately the stars.  It's like an engineering problem solving dream come true + I LOVE space

Don't be deceived by the "Early Access" title, this game is deeper and more polished than many fully completed games

The gameplay is much better visually than factorio. Space travel is awesome. The visuals are great. It keeps you busy until late game. Once you've reached the point where you are constructing the Dyson Sphere, the only thing it has going for it is watching the Dyson sphere being constructed. Expanding beyond this point is repetition (I usually just start another game). Multiplayer is possible with mods. It works fairly well till late game at which point some players are seeing things that don't sync with other players.
     Biggest problem. Mid to late game fps is terrible. You'll notice with an overlay that fps is at 20ish but your cpu and gpu are not being utilized above 50%. Well that's the case with my 7950 and 4090. The game desperately needs optimized. I cannot overstate this. The framerate is the biggest cause to start a new game or just play something else.
     More content is needed late game. The fact multiplayer is not built in is almost a deal breaker. The game has a lot going for it otherwise.

I first thought that I'm not a fan of the factory building genre, but I was wrong. This game is that good. It's beautiful, relaxing, full of content and possibilities for optimization. The ability to move goods (and yourself) between planets and even stars is awe-inspiring to me. I wish I'd just had this much amount of time to occupy this huge amount of space.

So, Factorio dumped me. It's fine, though. I'm playing Dyson Sphere Project now. I miss Factorio sometimes, but I guess it's time to move on.

Dyson Sphere Project is okay. It's not as complex or exciting as Factorio, but it's pretty and has some cool space stuff going on. It's a laid-back experience, I guess.

Honestly, I think the reason Factorio dumped me was because I couldn't perform... when it came to designing circuit networks. I kept getting tripped up on builds, and I think it frustrated the game. It's hard, you know? 

Circuit networks are a whole other level of complexity. But I'll keep practicing, and maybe one day I'll be able to win Factorio back.

I don't recommend Dyson Sphere Project to anyone looking for a satisfying gaming experience. While it's often compared to Factorio, a gold standard in the factory line game genre, Dyson Sphere Project fails to meet even the basic expectations of a good game.

One of the biggest issues with Dyson Sphere Project is the lack of long-term objectives. Unlike Factorio, where the end goal is clear and drives the gameplay, Dyson Sphere Project leaves players without a clear sense of purpose beyond building and researching for the sake of it. Even if the goal is to provide power to your planet, you can do so with burning wood from trees. Without any explorative end goals, scores to meet, or places to go, there's no real point to the whole game.

Additionally, the lack of challenges to overcome makes Dyson Sphere Project a one-sided and ultimately boring game. In any good game, players need to face obstacles and overcome them through gameplay. However, in Dyson Sphere Project, there are no real challenges to overcome, making the gameplay feel pointless.

Overall, I don't recommend Dyson Sphere Project to anyone looking for an engaging and satisfying gaming experience. While it may look and sound like a good factory line game, the lack of purpose and challenges ultimately make it a disappointing experience. Save your time and money and look for a better game.

If you're into factory building games and 2D building doesn't bother you: Look no further! 

This game has scalability, optimization and user created content like no other game I've seen. 

The game starts out small enough for you to handle. If you're like me, the science runs in the background during workdays when I can only concentrate on the game max 10% of the time, you don't even have to expand beyond a single (top-offed) matrix until the late game when it's exactly the kind of challenge you would like. 

This is clearly a work of passion: It feels like a finished game already and they're still in early access adding more significant content. I gotta admit I despise early access as an idea but these kinds of games (Satisfactory included) raise my optimism toward the concept. I'm happy to give the developer my money to support their goals. 

There are a few minor translation problems (f. ex. at the moment hovering over Life Distribution of Solar Sails in Dyson Sphere view shows Chinese letters but I've managed to survive without the translation. I'm sure an optimization engineer could tell you what it means since they're trying to draw every last drop of any resources you have but I'm an infinite resources pleb and just shrug at the lost information. Ah, and if you don't like figuring everything out by the badly translated tutorial, there are a lot of helpful tutorial videos on the internet. 

Some weird button combinations exist where delete does a certain thing when it doesn't any other time and right click is *very* flexible on when it does what depending what interface you have open. It takes some getting used to but in the end you never manage to do anything irreversible by accident. 

This positive review was brought to you by getting to put the third input into a weirdly placed advanced mining machine after building the two other ones. It wasn't possible before but the devs managed to make it possible anyway. Thank you for that! You seem to know what you're doing. My humblest thanks and more, please!

I love this game, as you can tell by my 600+ hours playing it, but there are some things I'd like to see changed:

Pros:

Beautiful scenery

great randomization of planets and stars

Great replay-ability with the new research carryover 

Cons:

the tutorial is pretty much junk

uses for items need a better breakdown, especially for rare items. The only way to tell what they are used for is the wiki or going through every other material to see what they are used for. I should be able to mouse over each rare item and see exactly what I can use it for

the mini drones for transporting goods to you should be able to be added to all the logistics towers so you don't have to attach storage units and dispensers.

The items enhancement sprayers should be trackless to use personal drones and have built-in storage

The upgraded optical miner should be reduced from requiring green research cubes to purple. By that point, I have enough miners out that they almost feel redundant. You should also be able to use the old miners to upgrade to the optical otherwise you are stuck holding onto a ton of them and it feels like a waste of resources.
It's unforgivable that cloud saves weren't one of the very first things implemented with this game...all that progress lost...

This is a purchase you cannot regret, especially given the price tag.

This game brings a sense of achievement very few others does, you'll feel it when you'll be spending time watching the beauty of it all. You'll spend more time here than on most triple A games, no doubt.

This game had me saying, "someone call a physician because this shit is sick" about every 10 minutes.

Dyson Sphere Program is IMMENSE. The scale is not encumbering but also not unrealistically small. You can truly feel the size of these celestial objects and the unimaginable distances between them. Despite all of this, DSP is likely the most detailed game I have ever played. Literally, everything is shown. I mean EVERYTHING. When launching shuttles and solar sails to stars to build Dyson spheres, you can see them being launched out into space (whether or not you are on the planet) and watch them take their positions around the star.

It was an incredible experience. The tech tree is actually important and makes you feel as though you are pursuing a grand purpose. It took me more than 2 hours to get fully sucked in so try to outlast your refund tendencies. But seriously, if you love these engineering games, you'd be doing yourself a major disservice to not pick this one up.

I had this in my account for a while, I dropped it shortly after playing the first time for some reason but i'm glad I came back, getting to an interplanetary stage is a bit of a hurdle but after that the game really gets going. I have a particular fondness for games with planets you can walk all the way around on so I might be biased in that regard, nevertheless, the amount of detail in this game is amazing, you can design your sphere piece by piece and watch it be built bit by bit, really feels immense. building your factory and looking up to see your Dyson Sphere looming overhead, a testament to your tenacity, is very rewarding. I am a bit worried for the combat system that is soon to be released, I don't want my sphere to be damaged =3=.
Somewhere between Satisfactory and Factorio. Relaxing with plenty of quality of life features

Strongly, strongly recommend this game. The progression is amazing, the way the game makes you scale everything is so well made and even tho there is an actual limit to the resources you could use to scale, it is basically unreachable. I played this games a few times, completed it fully twice including having 6-7 full dyson shpere in one of the playthru. They even included the "metadata" thingy which allow you to bank stuff for a next playthru to skip some of the steps. This even gives you a reason to over-scale even after having completed the game.

One "cons" I would say is that the "Mission complete" stage is way, way to easy to achieve even on the first attempt. It should ask you for something like a million white cube so you would hit a massive wall and you have to re-think.

I strongly recommend to play at 1x resource and not fall for the "infinite" trap as this makes the game actually less enjoyable. Having the resource deplete quickly forces you to be more efficient in scaling up, finding better ressource and explore more planets / system. Once you got a few blue print, you can industrialise an entire planet within minute (and it IS enjoyable).

And the feeling of seeing your first Dyson Sphere being built in real time right around the sun is out of this world. I have a beefy PC and I was actually surprised it could handle everything that was happening when I started the launch sequence for the dyson sphere to be built.

This game is a lot of game for your money.

Strongly recommend, I would place this in my top 2 games of the genre, right above Satisfactory, letting factorio far far behind.

Un jeu d'automatisation intéressant. 
L'interface est très bien pensée et permet de construire efficacement de larges systèmes. 
La progression technologique  et les améliorations de notre mech sont assez rythmées et diverses et nous amènent d'une phase de minage manuel au sol à la fin de partie où des vaisseaux de ravitaillement automatisés sillonnent la galaxie, de système solaire en système solaire pour alimenter la construction de notre sphère de Dyson et notre mech vole de planète en planète, supervisant la construction d'immenses plans depuis le ciel ou l'espace.

Les surfaces de construction sont des sphères et bien qu'il soit possible de construire sur une grille classique tant qu'on ne s'éloigne pas trop de l'équateur, les pôles sont une tout autre histoire et donne l'occasion de construire des motifs circulaires bien différents des classiques vu dans la plupart des jeux de cette catégorie.

Espérons que le futur système de combat (optionnel) ajoute encore à l'intérêt de ce jeu.

If you like builder style games and you like space, kiss your social life goodbye because you can sink TONS of hours into this game (check mine). 

The premise is fairly simple: start from nothing and use raw materials to start building more and more until you're zipping through the cosmos at warp speed to traverse the crazy distances (light years!). Find rare resources to ease production line requirements or be very neat and tidy because you'll need plenty, PLENTY of resources to build your final dyson sphere around the star to collect ridiculous amounts of energy. The addition of the Milky Way lets you compare your output to other players and is nice touch. 

Supposedly, enemies are coming soon but you'll be given the option to play peacefully with no interaction (this is how it is currently at the time of writing in early Feb 2023) or with enemies that will be building themselves up for an eventual showdown with you. 

All in all, great game and if you can get it on sale and love this type of game, you shouldn't think twice - just get it!

here are some late game tips:
1.have a hare time finding a tied locked planet to farm critical photon? build a sphere that covered the inner planet,the whole surface of that planet can produce it
2.every planetary logistics station produce 1 product, get interstellar logistics station in a line ,link them with warper,to do  interstellar transit.
3.every giant planet can put up to 40 orbital collectors 
4.deuterium is much need in late game,make a blue print of fractionator is needed,make sure the line of hydrogen goes back to the same  planetary logistics station.
5 proliferator is excellent every CPU,turbine,plane filter, quantum chip,matrix,rocket,anti matter fuel rod,particle broadband production ine need it as well as your power supply
6.automatic piler straating at end of the productiong line, put the first one in 30/s ,then put another one every 15/s
7.silicon ore is much needed double or triple the production rate.
8.try to build a production line for every building ,especially belt,sorter mk2 ,assembling mechine mk3 smelter,lab,tesla tower.
9 you will need multiple  interstellar logistics station for some raw materials such as silicon ore,hydrogen,spiniform stalagmite crystal, carbon nanotube,deuterium,
10 make sure  every  logistics station charges at full speed,DO NOT put the material mentioned in tip 9  in one  interstellar logistics station,otherwise the vessels are too busy to transfer every materials you need
游戏后期小tips：
1：还在为好不容易找一个潮汐锁定的星球铺满射线接收器结果产出的临界光子还不够用发愁？其实只要你的戴森球够大，把本星系里最里面的那颗行星包裹进去，那这个行星所有表面都能24小时产出临界光子
2：搭配利用好行星内和星际物流站，建议是找一个纬度铺满一整排星系物流，所有星系物流站之间可以直连跃迁，上下空间放人造恒星，然后每个行星内物流站负责1种产物产出，模块化搭建
3：每个气态行星最多能摆40个采集站
4：重氢到后期即使你把所有气态行星都插满还是不够用的，保存一个上百个分馏器的重氢分馏产出线比粒子对撞省电，但务必要设置回流到出发点+备几幢液体储存罐不然会堵
5：增产器神器，CPU，绿马达，黄马达，白糖，运载火箭，位面滤过器必用 
6：自动堆叠机第一个放在产出刚好满30个每秒的地方，后续的要放15个每秒的地方，电路，电磁铁，金伯利矿，干冰必备
7：硅石缺口较大，建议大型矿机开倍速
8：给每个建筑做一个生产线，如果暂时资源不够，优先熔炉工厂。
9：当一个星球工厂覆盖率高时，有些资源只靠一个星际物流站是来不及运输的，典型石笋，单磁，重氢，各种矿石
10：限制星际物流站运力的一个电力一个飞船数，电力能拉满都拉满，然后5个选项里要注意合理搭配，一般是建筑配高消耗性材料。低消耗材料放一起。不然会有的忙死永远0/10，隔壁那个却空闲天天10/10

The game is a very enjoyable factory game.  With huge FPS problems.

The development team has their priorities incredibly misaligned with the needs of  the game.  The developers have stated their number one priority for 2023 is to add combat to the game.

I reached a point where I wanted to build my first Dyson Sphere in a cluster I was excited to use as a location for several spheres.  Even in planning mode, a single-layer moderately-sized sphere killed the FPS on my machine (the game went from 60 FPS to 14 FPS).  I had not created one element of the sphere, I had simply created the plan for it in planning mode.  My video card is an RTX 2080 Ti.

The Performance Test view showed the "Draw Call" method had gone from a 1 ms call to a 12+ ms call, simply by planning the sphere around one star, without even building one element of the sphere, no sails, no nodes, no structure.  Clearly, the existing tools show the developers where to focus their attention to fix this problem.

For the gamer, the only way to make the FPS return to a playable state is either delete the plan for the sphere, or turn off the display of the sphere entirely (after creating the layer plan, you need to disable both Display settings, removing the checks in the tick boxes, in editor, and in game).

Many players have complained about the FPS-killing nature of the spheres, so it wasn't hard to find an article mentioning turning off the display of the spheres.  I think it is preposterous that the development team for a game called Dyson Sphere Program would prioritize combat over fixing the game breaking logic problems related to the eponymous game feature.

I've enjoyed playing the game,  It is a real shame a reasonable video card cannot display a sphere, and one must completely turn off the display of the primary end game feature  to make the game continue to run.

The guids are strange. There are guides for all the easy stuff, but when you get to the complex topics there is no help to be found. 

The end game was pretty disappointing. It feels like there is missing a mining / foundation automation function. You basically just fly around placing interplanetary logistic stations and miners. It's actually pretty boring at this point. 

Maybe I just played it wrong 🤷

Still a great game, but yeah. The end game could use some more work. 

Spoiler: It's also really strange that the game "completes" when you have produced and researched 4000 of the white cubes. You can do this without even starting on building your Dyson Sphere. I think they should change this or maybe make another "research tree tab" where you track progress on a complete sphere, whith sub-goals etc. That would make the end game much more enjoyable, for me at least.

Edit: After giving the game some more thought, I feel like I lacks purpose. In the beginning you are told humanity lacks energy. But you never end up providing it. You just use it to harvest more resources and devouring more planets. All energy is invested in creating antimatter to further the research, allowing you to be more efficient. But there doesn't seem to be a purpose to any of it. Like "Congratulations, you a now generating 30GW of energy on this empty cold planet of solitude in a starststem far from any lifeform." Why would I ever wanna do that? I've actually changed my mind about the game! Its gameplay is great, and it's fun to strategize, but it completely lacks purpose.

I had this wish listed for a while. It took boredom and $20 out of my pocket to cannon ball into another random game, take a risk with early access, and hope I got something decent here. In short - if you like Factorio, you'll like Dyson Sphere program. Very similar in nature, but differences slice the land when it comes to the experience. U N F O  R T U N A T E L Y, Dyson Sphere Program (at the moment) does not have multiplayer, which made Factorio a unique city-building type experience you could share with a friend. Does the game hold-up without that? For the moment (being gracious of the current game state)... yes. Keep in mind... early access review, review will be updated with time.

The [b]gameplay[/b] intermediately differs from Factorio as we move off a 2D reality and roll into a 3D world... literally. Factiorio had a top-down approach whereas Dyson Sphere Program (DSP) works within a model requiring 3-axis (how'd you pronounce that last word... axeees, or ax-sis :). I'll be honest, the ability to run between planets is enticing and the ability to fly gives DSP the new feel that the player isn't replaying Factorio. Being able to stack buildings with familiar settings doesn't make the game feel completely alien, but starting fresh is always a challenge. Strategies change as conveyor belts are narrower (1 item at a time) and the strategies start changing when conveyors can also be built vertically. That's just the start; when the player starts thinking about going to other planets, there is a decent amount of planning that can go into a move like that. Fuel is the first concern, gaining resources by building the base at home is another. I should point out the liquid system isn't quite in effect yet and the devs seem to be using the conveyors as a solution method for the moment... which is kind of nice because it simplifies things. Maybe keep it as an "new map" option feature/edit? 

Hours in, I really like the concept of linking planets together. This is Factorio on a bigger scale, and a lot friendlier. The ability to fly, right click to move, and drones to reach nearby construction make the game a little more fluid than its predecessor. Factorio had more of a grind where I feel this is a little more easy with its approach. I feel like repetitive (or annoying) motions that the player has to constantly go through has been avoided through the use of blue prints and other little neat features. Exploring space is quite the trait this game offers. Gas giants, Dyson Spheres, travelling to different planets, systems... it's pretty cool. I hope as the game progresses that useful features will continue to be added (and not just new stuff to have new stuff - gameplay/interaction is always nice)! I wish there was a feature where civilian sustainability could be introduced, would add an extra layer of balance. I like the little additions such as being able to customise armour and animations when the player is idle, shows the little detailed touch.

I feel DSP continues with its user friendliness in all aspects. Besides one little early access glitch (not displaying the proper item for fuel - mini fusion reactor for power), everything is explained well enough that the player can understand what they need to assemble an item. Maybe because this game is focused more with ships, it seems a lot easier to transport items within arms reach. Additionally, players can use drones to restock their items instead of manually restocking. This might seem like a tiny detail, but goes a long way when it comes to saving time. I really wish I used this feature a lot earlier in the game instead of travelling star to star to get what I need. The other massive detail is the current galaxy the player is in; zoom out and an entire giant new cluster of stars (literally everywhere) appears. It's crazy to think the player can literally go and travel to anywhere - and get lost if they don't label systems properly! This game is an automator's dream; everything can be automated! Storing buildings, supplies, ships, fuel, and all sorts of other things can be done almost automatically (and a lot easier with a set of blueprints to rinse and repeat build styles). 

The [b]graphics and visuals[/b] are pretty good and suitable for the game's atmosphere. It's sort of cartoon-ey, but not to the point where it is annoyingly cartoon-ey. Planets have a different feel (hope more atmospheres and environments to come!), the topography is noticeable from certain camera angles, the user interface is nice on the eyes, and the space environment is pretty cool. The only issue with the space visuals is that it can get a little empty flying between planets. I do realise that last statement may be a little contradicting as space is empty, but since this is a game why not pretty it up? The user interface is also awesome and very straight forward. I really liked the variety of camera and map viewing abilities to get a better view on things. There is an option to increase the size of the UI. The [b]sounds and music[/b] are at best okay. I wish games would take more of a risk and try to make it sound like some of those buildings may have people working or making noise in them (think Warcraft 2 / Knights and Merchants). This game has the potential to add a little grit and play with the players emotion. You're kind of a robot mech thing all by yourself, alone in a system about to get some huge industry going... that's a big deal! Make it sound like a big deal! 

Overall, the game is pretty good but certainly needs to continue growing. I think the multiplayer option should be high up on that to-do list in conjunction with adding more to the game. I think there are enough resources to keep the player happy, I also think adding some challenge or variables to the game can really take it to the next level. I think being able to "stamp" or label certain areas of a planet would also be a neat feature (and maybe somehow more hover pop-up menus to indicate the production/power/etc... of the planet). Another neat addition I think would be to introduce civilian life. Production to maintain civilian life and perhaps down the line adding policies that can dictate planets. Grow food, terraform,  perhaps with mods defend? But hey - that's my opinion to the Devs! I would recommend a purchase on sale if you're really curious, I would also recommend waiting to see what the final product looks like. I am willing to give this game a bump up to a 8.5 if multiplayer gets included!

We all know the feeling of games that can accelerate time. You get deep into the game and the next thing you know, 5 hours have gone by and your wife/boyfriend/dog/hamster is pissed because you've been in another universe for too long and didn't take care of things you were supposed to finish.

This game is like that but at least an order of magnitude stronger. Time feels like it just blurs by while playing. It's just plain surreal how fast time goes by while you're balancing out your titanium crystal production or refactoring that ghetto hydrogen factory with new recipes that you picked up.

And then you fly to another planet to bring back a bunch of titanium ingots... and make an interplanetary logistics station to bring them back for you... and, yeah. Good game.

A production line game where you start on a single planet and eventually expand to nearby solar systems. The game eschews a lot of the conveyor belt gore typical to the genre in favor of drones and ships that can move items to almost anywhere else, and the challenge exists in determining and producing whatever finite resources you need more of to keep your production lines running at full efficiency. Even in early access it has a smooth difficulty curve and an explicit end goal, though expect to see some odd balance issues with resource availability (e.g. in earlier builds, hydrogen generated from oil refining had such limited usage that dedicated power plant factories were, and likely still are, recommended to burn the excess).

Initial thoughts: Love the Game, have over a 1000hrs in it. If you love building a factory with beautiful visuals and amazing game mechanics. This is one you don't want to miss out.

Final thoughts:
The game desperately needs some optimizing because I'm only getting 20-50FPS even with my new computer. I built my new computer so I could play this game. Please optimize this game

Only 3 hours in and I am absolutely blown away by the degree of content and level of detail with each upgrade. I am a die-hard fan of automation-based gameplay. There is something absolutely fascinating about designing a factory system from a simple idea and developing a complex logic system from that. I have played others like Satisfactory, Factorio, Little Big Workshop, Factory Town, etc., but the Dyson Sphere Program is one that stands out on it's own among the rest. So far I'm sold on the basic fact that there are detailed analytics of almost everything you do. Being able to copy your industry layouts as blueprints is incredibly useful for later-game progression as well. I'll update this once I've sunk more hours in.

This game honestly had so much potential but was entirely ruined for me.

The fact that everything is so incredibly finite makes what could have been a relaxing experience a constant fear of your factories shutting down because you cant find the resources anymore. Maybe it is possible to add a feature that makes resources infinite? And no not sandbox mode, I just want the regular experience but my resources dont run out. To make it more balanced maybe make the nodes smaller so they give less output.

Another thing I absolutely HATED was the fact that the mining speed of a miner is dependent on how many nodes its attached to. In principle this isnt such a bad idea but in practice it works out a lot different. If you wish to calculate exact amounts of usage and production (which in my opinion is a big part of the enjoyment in games like satisfactory or factorio) you have to keep in mind that the resource node gives much less output then what you may think. If your miner gives 180 p/m base your factory around 90 p/m because as soon as one node runs out the miner starts mining slower. This broke all of my factories while playing and it frustrated me a lot. A way to fix this would be that the miner mines the ores at a constant rate no matter how many nodes its attached to. 

So yea. If you like factory builders for relaxation like me, this game might not be for you.

Even though this is considered "Early Access" this is one of the best base builder games I have ever played. Great quality of life additions constantly being added by the devs.

Only issue is some UI elements could be a bit clearer.
For example if a tech tree requires something else it would be nice if the "requires X" could be selected to take you to the tech that is required rather than searching for it manually. The tutorial part could be a bit more robust and some of the localisation could be slightly better. Those are just some minor nitpicks though.

Overall the gameplay loop is fantastic. Would recommend.

EDIT:  So much time has been spent in this game I have put in more hours into this than my full time job almost 400hours between 11/29/22 and 1/29/23

This game is addictive. It's probably my favourite of the automation/base building genre. Mostly because you have a change in scenery when you start conquering new planets, so you aren't stuck looking at (or cleaning up) the same mess you started with for the rest of the game lol. Also, Dyson spheres are awesome, and it's what made me want to try the game in the first place.

I really like being able to fly around to other planets and solar systems, spreading and setting up bases to make an interstellar network. The movement and flight feel great. The skill tree progression feels rewarding and impactful. The interplanetary logistics system works pretty well, although I haven't stressed it too bad, but everything works as I want it to right now with about 3 planets. The scale you can eventually build at is enormous once you have the resources of multiple planets to work with. I guess it has to be, to be able to build a Dyson sphere. 

It's been a long time since I've been so engaged in a game. I should probably save this one for weekends only so I don't suddenly realise I have to be at work in a few hours on a weeknight.

Also, it's very well optimized. I'm quite surprised at that, as it's still in "early access". You'd think it'd lag like crazy once you start getting multiple planets running simoultaneously, while launching thousands of rockets, ships, satellites etc.. But nope, it still runs well with minimal frame rate losses.

This game is a low-stress resource management and building sim.  You can't really 'die' in game and the goal is to research technologies, then build the infrastructure that allow construction of a giant spherical structure that wraps around a star.  It is also possible to build more than one sphere in matrioshka-layers around a single star, or around different stars, etc.  If you like building automation that feeds into more automation, and so on, until you're building truly massive structures in space, then you'll like this game.
The only downside is that there is no Steam achievement for completing one.  The game has achievements you can earn, but they are for lame things like "burn every kind of fuel".  Weird.

[b]BUT![/b]
This one is pretty playable and enjoynable right now! Aboard, guys!

[h1]Pretty Playable[/h1]

Firstly, you can now make something like MALL right now without large amounts of planetary/interstellar logistic stations. And also, this is more important, supply yourself by bots. This is really gamechanging innovation, you won't need to build by yourself large amounts of stuff managing parts by hands, you can delegate routine to machines!

Also, I have to check another points like achivements, bugfixes and performance improvement and other, which is really hard (on unity much harder). Blueprints are not carefully and easy done, but they are here and just works. After hours of gameplay I have reached some level of automation and spheres are building itself without large of trivial rounds.

But here are some another issue. [b]Lategame.[/b]

It's boring. Around half of time (total) is aboutt Alt-Tab. And at the lategame it was around 80-90%. I just pasting print on another planet and wait while sphere is building. Easy? Yeah. Interesting. Not so much. There are to little to play around factory designs or productivity. It can be little tuned with cosmetic-elements, but in core solutions there is just two types of - totaly on belts or massive logistic stations. And another point of this is that belts are sucks - you can make modular design very early (and its good) based on flying drones and this would be a painless, although repetative, base operation. At all, after gathering all rare ores and replacing production by alternative recipes there is nothing to done but extend.

I'm not fan of giving treatment to this game, absolutely, however this can make game more intense. Anyway, I think some new techs should be added. Firstly, another options to base layout; it could be anything - from sushibelts, pneumatic mail or train to material -> energy and energy -> material generators. Second, extended logic is musthave, I really want to build self-extending base, but cant be done right now, sadly, in any condition - there is no factorio-like dronestations with building bots: you have to build anything by yourself. Third option - is about travel yourself, it could be lazy teleports or somekind of hyperloops/space-train. And, finally, gameplay should be, imho, extened NOT in managing against threat, but in different layer, maybe space-orbit manipulating, planetary annihilation in order to catch some rarest resource or anything else. And this is very, very weird that in game about space with building dyson sphere everythere (one of the most unbelievable project in the universe) there is no of other spacebuildings, like orbit stations, space elevators or large ships. Just weird.

Last con is controls and readability. This is a little better when early, but still with glitches and unforgivable behaviour. Like you've built large chain of deiterium processing and somewhere chain was disconnected becouse of unstable grid. 95% of causes is about grid. It should be fixed, but this is hardest part connected with begin setup and design. You can't move almost ready square-grid project to hexagonal one. Hardly, but we can fogive this issues, but they are very distractional.

But, as I have said already, the game is pretty good itself right now. Much more. And in my taste dyson sphere program could be much more cool, but this is nerd opinion. Today it could give you incredible puzzle-like gameplay with large sandbox for newbies, much more forgivable gameplay unlike factorio. And sometimes graphics are spectacular.

I will say there are a couple obvious achievements lacking, namely:

Outstanding factory game. Maybe the best one ever created. On par with Satisfactory for sure, but without cats.

Much like Factorio and Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program shines bright among the automation base building genre.

The tutorial when first starting a new game nudges you in just the right directions without being overbearing. The game loop of collecting, building, and automating is like crack and keeps you in the zone until you realize the whole day is gone.

Each planet has a finite space and you can circumnavigate them with ease. Logistics are intuitive, powerful and it just works. As you play you progress through local, planetary, interplanetary, and interstellar logistics which has a very satisfying complexity.

What makes this game stand apart from others in the genre is how it *feels* to play. You feel the scale of the planets and the vastness of space. Sometimes it's nice just to kick back and watch and listen as the factory you've assembled hums along, the drones fly by and cargo ships arrive from distant worlds with new resources to feed the beast.

And at the end of it all, you can look up into the sky from your starter world and see your hard work materialize before your eyes. The Dyson Sphere will start to take shape, piece by piece. It becomes more complete and only gets faster as you optimize your factories. It's very rewarding to see!

Don't be put off by the early access tag. Even if this game never got another update it would be worth it at full price. I am excited to see what the developers do next!

If you are looking for a satisfying, polished, and thematically exciting factory-building game, then get Dyson Sphere Program.

This game is truly amazing and at of the time of this review it is being continuously updated with new content. The objective of the game is to colonize an entire galaxy starting from just a single planet -- and it is HARD. To date, I have never been able to "beat" the game without running out of resources first. You must manage your resources wisely and quickly utilize them to gain access to MORE resources (i.e. another planet/solar system/...). It is a constant race against time and requires serious planning to come up with an efficient solution. 

However, you can also have a blast playing this game without having to worry about efficiency by just setting all resources to infinite. The gameplay alone makes the game worth it because the simple action of building (placing structures, belts, sorters, etc) is intuitive, convenient, and satisfying. 

This is probably the longest review I've ever written, so yeah... I truly think this is a game worth your time.

This is a well thought out game. Has a good community building blueprints for different kinds of factory styles. Overall you will have fun if you enjoy complex games eventually turning simple.

Don't let the broken, obviously-machine-translated tutorial voice-over discourage you. I did for a long time and it was a mistake. While that is a hokey aspect of this game and may make it more difficult for total beginners to the genre to get started, this is a very well fleshed out game easily (IMO) worth the current price despite being in Early Access.

Like most games in this genre, the early game can be slow and a bit painful if you're figuring things out for the first time, but as you make your way down the tech tree it accelerates and expands rapidly and massively. 

Feature-wise I would say that this game qualifies as a complete experience exactly as it is now. 

There is quite a bit of room for improvement in terms of optimization - the game gets VERY demanding on your hardware in the later endgame and some players will find their upper ceiling set by their hardware rather than their willpower. That said, the developers have already done a lot of work on optimizations and I'm confident they will continue.

Easy 8/10 currently. With more optimization work and an actual native or at least fluent english localization for the tutorial and tooltips that remain a bit incomprehensible at the moment, it will be an easy 10 in my book.

I like this game and I'm probably only half way through; but I'm not going to go any further. Why?
This is a game about efficiency - shunting loads of materials and objects via conveyor belts through 'factories' created from blueprints you design. 

So why I am not going any further?
 - The design and modification of blueprints is a PITA. If you do it a lot (and you will) in order to try out new layouts and increase your production capacity, you will quickly find the UI tools to manage and update your blueprints a real grind.

- Resources are limited, storage is limited. When you delete a whole swathe of production facilities in order to try a more efficient blueprint, the raw materials, components and facilities themselves are barfed onto the planets surface for you to pickup - and you simply don't have the storage space to hold this stuff. There's no feature/tool/technology that allows you to easily reclaim and recycle it, you're left to simply delete it - loosing all that hard earned production.

- You can build an automated transportation network that spans planets - but you can't see how much stuff you're holding in a remote storage facility. Did I miss researching the Internet?

- You can't prioritise supply chains. Running out of conveyor belts because there's no more Iron to build them! Well at least you have loads of Steel to build Oil Refineries - which need conveyor belts, oops!

In short the game starts out slowly. You build, research and automate. Then as you move off planet you transition into a play style that is about pouring as much raw materials into your production funnel as possible in order to get out what you hope you need in a self sustaining way to fund future R&D and production facilities.

Need more power and mining machines? Then mine more raw materials and build more factories to make more power and mining facilities - why not dial back on my production of Matrix Labs instead and funnel that to my new factories? Well, I have to fly/walk to the facility and manually turn it off of course - and then some other production facilities will grab their share of it.

I feel like a Zoo keeper feeding a menagerie of ravenous beasts. My Lions are dying! But all I can do is find more meat, toss it into the Zoo and hope the Lions eat some before another carnivore does.

Do you like resource gathering, production line building for upgrades? Is efficiency your kink? If yes, this game is a yes. The fact that its in space and you will see many beautiful things is just the icing on this already amazing cake. Additionally the devs communicate and update regularly so its one of the better feeling Early Access games out there. Strong recommend.
