Having a blast with this game. The gameplay is really fleshed-out, so it is hard to believe it is still in Early Access. The user interface and tutorial information seems complete. It is fun making the production chains, and the artwork is beautiful - even down to the conveyor belts at night. The game is slow-paced, and after 50+ hours, I am still trapped in my home solar system. It's a great, chill base-building game, with no time-challenges, dexterity challenges, enemies, or even much puzzle solving.

I created a planet-wide factory on an Ubuntu Linux desktop computer, with Steam's Proton compatibility software. The game requires a lot of computing power, and my system sometimes had trouble handling the graphics while flying between planets. Otherwise, I had no other technical issues. Really happy with this purchase, and I feel this is totally worth the price, for those who want to tinker on virtual machines.

Build the most efficient intergalactic factory in space simulation strategy game Dyson Sphere Program! Harness the power of stars, collect resources, plan and design production lines and develop your interstellar factory from a small space workshop to a galaxy-wide industrial empire.

Look, it's pretty, it's satisfying to make things and have them just WORK, it has fun exploration elements, you get to build a dyson sphere around a star--or around SEVERAL stars! Is it 100% realistic? Nope. But it's still fun as all heck. Also, the developers, while a small team, are very active about listening to player feedback and making changes to make the game more fun. 

Potential cons: 
-vague story at best, although combat update should be changing that a bit here soon
-will eventually chug once your factory reaches a certain size, no matter how good your computer is
-some translation errors/weirdness, but it's mostly easily ignored
-will steal days of your life without you realizing

Overall: 9/10, excellent, absolutely worth the 20 dollars they're currently charging for it.

If you want realism, this game is not for you. Building a Dyson Sphere is an impossible task mainly because of the scale, but this game handles that surprisingly well

Let's take a look at our Sun for example, the surface area of the Sun is about 6x10^18 m squared. This means that if we want to build a Dyson Sphere with a thickness of just 1m entirely covering the Sun, we will need 6x10^18 (6 Quintillion) m cubed of materials. For reference the volume Ceres, the Dwarf Planet in the asteroid belt is roughly 0.4x10^18 m cubed. So unless we can find 15 Dwarf Planets made of pure titanium or carbon nano tubes, humanity is still far away from building a Dyson Sphere

In this game the scale is brought down to manageable levels, your local star is no bigger than a planet, and the emptiness of space (especially interstellar space) is remedied by warp travel. Ultimately this game does a great job of creating the illusion of space being a rich and abundant place to feed your mega factories, instead of the vast and empty nothingness that it actually is

This game took me by surprise. It sat on my wishlist for nearly two years because I thought "Well, it's Early Access so I'll wait until their committed to a full release." Full honesty, I still don't know if they are or not. But what's already here is definitely a full package experience. Unlike probably most, I haven't played Factorio or similar games. Maybe I'm shallow, but the only reason this game drew my attention at all was because #space. But man, does it work. Unlike others, you get a very significant expansion of scope as your technology and throughput increases. Your not staring at the same map for hours on end - you're building up from a modest corner of the world, to a factory hub, to suddenly making planet-spanning designs, to flinging yourself across the solar system, then between stars. Just like how seeing a smaller setup functioning correctly is satisfying, seeing the space between planets light up with dozens of hundreds of small lights from ships is just as much satisfying, if not more so. There's a real sense of exploration, albeit on the level of Elite Dangerous rather than NMS. But just overall, this game went from a game I thought I'd only put a couple hours into, to completely eating up any free time and thoughts. I recommend this game not just to factory-builder fans, but to problem-solving minds in general.

The game has potential to be really good, but there are too many bugs. Some of which I see people complaining about 2 years ago, so the devs aren't fixing the most annoying bugs that make the game frustrating. Blueprints are barely useful as they will only work in the same specific spot of a planet. Blueprint a production line, try to copy it just above.. you can't! Proportions aren't the same. And here I'm not taking about the tropic lines which ruin your original designs, make you lose space, and force you to always build everything the same way. So the game is just a repetition of making identical production lines along the horizontal lines in the zone the equator is in. Production lines that were working perfectly well suddenly stop working because all the sorters decide they aren't picking up stuff from the belt for some reason. You delete the machine, copy the one next to it that isn't working either, paste it on the spot of the deleted machine, and it works. This means basically having to delete and remake whole production lines on a regular basis.
It's also very badly optimised. Bad FPS that can't be fixed by changing options. Once you got a significant dyson sphere, don't expect more than 20 fps, unless you disable its display both in the world and in the editor. Once you've maxed out your dyson spheres on a system, you will have 1 FPS if you display them.
If you come from factorio, expect to be disappointed.

Dyson Sphere Program is a great automation game. The futuristic style of the technology allows you to achieve some pretty impressive feats, and it makes it fun to watch your assembly lines grow with each new piece of technology that you introduce.

I'll start with the basics. The game has a pretty decent starting point. You begin by getting resources and using them to fuel your mech and build up basic technologies to help you automate things. This part of the game is unfortunately the most boring and least exciting part. Your mech is slow, your resource gathering is minimal, and you must undergo the very boring task of manually clicking on resources to harvest them.

Once you pass this point of the game and start upgrading your mech, the game opens up tremendously and allows you to start making some progress and introducing some very fun technology to use to help with logistics, transportation, and more.

 Now, here is the unfortunate thing about DSP:

There is no end goal.

While you have objectives to complete, the game doesn't really "end" once you complete the final objective. The only thing that happens is you get an achievement.

For me, I set the goal to build a Dyson Sphere large enough to power my home planet alone. Once that was achieved, I stopped playing, as I felt I had "beaten the game" so to speak. While you can decide when you want the game to "end", it does lower the replayability for me when there's not really an end goal.

Another issue that this game has is that it is hard to keep track of your production lines. This is a bit of a spoiler here, so skip this paragraph if you want a spoiler-free review. I ran into multiple issues where various planets I travelled to had bottlenecks that happened on them eventually. I had no way of getting notified of these bottlenecks or losses of resources, and it wasn't until I stopped 5-6 steps down the line with my production that I discovered that the resource mining on another planet several light years away had run out. Granted, you could say that this is part of the game, to manage these supply chains, but it turned into a more frustrating part of the game rather than interesting and challenging part. I believe it would be much better if the developers introduced some sort of alerting system that allowed you to know when resources were about to run out on various planets and such. While this would start to clog your UI slightly, they could easily make it a collapsible menu that you can check, with highest priorities first, so on and so forth.

Overall, I think this game is a solid automation game. If you enjoy games like Factorio or Satisfactory, you will definitely enjoy this game.

It took me roughly 80 hours to get to the point where I was able to build my first Dyson Sphere. I'm sure many people have done it faster, but for someone who had never played an Automation game before, I feel this is a fairly average time.

So take that time investment and multiply it out a few times to get roughly the amount you'll need to reach "end-game" type stuff. It will take quite a bit of time. However, I had great fun and highly recommend this game to anyone who is up for automation or management games. You'll enjoy the technology, endless amounts of upgrades, and large-scale beauty of the game.

For the time being, only a partial recommendation so long as it's in early access.

In short, the gameplay's good, the mechanics are fine, but there are a lot of little nuisances strewn all over, a lot of stuff is very unintuitive or downright clunky, and the user interface is downright awful which makes these issues far worse. For the time being, Factorio is simply the vastly better game due to being far more refined.

However... you can still have a lot of fun with Dyson Sphere Program. It's still a good game at its core. Once you learn all the weird, intricate nonsense, it's not that bad, it's just definitely not great of an introduction to your first factory builder genre game, nor is it currently as good as anything else you would play instead.

The thing is, the overwhelming majority of these problems are things that tend to be cleaned up at the very end of a game's development. The tech tree, for example, is an absolute mess. Techs you research don't have prerequisites of required parts, so like you'll learn a new tech, go to build it, and discover you don't have the tech to build it, and the tooltip doesn't tell you where it is, and then you have to go open every single other tech on the tree to figure out where it is looking for it by icon alone only to find it's on the opposite end of the tech tree with no indication the two are linked at all.

To give a more in-depth idea, I recently unlocked the ability to trade between planets. Yay! You kind of need to since not all resources are on all planets.

But yeah, basically needed spots to deliver to, the delivery spots have to have their own bots, have to specify what they're requesting, have to be manually set to actually request anything, and manually set to request instead of sending out by default. That's just for the boxes themselves.

From there, you also have to set up the distribution towers between planets, each planet needs its own tower, the tower needs two kinds of bots, has to be set to request/send locally or interplanetary separately, and though it has bots it can't actually accept stuff directly you have to have a box set up outside and explicitly conveyors going into the tower but not into the box, and for getting things out of the tower there's a special new icon that only shows up if you hover over one of the output slots that aren't very clear they exist and it's not clear that it's needed to do that to get anything out of it.

This gets things onto and off the planets, and into nearby boxes, but you also need planetary scale towers to get the stuff shifted around a planet since the boxes have limited range which isn't shown anywhere as far as I can tell.

I got stuck on almost every single step of all of that, because of misleading, unclear, or just flat out missing tooltips combined with extremely unintuitive methodology. If this were some rare, unnecessary part of the game, it wouldn't matter so much, but this is a pretty fundamental "you absolutely need to do this to continue" aspect of the game, and it took over an hour messing around with it after I had all the parts to figure out how they fit together and what setings to set them to in order to get them to work. If it didn't work, there was basically zero feedback other than it still didn't do anything. No indication of what was wrong or what to do to fix it most of the time.

Most of this will probably change by release though. Most of these things are early implementation methods, or things that change often (like the tech tree order and tooltips) so it's not surprising that a lot of this is a mess because it's early access still. The issue is that these things are kind of necessary for basic functionality of the game, and there are a lot of problems with it at the moment. They will probably all be fixed by release as the team's clearly making good updates and fixing things as they go, and much of these issues are things that usually get fixed at the very end of development as stated, but this means that this is a very blatantly early access game.

It has, however, not crashed yet. I had a partial soft lock for a few minutes in the UI once, but was able to fix it without closing the game. The game runs smoothly even on my old junker computer that wasn't fast even when it was new.

Dyson Sphere Program is also fairly pretty, with not too bad graphics at all, though not the prettiest you'll ever see. It's fairly stylized, the buildings make sense looking at them, it visually fits together well, and the music is really nice.

So... if you're bored of factorio or mindustry or any of the others in the genre, DSP is reasonable to pick up. If you're new to the genre... you're vastly better off getting something else for the time being. When it's released fully, DSP will probably be a great game and a top notch contender for second place in the genre, possibly for first place if it can manage a strong modding community with internal support for such combined with multiplayer. If it lacks multiplayer and modding at release, then it will still be behind factorio because of those factors, but it will provide a more pretty visual experience, so some people will prefer it for that.

For the time being... support them with purchase if you want to make sure they have the finances to finish it and polish it up properly, but understand that this is clearly an unfinished game. It's like 90% done or so I'd guess at this point, it "works" as in it "functions at a playable level" but it's lacking a lot of the really important polish needed for a fun user experience instead of a lot of headaches. Give it another 6-12 months from the date of this review and it'll probably be one of the best options on the market.

I don't regret getting Dyson Sphere Program at all. It's just an extremely hesitant recommendation in the state the user interface is currently in is all, and a few other issues with things like how raising and lowering conveyor belts is a pain to do. Most of this looks like it'll be fixed in the final released version, though. Possibly all of it.

Editing my original review:
I came back to this after a long break, forgot everything, excitedly started a new game, and it seems updates have just made this more buggy. 
Game continually gives me an alert that it's disabling Steam achievements and segregating me from everyone else (the game pools your data with all other players, so basically you're playing with everyone else, even when you aren't) - I'm just not about that life. This is not China. Do not punish me because of your game bugs. I noticed the Engrish translations have not improved, either.
Sigh. Oh well. Original review is below.

Original review:
I LOVE this game. I HATE this game. I CANT DECIDE. This game is insanity.
I've become demoralized watching videos; after getting to what I thought was the start of endgame only to realize I was near the end of the early game.
I played Factorio. Hated it. Played Satisfactory. Loved it. This is like a love child between the two, but powered to a factor of ten.

PROS:
- BEAUTIFUL game
- You get a MECH! Awesome!
- Automation is super cool to see. It's like, "I built that plate of spaghetti, and it's ugly, but it's functional."
- SCIENCE!!!

Cons:
- NO MULTIPLAYER IS A GIANT DRAWBACK
- This is a Chinese game and the translation is so-so. It's clear that English was not the first language of the individual writing the script. On a HIGHLY TECHNICAL game like this, that matters a lot. I found myself getting lost more and more frequently as I unlocked more technology. (This is why I went to search How-To videos and fell down a rabbit hole of hopelessness.)
- The tutorial is about as helpful as someone putting a plate of food in front of you, explaining what the food is, and then expecting you to reproduce it from scratch. It's helpful but it's not as robust as it needs to be.
- The game is massive. That is an understatement. I tell you it's massive and maybe you're excited or maybe you're thinking I'm exaggerating. I am not. It. Is. Massive. (The game world becomes a little smaller as you unlock advanced technologies for quicker travel, but it's still massive.)
- The time sink is real and it's hard to remember what you need to do BECAUSE of how massive it is. You set up Planet A for a specific purpose, go to Planet B, C, D, and/or change stars - you have to automate *entire planets* for specific purpose(s), and then get those planets to automate with other planets. Drones help but this process takes HOURS, and that's *IF* you have made good use of blueprints and shortcuts AND have your automation set up properly. If you are manually setting everything up this becomes an impossible slog. Admittedly your mileage may vary depending on your play style.
- Controls are wonky, and that's being kind. Moving on a planet is intuitive and wonderful. As soon as you take off for flight, things start getting wonky, but it's manageable. However, as soon as you are able to leave a planet, things go downright bonkers. I spent half an hour of my life freaking out as I had freshly unlocked the ability to leave a planet only to realize I had no fuel and the way I left the planet was not the way I would get back to the planet. (I literally got lucky and was forcibly slingshotted around a planet which put me on path back to mine.) It was a mess and I made it back by sheer luck and waiting AGES for my fuel reserves to replenish. (Thanks, Auto-Save, for saving almost immediately after I left the planet....) HIGHLY suggest watching how-to videos for this, if any are present. I'm still afraid to actually leave the planet.

Pros/Cons:
- PHYSICS MATTER. Literally!!! I'm not just talking conveyor belt speeds, I'm talking the angle of certain buildings can't shoot certain sails unless certain conditions are met. If there is a PLANET in the way, it won't fire!!! If the degrees don't match, it won't fire!
- You can spend 15 minutes in this game and make meaningful progress, that doesn't feel meaningful at all. You can spend an hour, two hours, three hours, and have the same effect. It's sheer size and requirement of being a time sink will get you lost in the game if, and only if, you have time to spare but that also means you will spend a lot of time doing a lot of things and feel like you make zero progress for it.

Overall I would recommend playing this game but only to those who have watched one of the endgame videos out there, one of the long 45 minute ones, so you can TRULY appreciate the sheer size of this game, the massive timesink you are looking at, and have an understanding and respect that you will likely NOT know if this game is truly for you or not with an hour or two of playtime under your belt. You will likely spend a good 10-20 hours before you decide if you've got the fortitude to complete this massive game.

This game gets compared to Factorio a lot. Also to Satisfactory, but… nah. It's closer to Factorio. 
It's pretty much like Factorio, but…
…the planet is smaller (not only not infinite, but traversable in flight mode small)
…there are many planets which you can fly to (manually, don't get lost in space!)
…no trains
…no biters
…no Multiplayer
…less tech tree
…3D!

So… if you got bored by Factorio or you're not wanting to pay the price tag: Here's your digital crack! It's the same kind of fun, just with slight differences. Also: It took me almost 15 hours to realize there are two splitter models and I don't have to spaghetti my main belt. FML!

It seemed like a lot at first, for me. Probably my 2nd or 3rd time sitting down with the game, it clicked, and now I'm 13 hours in. This is Industrialization: The Game. I've seen it compared to Factorio, which may be accurate. It's vaguely similar to Oxygen Not Included's automation, and the same in some Minecraft modpacks.

Don't build things personally. This extends to buildings/factories as well -- automate production of those as soon as possible. Conveyor belts are cheap, you can run them across the world pretty easily, spread your stuff out. (Edit to add: And logistics can use drones to ship stuff pretty quickly without the spaghetti at an energy premium.) Some buildings (smelters and assembly buildings, particularly, but research matrices too) need more than one intake from the belt, and/or more than one belt, if you want to maximize production.

Honestly, the factor of not doing things personally makes sense if you consider the scale of what you're trying to build. Of course you're building factories to make factories! Note that 13 hours in I have had little to no reason to leave my starting planet, though I am able to (edit to add: I lied here kind of, I had left briefly to mine some titanium in the starting system, which is what I meant). I have a Dyson Swarm forming that is getting quite respectable power generation. I am also trash at this game LOL, there are degrees of optimization I make no effort to achieve.

Edited addition: The planets in this game are really small, and everything is really close together. The excuse is that your mech and buildings are just gigantic, but it doesn't feel like enough IMO, the tinyness does show through.

[h1]Early Access test results...       loading...... 
[/h1]

[list]
[*]Stunning 65-100 FPS, blowing away many completed titles in any genre
[*]More content by epic levels than most completed games.
[*]Animation and Artwork that surpasses most "Polished" games in full release
[*]The score for music and sound is amazing.
[*]Updates regularly without pushing, panicking or raging... they come with ease.
[*]Growth, Development and Replay ability is unsurpassed
[*]Stable is an understatement. It runs amazing... flawless on any graphic setting. If you have issues, it is a driver or something mechanical on the players end. Tested on 4 machine types with various setups, one as old as 17 years, and the game operation was flawless.
[*]Immersive at levels that can not be described. not a full on space junkie, until the last 6 hours played at the time of this review. (YES first time played, never left our seats in 6 hours)
[*]Priced AMAZINGLY low at a mere $1.17US per hour of entertainment! 
[*]On sale would be mind blow of epic levels and unexplained.... but even at full price, just trying to get our understanding of undervalue pricing here. Grab it now!
[*]There is an End Game point, but can be endless if you wish.

The negatives... how forced they must be... but honesty is key...

[*]You must be able to read Chinese or English, they are the only two languages currently
[*]The bad English translation that still exists in areas, funny... but nothing that effects game play or understanding of the task or instructions.
[*]Time can fly by. So immersive can be cataloged as addictive. The visuals alone can move you into a trans.
[*]Single player only at the moment, as multiplayer may come in a long way away down the development highway. 
****So stable in Single player, no need to break it or worry about multiplayer yet. Enjoy the stable, stress free journey at your fingertips.

[*]A beautiful and relaxing ending to each game. Visually stunning. Amazing. Awe inspiring. 

[/list]
[h1]In closing...[/h1]

Dyson sphere Program® is the most undervalued, and unexpected game of 2021.
Amazingly bliss...  Fantastic work by every department developing this game.

Oh, last thought..... let us remind you... since Dyson Sphere Program does play so much better than 90% of any completed titles out there, it is still Early Access.

This is probably one of the better games I have played in quite some time. You start on your home planet and begin manually crafting your way to higher tiers and equipment. You will make a mess of your planet with belts and the haphazard ways you lay out your factories. Do not get discouraged. You will have to deconstruct what you built to accommodate the next level. It doesn’t stop here either. You are in your own solar system and will eventually be able to travel to the planets there. Your resources on your planet are finite, which makes you leave your planet. You will set up your main base of operation on your beginning planet and bring resources to it. Not everything you need is on your planet. You must explore and travel to other galaxies to harvest and build what you need. It is so complex with the logistics system you will find you are thinking about this game while you are not even playing it. You will not be disappointed with this game. It is addicting.

The game just straight up runs like garbage on 4K displays even if you turn all video settings to minimum and make the resolution the size of a postage stamp. At best I get around 15fps. when playing on a native 1440p monitor I get very high fps, around 200 or so. I'd wager render resolution is always just determined based on your display native resolution no matter what settings you choose from the very limited selection. You'd think a game like this would run great on a RTX3090 when it's the size of your thumb with minimum settings, but I guess not.

Otherwise pretty fun. A bit simple perhaps, but that's ok. Just wish it would run better.

This prevents players from rebinding pretty much any keyboard controls in the game, and is a huge accessibility fail. I don't care what software is available to fix this according to those commenting on other reviews. This game is extremely inaccessible out of the box right now because of that fact, so I cannot recommended it. I will change my review if I find later they have fixed that issue and maybe re-buy the game, but until then it's a no.

The game is near perfect. I've had two full runs and I have nothing bad to say about it. The pogresson is very satisfying. The gaps between research tiers are just right that it's not too fast but also not too slow that it starts to feel tedious. 

The controls are intuitive enough, with a lot of shortcuts provided for more convenience. Blueprints are also provided to make scaling up much easier. 

And the graphics. Oh my God the graphics. The way it renders space travel, the solar sails, the Dyson sphere. It's like a vista you can just keep watching because it's absolutely beautiful. And even until now I can't stop being amazed at how an indie game manages to render all these details without my computer catching on fire. That it can even render thousands of solar said and rockets at the same time is absolutely mind boggling. 

I also didn't encounter a single bug. Easily the most polished indie/early access game I've played ever since I got it almost a year ago. I would've paid AA prices with how polished and beaitful the game is. Everything just works.

"Hey you just built a storage; let me tell you how that thing works." Yeah cool dude I only built a gazillion of that already...

Update: You seem to be able to disable it now in the settings. Yet you won't get any advice with this setting in general anymore it seems. Would be nice to just disable its voice lines.

Other than that it's a decent logistics puzzle game.

honestly i play a lot of factory/automation games (factorio and satisfactory being the most notable). i enjoy the genre a lot, but most games never keep me engaged long enough. i played this one a bit off and on when i first got it, it was about the same as any other automation game to me. i'd play it a bit, then lose interest after some time. i decided to get back on it after a while, and it had been QUITE a few months (if not a whole year) since i last played it. lots of stuff had changed, which would [strike]hopefully[/strike] be expected as it's in early access. the differences kept me engaged longer, as they were pretty much all positive. i then ended up progressing more than i had in my original save, and the more i play it, the more fun i end up having with it. i prefer this game over any other automation game. i think it's WELL worth the money, and if you're looking into getting any type of automation game, this one would be my top recommended. if you've played other automation games, 100% look into getting this one.

TLDR: If you like Efficiency puzzle games such as Factorio, Satisfactory, Little big Factory, Automanaut, Tropico, City Skylines, ect. Then you'll like this game as much as you like or love those. 

You'll see most people say it is intergalactic Factorio\Satisfactory 

But the truth is it is intergalactic Factorio. The satisfactory feeling is from one of two things. It is A) 3D and B) one of the options is to set resource nodes to infinity. Normally they get eaten away like they do in factory and hence the intergalactic part. where you have to go further and further away building logistic chains just for sending warp cores to all your far flung logistics hubs so your long haulers can warp from whatever star system you've gone to this time to get ... and ship it back to your factory on your first or second planet where ever you chose to do so. 

Or you can enable infinity resource nodes, and then it plays more like Satisfactory in that your nodes stay in the same spot and you just build your factory. This is easy mode to learn the game on or if exploring and rebuilding mining posts doesn't interest you. 

now it is <7 days old released in to EA when i write this review. So it is missing 1 major QOL feature (or I just missed it during the tutorial....) is a blue print feature. Because of this I quite building smelters on other planets to cook the ore. I just shipped the ore back to my main planet.

Less power so less time spent setting up a power plant on that planet. and ect. 

Right now at it's current state it does basically everything that Factorio\Satisfactory does and then the extra unique bits that come with space travel.  and it's only come out 7 days ago in to EA on steam. 

Imagine what it could be in 2 yrs.....

I'll update as they do.

EDIT: Theyve added in blueprints and quite a few other great things.

Edit 2: They just keep adding more, Combat is coming soon. Sqeeee!

Dyson Sphere Program is an incredible game that offers endless hours of fun and challenging gameplay. The game allows players to design and build their own space-based civilization, managing every aspect of its development from the ground up. The game's physics engine is incredibly realistic, making the experience of building and managing a space-based civilization both challenging and rewarding. The game also has a lively community of players and modders who have created a vast collection of additional content, such as new technologies and gameplay options. Overall, Dyson Sphere Program is a must-play for anyone interested in space exploration or engineering.

after 180 and hours I can definitively say this game is worth the cost of entry even at full price. 
Dyson Sphere Program combines so many good aspects of other automation games into one package that it is almost impossible to NOT recommend to fans of the genre or people who are interested in dipping their toes in.
The game starts off slow hand collecting basic materials but within about 10 minutes you are already starting to build facilities to automate those steps.

As the required items become more and more complex they never seem to stray too far outside being manageable. 

There is only one section of the game, progression wise, where players tend to get overwhelmed, Yellow Science, about 10-20 hours into a save for most people. And that is because that is around the time you need to start going interstellar and getting new materials from another planet, something you must do manually for a bit until you can unlock another way to automate even interstellar gathering!

There is so much here that is just fantastic, Dyson Sphere Program builds heavily from and shows it's inspiration from Factorio but never in a bad way. The added 3rd dimension to building, being able to weave belts however you please is a nice change and being able to have an entire planet saved as a blueprint can cut down on tedium later when you are making one material planet wide.

It's worth a play through by anyone who even remotely enjoys  Automation games, especially if you are a Sci-Fi nerd. Combat is coming soon in a patch and the last thing the game needs to truly shine is official multiplayer, although there is a mod that adds that function to the game that is surprisingly stable and works well enough, FOR NOW.

GIVE US OFFICIAL MULTIPLAYER!

Enjoyble factory type game, with a really well optimised 3D engine (not sure if it's bespoke, or based on a commercial engine) as it can handle so much animation without any noticeable slowdown even in very complex environments. Good variety of technology and fairly fast progression is possible without too much effort. Travelling between planets is simple, and setting up inter-planetary material movement is trivial really.

The only downside I found was in the late/end game the prospect of making hundreds of thousands of the last "white" cubes was too daunting for me to continue as one of the materials is extremely time consuming to make (I had tens of thousands of all other colours, after every remaining upgrade then needed white cubes to continue). That just seemed like a time-sink, honestly. So I finished the game as far as I wanted, and enjoyed it, but had no desire to continue. I know this game is still under development, and hope it's something they address though!

Im still barely scratching the surface.

You start with really primitive things, you'll feel like you're progressing really quick through the research system and suddenly you start needing very specific things. So you dedicate an entire side of the planet to making that specific thing only for that thing to lead into even more. And then you need to set up interstellar logistics so you can make use of that anywhere you need it. THis game has so much depth and i really cant wait.

Dyson Sphere is a fun and relaxing factory building game. The story is present, but mostly there to guide you on the options within the game. I have spent a lot of hours enjoying de-stressing and trying different avenues of logic to building a balanced and functional planetary factory. 

The graphics and effects are well done. Exploring the worlds throughout the star cluster can get repetitive, but it looks fantastic just the same.

The developers are active and introducing new additions to the game frequently as well, giving the experience refreshing renewal for multiple play sessions. 

Dyson Sphere is recommended for those that enjoy logical building and factory games. There is room for the game to grow, and the developer team is actively adding to the game, giving more value to the future of the game as well.

I do have some suggestions however:
 * TELEPORT. Interstellar travelling really gets annoying over time so this should be added as some sort of late game technology. Like selecting a waypoint to a destination, it should then be possible to teleport there directly. It could consume a warper or two. Heck, this could also be used on a planet scale. Just pick a point in planet overview and teleport there.
* LOGISTIC OVERVIEW: There should be a status page of all the logistic stations like there is for production. It should be possible to overview what a certain planet or star cluster is providing storing and demanding. It should even be an option to teleport there directly. 
* An option to auto replenish fuel and warpers for your mecha. Its just a needless step having to deal with that since there are fidget spinners providing you with the items anyhow.
* An option to set a travel destination from a planetary view.
* A way to label/bookmark certain buildings and then be able to search them and even teleport or set a waypoint to them.

Hope somebody reeads this. Cheers

This game is pure crack cocaine incarnate. You will spend more hours on this game than you have and that's a guarantee. Each time i recommend this game to a friend or a loved one of my mine i have to warn them of just how addicting this game can be. In my 300 hours I have played through the game several times, cutting my total time to beat the game in half each time i played through the game. Each addition from the developers has had a positive impact on the replay-ability of the game.

Unfortunately the possible end game that this game holds is currently limited by engine performance, with the ending of the game being at a safe point before significant frame rate drops of building several Dyson spheres or multi-factory filled planets. I'm hoping the developers of the game can greatly optimize the performance of the engine, as the combat update looks to be a lot more than what the current engine could handle at a decent frame rate. I'm hoping with greater optimization we can see more end game goals and truly push this game to the limit similar to how people have done in satisfactory.

I enjoyed the game, and you might to if you're into the Factorio-type games. Although, I did find it irksome that the research is about calculating "hashes". It's like the developers are enamored with blockchains, but didn't know enough about the topic to understand that hashes only serve two purposes there: 1) To verify that the previous block wasn't altered. 2) To simply slow down the computer with excessive busywork, so the entire chain's checksums can't be recalculated within seconds, increasing the chances that the nefarious actor will be caught before they're done.

But once I cried myself to sleep and got over it, even at an early access point, it seems fairly well polished and competent, and shiny.

I feel like the Dyson swarm/shell construction should be introduced far sooner. There's a lot of work to get to that point, and it's the main theme of the game... and once you get there, it doesn't do a whole lot. By the time I reached the "winning condition" of researching the final main-quest technology (which had no technology?), I felt like I was basically done playing. My first shell was still building, but I didn't feel like I had to stick around, to either wait tens of hours for it to finish, or try to expand my production, just to see it complete faster.

The game also doesn't provide a lot of reason or incentive to go explore the universe. Sure, it was cool to find a black hole, and you can get the rare/valuable elements mine and shipped back home... but once that's done, why bother? I think exploration could stand the be reinforced. I think I could go to another star system and start building another Dyson shell/swarm... but why would I? You have to enjoy tackling the daunting in the first place, for a game like this, but that might not be enough to keep you going once you've gotten what fun you'll get, out of the game.

I did play with the resources being set to infinite, so I couldn't deplete them. That definitely affects whether you're incentivised to seek more resources elsewhere, but I was finding that depletable resources were sapping the fun for more. Any game will provide a list of hurdles and challenges to overcome, but I'm happy that the game let me decide which challenges I wanted to have, for the most part. My point is, however, the game should have additional reasons to explore beyond that all your resources are gone at home.

Unlike a lot of reviewers, I've not actually played Factorio... but if you're looking for a chill resource/logistics game, this is definitely a good choice.

Pros:
- Incredibly satisfying to set up production lines
- Space flight and interstellar travel is easy to control
- Logistics allows for easy transport of items across planets and star systems
- You can see your own (custom designed) dyson sphere being constructed in real time
- Research trees and upgrades give a clear goal and rewards for investing resources
- Difficult (nearly impossible) to mess up and be unable to recover. You'd have to waste all your starting planet's resources before getting access to space flight, which would be unlikely to happen by accident
- It's possible to share blueprints online, so if you're lacking inspiration you can find expert builds in many places

Neutral:
- No combat or time constraints (as of Nov 2022), I personally like this as I can relax and go at my own pace, but I know some people like the pressure this provides

Cons:
- Some materials are disproportionately difficult to make (e.g. organic crystals) and can really bottleneck your production early on
- Travelling outside of your star system isn't actually required to beat the game, and doesn't really grant huge benefits vs the cost of doing it
- Some tech unlocks are not worth it until later, like solar sails

And finally a tip: Set up production lines for all your basic components as early as possible, you'll thank yourself later.

I don't write a lot of reviews but this game needed it. Quite frankly, its way better then it has a right too be! [h1] This is review two of three [/h1]

 I am writing in depth reviews for what i consider to be the three main factory/automation games, [b]Factorio, Dyson Sphere Program, and Satisfactory. There will be TL;DR's at the bottom of each section as well as at the bottom of the review[/b]

[h1] This is an early access review. When this game is fully released I will update review[/h1]

 Dyson Sphere Program (DSP) is one of the most promising early access games I have ever played. It is a prime example of a game that looks at the leader in the genre (Factorio) and iterates and improves on what worked in that game, as well as creating it's own unique systems. This is something that I think Satisfactory ultimately fails at and I will illustrate why I think that in my review. DSP has a lot of potential but I worry that it may suffer from feature creep, I hope that the devs can continue to add and iterate at the pace that they have.

[h1] Performance [/h1]

 Dyson Sphere Program, impressively is a pretty stable game. Even in it's current early access state, I didn't start seeing frame drops until deep in the late game. This is impressive because DSP is a 3D game, with multiple layers to it unlike Factorio. Planets are fully rendered, though lacking in detail, and once you have multiple bases on different planets, you can look up into the sky and see the fruits of your labor orbiting, launching or doing whatever else, even across space. It really is something to see, when you have a dyson swarm completed and you see the thousands of pieces individually orbiting the star. There is a list of options to assist with performance, however it's not as extensive as i would like, but overall the performance is extremely satisfactory

[b]tl;dr: for an early access game the performance is very impressive. Fully rendered planets, factories, and thousands of entities without frame drops into deep late game. The game is very visually pleasing to look at as well[/b]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
 
 Like in Factorio your goal in this game is to automate a factory, though the end result is completely different. In this game your end game goal is to build a fully functional Dyson Sphere, and everything you automate along the way will assist you in that goal. To do that you need to produce data packs, which allow you to unlock things in the games expansive tech tree. This game is also on a universal scale, you are given a sector of a galaxy with dozens of stars, and planets to exploit, and eventually you will have entire planets completely covered in factories, absolutely teeming with logistics, and shooting things off to distant stars, it is very satisfying to see. Where DSP differs in it's factory design is with less of an emphasis on complexion of the recipes, and more of the mass production in my opinion. Adding in the extra axis by making the game 3D is used to great effect here, and it is carefully designed with many items to assist in with the extra complexity an entire extra dimension to build in adds. DSP, like Factorio, is not scared of big numbers, and also of just giving you the tools that you need to have to streamline efficiency. 

Using the inventory and building feels snappy, and satisfying. Everything is very clearly presented and even late game factories are easy to follow and see what is going where. The game also has a nice tutorial at the start that will help new players ease in.

 As of right now DSP does not have any external threats to your factory, however a combat update is in the works and it looks absolutely ridiculous and I will update this review when that is implemented. DSP does have a local, and planetary logistics system though not as in depth as Factorios, definitely does feel well thought out and extremely intentional in its design all logistics are done with either belts or drones. Your late game planets will be swarming with drones, and the space in between the planets will have swarms of interplanetary drones as well. As of right now there is now logic system for computation in the game.

[b]tl;dr: DSP's gameplay loop is extremely addictive, with very well thought out factory design mechanics that keep you moving towards your next goal or milestone. A responsive and easy to use inventory and blueprint system make for a game that flows very well from one objective to the next. Logistics in this are simple, but fun to use systems that are extremely fun to watch in action as they fly in the skies or between planets.[/b]

[h1] Early Access [/h1]

 I feel like one important thing that is often overlooked when reviewing early access games, especially on their full release, is how did the devs treat their community, as well as their game when it was in its early access period? I am happy to say that as of right now, while major updates have been slow, the dev team has been very communicative of their goals, and while pushing out minor updates, have continuously been working towards the large combat update. The team is open to feedback, and is quick with hotfixes when major bugs are discovered.

[h1] Overall tl;dr: [/h1]

[b] DSP is an extremely well designed and very promising early access game. The games performance is impressive on my rig with stable framerates up until the very endgame, there are many options to help performance as well. DSP has a fun and addicting gameplay loop, shallow but rewarding logistics systems, infinite scalability with the blueprint system, and a dedicated dev team that seems committed to providing not just a clone, but a competitor to Factorio. [/b]

I love this game.

While it wears the Factorio inspiration on its sleeve - conveyor belts, inserters, assemblies and smelters, colored science inputs - Dyson Sphere Program also has more than enough of its own identity, and a lovely design, along with a pure focus on building. No biters here. Heck, I can even ram into a black hole and my mech is fine.

Starting from manually collecting resources by hand, you will go from a humble planetary industrial hub, to building your own megastructures and having a proper multi-system empire. And what is very impressive to me - spreading to other planets is not a gimmick, but a necessity. The game has its hooks in me and will not let go. After finishing Factorio for the first time, I at least had a moment of "okay, time for a break", but I keep getting more ideas in DSP.

I wish they'd implement a few quality of life updates, for example some overview of a planets logistic stations, so I wouldn't have to manually check which ones supply and demand specific materials, but the game is worth the full price right now.

If you get it, my recommendation is to not look up any strategies and go in blind. It's so satisfying to figure stuff out by yourself, and improve upon your designs.

Performance could do a bit of work though. Framerate can start to get a bit taxed with dense designs. Maybe another reason to spread production around.

This is a wonderful game if you are into the factory building game genre. A dyson sphere is an incredible project to centre a game like this around; it is a long term goal and how long it takes you is directly proportional to how efficient you have set things up. The devs are extremely active and work hard, and it shows. So despite some flaws, this game is a solid recommendation. Just a few points to keep in mind that I want to touch briefly, though I could go on for hours about the small details and design decisions of this game:

-> The game does not explain that there are features like tidal locking and variance in the rotational periods and inclinations of planets; this affects things like ray receivers for your Dyson Sphere significantly, and with a bit more info might prepare you to start building your (first) Dyson Sphere around a different star.

-> You can get stuck in space with no respawn mechanism if you run out of fuel. Autosave works and is frequent enough, but hoping for some sort of respawn mechanism to avoid this pitfall in future. Again, Early Access. 'Just reload a previous save' is not a great solution design-wise.

-> English localization has a solid B+ for effort, lots of voicelines recorded, but do not expect perfect English. To me, I honestly find it charming, rather than taking away from the experience, but some might feel differently. Voice acting is solid, even if the lines are likely machine translated.

-> There is no coop at time of writing. I don't expect it to be implemented by the devs, but there IS a mod for it, and it DOES work. The game lends very well to coop due to the ability to go to other system and do independent tasks while contributing to the same goal.

To reiterate, the game is excellent overall, and deserves the price asked. The devs are constantly updating the game, and I have no doubts this game will reach full release in due time. Too many early access games get abandoned; I sincerely hope to see this game reach full release and go on to make DLC and/or a sequel. This game has heart and passion behind it, and deserves success.

I have now partially completed my first sphere and have "won" the game.  It took about 100 hours and I did not rush through it.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and I highly recommend it if you like solving problems and building.

You start off on a planet in a randomly generated cluster of stars.  The game is rendered beautifully in full 3D with planetary axis, rotation, and orbit being relevant to energy production.  If you want to unlock techs in the game, you must complete ever increasingly complex mining, refining, and assembling (and logistical) challenges.  The game helps you get started with some simple in-game instructions.

Eventual you unlock the ability to travel to other star systems to obtain more resources.  And finally you have to figure out the elaborate process for creating a steady stream of sphere components and start building a dyson sphere.  I found that the factoriolab calculator for Dyson Sphere Program was very helpful for figuring out total resources and building ratios required for each new product.  Google it.

Once you have your sphere started, you "win" the game but you can use the insane energy generated by the dyson sphere to keep growing and expanding to other star systems if you want.  Or you can start over with a new randomly generated star cluster.  The developer is still adding features to the game.

I've played Satisfactory as well.  I love that game too.  But I never felt much of a purpose for meeting the various milestones in Satisfactory and it is much harder to build with the first-person point of view.  I really enjoyed the interplanetary and inter-solar setting and scale of Dyson Sphere Program and the top-down building point of view.

My only criticism is that there is so much unlocked potential to create more lively solar systems and challenges to go with them.  There is a variety of planet types but planets only come in two sizes, normal and gas giant and gravity is the same on all planets.  There are no animals.  There are no moons, no asteroids, no comets.  No solar flares.  No binary star systems.  Planets have no weather and the atmosphere is basically irrelevant.  Space is only a medium to travel through. There is no building in space other than the sphere for power generation.  Dyson Sphere Program 2?

I would recommend this game to anybody who likes building massive, planet covering and bigger, factories. Yes you do get to build a Dyson Sphere but first there is a lot of building, collecting resources and exploring your universe. It is not easy, even without enemies, but persevere and you will get there.
The UI is excellent. The first time you realise you can build up as well as horizontally brings a huge smile to your face. Travelling from planet to planet is good fun initially. Later you can make it easier and more fluid with upgrades. There are lots of upgrades for all your factory buildings and for yourself. These can open access to more resources. Nuclear reactors for instance. Even better you can even build a small star to power your entire base with ant-matter fuel pods. however at first you are limited to wind turbines, solar power and coal burning. When you move to different planets, as you will have to do at some point, pay attention to which power sources are available for that planet. Wind turbines will not work if there is no atmosphere. Solar panels will not work on the dark side of a rotation locked planet. Just like our moon but bigger. Coal will burn on any planet but you may have to actually transport it to the planet in the first place.
I'm sure you get the idea.

Of course I am a Chinese but why I use English to write this comment because I want to let more people to recognize the quality and the amazing thought of this game. (我是中国人，但是此篇测评用英文写成，意在让更多人了解这个游戏的优点)
The Dyson Sphere idea was brought to us during the 1960s, and this five-person developing team somehow managed to transfer this deep-scifi idea into a universe building game which is full of design as well as optimization drawbacks as the moment. But the point is that the idea is fresh and the construction line is thorough according to my view. Although the local language is not available for a large quantity of players at the moment. I am pretty sure that it will do better. We already have excellent building games such as the Factorio and Satisfactory which also uses the idea of expanding our civilization in other planets but where is the end of the game? This game has an ultimate goal which is not only finishes the research but also builds your own Dyson Sphere model. Everyone can be a designer and imaginable person to create yourself a Dyson Sphere. 
At the moment, this game is not included in the NVIDIA Geforce Experience or other Graphic Card Adjusting platform so you can't adjust the game to fit your PC. This game has not been optimized well so it really puts a large amount of burden on your Graphic Cards so do please prepare well for heat radiation and fan noise.
The whole game requires 80-100 hours to accomplish the goal and maybe even more when you are in your first saving just like me.  
In a word, this game is awesome and it will be better when it is fully developed. Wishing you a piece of unforgettable experience.

I've started playing a lot of automation games lately, but this one has to be my favorite. The mechanics are simple and intuitive, the difficulty curve is satisfying, and the scale is both daunting and exciting. 

I'm also constantly amazed by how smoothly this game runs despite the absolute massive amount of stuff it needs to calculate at any given time. I've got dozens of planets all shipping resources every which way and I'm standing in the middle of an absolute nightmare of a spaghetti conveyor belt system and I don't see any problems whatsoever.

After many hours of playing, it gets a bit lame having nobody to experience it with, but that doesn't take away from the fact that this game exemplifies what early access should be, which is why I'd still give it a 10. To me, Dyson Sphere is like combining many of the good aspects of Satisfactory together with Factorio. It's easier to build and scale than in Satisfactory, but you also get more of an open 3D world exploring aspect. Also lots of potential for playtime with different goals in the game (Building dyson spheres vs cranking out as much research as you can). Since I bought this the devs have added many great quality of life features and cool additions so that I'm wondering what's coming next. 

My only current issues with the game are a couple of things that I'm hoping the devs will address in the future. One of them being no easy way to deal with excess products. The other, is dealing with the Dirt/Sand. There's no easy way to get more sand for placing foundation. I found a mod that allows you to destroy excess products and gives you sand as a result. To me, this is a perfect resolution and fixes both problems. I would love to see something like this in the base game. 

Other than that, multiplayer would be cool but I don't think there are currently any plans to be adding that for a while at least. Also sometimes it feels like early game can be a bit slow and tedious, but the new logistics fidget spinner drones I think will help with that a little bit along with the metadata. However, having the early game production be a bit annoying makes it even more satisfying when you can simplify production lines to avoid more complicated ones with the alternate recipes and rare resources.

Truly a work of art. I bought this at early access launch and it felt like a fully released game. This small indie team puts out a better product than 99% of AAA studios. They could've stopped there and I would have been perfectly happy yet they continue to develop and release content and fixes.

A+ Gameplay

Your goal is to literally build a galactic industrial empire from scratch with the end goal of enveloping stars in dyson spheres that not only you designed but it's also assembled through systems that you created over your entire playthrough creating perhaps one of the most satisfying and visually pleasing gaming experiences I have ever had. I have an extreme love hate relationship with this game. All the other reviews are correct, it is deep and an amazing factory, world, galaxy building fun time. Absolutely. Other people have described it better than I will.
I'd give this game 98.555555555555555% percent as a score.

What do I hate - The controls are irritating over a long period of time, there is just so much mouse mileage and keystrokes needed to do simple stuff (which you will be doing a lot for hours!).

Ok ok, but but the blueprints would stop that! - No, they don't. I am willing to bet that 95% of users who try their first blueprint out find that it doesn't work for any number of annoying reasons. It takes practice sure, but isn't an easy ride.

So let's go back to the mouse/key mileage - First 10 hours of gameplay whilst you perfect and experiment...You place your conveyor, oh I need a sorter, oh I don't have one. Bring up craft menu because it wont jump to that item automatically which becomes irritating later on when you have lots of choice..so you start the build and it doesnt appear in your hand ready to use. Open inventory and hunt for item in a 8x8 grid full of pictures. At some point you are a little tired and you cant find it. 

Later on.... You're learning how to put together complex new things. You can't just pin the recipe oh no. You might place a builder to look at the recipe. Oh, you have to use the mouse to go find the teeeny tiny X to change the recipe (imagine doing this like 10 times over as you practice placing and figuring out efficiency) - all you want is a quick shortcut to choose recipe. 

Now the next thing might just be me but I find I'm having to do finger gymnastics just to select item, copy, paste new, inventory open, uh oh the two menus are in the way again, press escape/back once, oops, no twice to get rid of the other menu that stays open for no reason. Oh no, I dont have the item, better replicate it...repeat above. Oh no got to press the small X and choose. Oh no it's too close or too far from the box or conveyor, repeat all again. Press delete, hold shift to select all, delete, press back/escape twice to go back, press construct, repeat again. 
.
I'm going to go hunt for mods to see if any of this is fixed but otherwise I must keep playing because fun, but not for my wrist or wsad fingers.

Oh, this game touches my addictive side of brain. I enjoyed Factorio already with 100+ hours (never played Satisfactory though), and this game is very likely to end with 100+ hours as well. 

It's well thought-through and you never stop learning. Sometimes I even go back to older factories and just replan them to have them nicer looking and more efficient. 

What I am personally missing is a better tutorial, you have to learn most of it by yourself, if you don't build a new factory or item, you will not learn what it does and you can simply overlook things. I would love to see some guidance in the beginning like "build 3x this and then 5x that" to help you in the beginning a bit better. 

I love the graphics as well, very stylish, the planets are different enough for me, and flying through space using Warp is always amazing. Maybe a speeding-up would be nice to have in the end game, or a kind of auto pilot, as I can imagine when you harvest the whole galaxy it can get boring and lengthy.

Overall, definitely a game I recommend, but beware - it's really addictive!

I love the peaceful building nature of this game.  It's fun and challenging to line things up correctly and I like figuring out how to set things up optimally without pressure.  Recommended for anyone who likes the building part of 4X games.

Edit:
After hopping back in, I can no longer recommend this game. Barely any updates over the past year (blueprints and logistics chests I guess?) and many of the core issues are not being worked on. 

Devs have continuously pushed back against fans that want multiplayer, despite the fact that modders have already figured out how to do it. And the game is horrendously unbalanced, to the point that you can beat the game using only basic power gen tech right until you build a dyson sphere. People are also still clearly having trouble with the interplanetary navigation and we've all missed our planet and ended up drifting endlessly until we reloaded a save. 

I thought the devs would listen to the community, but they seem to only listen to the tiny fraction of hard cores that want to build giant megabases just for lolz and ignore that the core gameplay mechanics need to be properly balanced for the average player.

--- 

These devs are fucking heroes. Listening to community and constantly adding features that are being asked for.

DSP is a model for what all early access games should be!

Can't wait to hop back in when blueprints go live! We've been asking for these in satisfactory for years and they just said "no"...

There's a lot to this game, but it's more fun than a lot of world builders that I've ever played and it incorporates real ideas from science, which is a nice touch. It's peaceful and exciting at the same time, so it's a nice game if you want to take a break from something that's stressful. It's real time, but you don't have to sprint and the game gives you time and leeway to "rebuild" your operations to make them more efficient. If you like games like Factorio and Shapez, you'll love this game. 

Overall, very peaceful, but not mindless at all. I've restarted my world about 3 different times, not because I felt like I 'ruined' the world, but because I felt like I could build it and organize it even better.  

Here's something I'll add: give the game a couple of hours. The first world can be really slow if you're not strictly focused on building facilities and supply chains. However, once you discover that the point of the game is to build operations and automate everything, you'll get past your first planet and the rest of the game goes exponentially faster. Then the real game starts (in my opinion) and t's a really fun exploration process. I've only scratched the surface at 5 hours (and I'm still in my first star system, with 45 left to go). I'm super excited to see what this game brings as I continue to explore.

Edit: 6 more hours into this game and I can proudly say it is addicting lol. A few suggestions for the devs since this is in early access still:

- Make more chemical components besides graphene and sulfuric acid and plastic. It would be really cool to be able to make additional chemical compounds that can do different things - a suggestion would be to expand the silicon family of chemicals, because those are in the same column of the periodic table and have a lot of the same properties for that fact. It would also be cool to see things like Uranium or synthesized heavy elements get utilized and added as mine-able veins or make-able materials

- Adding species and aliens to worlds (namely the first planet) would really liven things up, especially if they had varying levels of intelligence and you could harvest them for materials or make trade agreements with them based on their intelligence level (or even better, help them evolve into intelligent beings).

- To combine ideas from my first two suggestions. A whole new family of discovery of genetic alteration would be pretty cool to add as well. You could effectively take the idea of the "Spore" games and plop that right into this game for an even better experience. DLC idea! 

- Currently, if you want to build something (like a building) and you have 0 of that item, it means that you have to manually open the replicator, find that item, and manually indicate how much of it that you want. It would be nice to have a feature that automatically opens the exact item page in the replicator if I click on an item that I have 0 of. For example, if I click on a storage facility and I have none of them built, it should take me straight to the replicator page for that storage facility. 

- Another nice feature would be wormholes and bending of space time to travel faster. 

Overall, this game is THE BEST world builder I've played so far and has so much potential. Bravo!

Factorio is one of my all time favorites; this one pulled ahead of it. It's just so easy to try different optimization methods and fixing previous inefficiencies is a lot of fun. Plus, the progression feels great - setting up my first gas giant harvester and oil refining chain across multiple star systems was incredible. Designing your own Dyson Sphere is also a great touch; you're not just building some pre-designed asset at end-game you get to start small and take advantage of your design in the mid game.

This is one of those games that I like to call "China-jank" which means that it is immaculately well coded and bug tested and it runs very well, but there's not a hint of originality. The mechanics mimic Factorio, the graphics look like Planetary Annihilation and I'm pretty sure a bunch of the assets are bought straight off of a store.
It's like the opposite of "Euro-jank" which is generally very original and interesting but completely bug-infested.

It's amazing. There is so much you can do and you can take all the time you need to get there. Dyson Sphere is really ambitious and yet it doesn't let you down. I love playing this game over and over.

One helpful thing I can point out is that your home system may not provide all the materials to advance your research into warp speed. This means you may have to travel between the stars the long way. At first I thought the game just needed more development but that's not the case - at least not right now. It's a bit of RNG from generating your star cluster and persistence on your part to chase your dreams.

It's essentially factorio but incredibly well polished and featuring many improvements. Dyson Sphere has a 3d perspective and uses this to offer building vertically to massively reduce how much space your factory will take up on a planet. Another great improvement is letting players move between planets and build on different worlds to reach different types of resources. 

The only downside to this game is that it doesn't have multiplayer. Being able to build with your friends is Factorio's greatest strength

Edit: HEY NEVERMIND! THE GAME HAS MODS AND SOME OF THEM ADDS MULTIPLAYER!

After resisting buying Factorio to get not addicted, I made the mistake to buy DSP.
It is not less addictive. The reason was mainly there are (not yet) enemies disturbing the building and the nicer graphics and biomes. 
Finally, as I can judge so far some of the mechanics are a bit more convenient. No tunnels as part, instead the belt can be raised any time. Sorter can cover 3 lines. 
The visibility of process flows is slightly better.
Research and Mecha-upgrades is a nice element to feel progress not only in the factory itself.
The only thing – I ve no idea how to change – are the handler, which are not looking that cool.
A good game to sink time into.

EDIT 2.5 - None of this review is intended to spread falsehoods about the game, I am just sharing my 45 minutes of experience with it and my knowledge from other people. Any incorrect information is an accident and is not intentional.

I thought I would like this game, but something about it broke my computer. After playing for 10-15 minutes my computer was already visually stuttering and slowing down. If you have a good computer and like automation games I would recommend this but if you don't have a good computer I would instead recommend Oxygen Not Included or Satisfactory. If you aren't a fan of 2D games I also wouldn't recommend this game either as most of it appears to be 2D.

EDIT - By "most of it appears to be 2D" I was talking about the building and construction system, where you appear to be limited to a 2D plane that stretches around the world, without any option to build vertically, to my knowledge. In relation to my comment about the performance issues, I own a nine month old laptop, as of time of writing, and my frame rate was basically chopped in half after placing a little over a dozen items (check comments for list). Hope this helps!

EDIT 2 - Some items can apparently be built vertically, but only up to a certain height (5 or 6). However, to my knowledge, you are still unable to build assembly items on top of each other, meaning you are still limited to a bunch of (mostly) 2D planes for the planets. In games such as satisfactory you have basically unlimited verticallity, unlike this game where you are very restricted. I have a laptop with 12 gigabytes of ram, which is, by no means a high end laptop but also not a low end laptop either. Another point which I forgot to mention in my original review is the grid system’s inconsistency. The grid gets smaller towards the poles of the planet and larger towards the center. I am aware that this is an intended feature of the game, but I personally dislike it. Sorry for the long review and I hope this helps.

I rarely leave reviews for games but for this one I have to.  I have sunk so many hours into this masterpiece.
1) It's technologies are much more scientifically accurate then most games I've played which makes it particularly enjoyable that it's realistic in this sense.  It's depictions of astronomy and the distribution of stellar objects in our galaxy is ... quite frankly remarkable that a game designer cared enough to put in real marvel that is our Galaxy.
2) There's no time limits or pressure to get things done by a certain time so you can go at your own pace .. which will still take A LONG TIME to complete a dyson sphere even if you're rushing
3) There are so many things you can do that you'll easily find yourself lost for hours doing something that ultimately won't contribute to you finishing the game but you had fun doing it anyways.
4) Doesn't penalize you if you need to rebuild something, you get 100% of your resources back so you're not stuck with some setup you made early on when you were still learning that's an eyesore you dont want to tear down for fear of losing resources.  Tear it all down, and rebuild it the right way, there is no penalty (other then your time)
5) The space flight is a little clunky, especially early on before you've upgraded your Icarus appropriately..  Make sure to have some extra fuel on you because if you run out in space you'll have to wait for your Icarus to (slowly) regen it's power.
6) There is some broken English during the tutorial section but it's not bad and you can still understand what he is trying to convey.  People nitpicking this one little lack of polish are missing the entire rest of the game because this tutorial section with voice overs is like 15 minutes of the game .. and you can turn it off.
7) Just watching your dyson swarm and later dyson sphere be built around the star you've chosen is fascinating and super fun to watch.
It's a great game, very relaxing yet really stimulates your sense of logic.  I just wish it was supported on Linux...

Overall, a fun strategy game thats Factorio on a galactic scale. Its fun and requires a lot of strategizing.  The big downfalls:

1) Graphics. I don't know what it is with these "cutesy" "cartoonish" graphics for far too many games these past ten years. It's a fad I really wish game developers would get past. 

2) Sound effects. For some reason, nobody seems to have noticed that the sound effects are stolen straight from Minecraft. A Chinese game developer stereotypically stealing intellectual proprerty from Western developers. Examples of Minecraft sound effects:

The mecha walking noises
Picking up items using the "litter" tool
The "pop" noise when your mecha inventory is full, and an item "pops" out onto the ground as "litter." 
Even the music is reminscent of Minecraft music.

For the longest time, I didn't even notice it. Until I randomly did at one point, and now that's all I hear. Minecraft noises all over the place lmao.

3) Language. The voice over is done very well 90% of the time, and the voice actor is pleasant to listen to. The voice actor doesnt "try" to be overly exagerrated like most games do.

 But the descriptions of some (but not all!) technologies sometimes make little to no sense. For me, its sort of immersion-breaking when you stumble across a new technology on the tech tree for the first time, and youre left scratching your head. 

Other than the sound effects, cutesy graphics, and language, it is a really fun game and you can easily lose track of time playing it, trying to reach the next goal. I would definitely recommend this game. Its really well-thought-out, well-executed, bug-free (at least, I havent noticed any bugs at all!) and works smoothly.

For language and graphics, I would knock off 1 point each.

For the stolen sound effects, I have to knock off a full 3 points. Stealing intellectual property is a Really Big Deal to me! 


I give it a 5/10.

PS:

Stealing intellectual property is typically a complete and total deal-breaker in my book. I always rate a game a 0 out of 10 for blatantly stealing from another game or artist, unless credit is given where it's due. However!

This game is overall, fun and creative enough, and the sound effects barely even noticeable at all. They're there, but they blend in so perfectly well with the overall environment of the game that the player isnt even going to notice it. It's so far from the central core of the game, that it was just simply incidental that I happened to randomly notice it. Because of the developer's ability to essentially "bury" the sound effects and provide an exansive and immersive gameplay, I couldn't bring myself to completely fail this game in my review, and will instead, actually recommend it. 

To the developer if you happen to read this:

1) Seriously, make your own sound effects! This would be huge!

2) Try to update the descriptive language with clearer English. Not a big deal, but it would provide just that much more polish and shine.

Good:

- Fresh take on the factory genre. So good I consider this one of the "big 4" (Factorio, Oxygen Not Included, Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program)
- Unique goal and progress towards building the Dyson Sphere is fantastic and has gameplay returns.
- Multiple planets and planetary travel
- No "magic resources" (OK: Except Gas Giants). Factory lines need planning and appropriate spending.
- Infinite resource mode is built into the core game now, which just eliminates tedium (Contrary to what the game says, this doesn't make the game "easier".)

My #1 tip: TURN ON INFINITE RESOURCES WHEN YOU START A GAME FOR A BETTER EXPERIENCE

Bad:
- The English voice and tutorials are bizarrely non-native. Please just get a native English speaker to write the script!
- The space travel can be long and boring (especially at first). It would be much better if there was autonavigation between targets or just faster travel in general. Nobody wants to spend 2-5 minutes just flying between planets!
- Blueprints are unlocked strangely late in the tech tree which leads to alot of early game tedium. They should be unlocked towards the end of blue tech and before red tech IMO.
- Early game tedium in general. Tossing items in and out of boxes or playing "lazy bastard"-style is really dumb
- Some recipes (like the new sprayers) are unnecessarily dependent on a single resource and a single way to make them. As a result, sometimes if you're out of certain resources there are ZERO alternatives, even at lesser efficiency / optimizations.
- The new "hard mode" with low resources is just annoying to play, it's not actually challenging
- Sphere based construction means that grids don't align correctly and make complex blueprints useless at large enough scale
- This is very much a "base game" like Factorio. It needs Angel's/Bob's/Industrial Revolution style mod support to get more interesting.
- Like Factorio, limited resources is the default, which leads to rebuilding your factory over and over. This is just annoying, not challenging.
