Dyson sphere program is a well made game with a unique and interesting concept, making a Dyson sphere. For those who don't know, a Dyson sphere is a megastructure meant to collect all of the energy of the sun and produce inconceivable amounts of electricity in the process.
 It's got a research system similar to Factorio, having "matrices" (plural of matrix) being used for research. In general you could compare this game to Factorio, having the same premise of creating a gigantic factory, although with a different end goal. Right now I think Factorio is better for the one reason of mods. Mods make a game so much better and currently Dyson Sphere Program does not have them. If mod support is added I think the games will pretty much the same quality. Overall Dyson Sphere Program is quite a fun game, though it takes a ton of time to create factories. I recommend this game to people who enjoyed factorio or people who have a lot of time on their hands and also like automation.

I've been playing this game off and on for the past couple of years. I've got ~300 hours on the game. It's like a 3D version of Factorio but with inter-planetary logistics and no threat of attacks.  I've never reviewed a game before if that says anything.

This is one of the few times I've ever reviewed a game, and definitely the first for an early access title. This game scratched an itch that Satisfactory and Factorio couldn't - Satisfactory was too much walking, Factorio was not my jam, art style wise. This fits perfectly. This game is hard and surprisingly deep. Was rushing to an end game, but then paused and happily spent 20-30 hours fixing early game mistakes.

THINGS I WOULD LOVE TO SEE ADDED:
1. A better way to offload excess inventory. This litter system is annoying when cleaning up full lines of ore.
2. Autopilot to planets. The flying through space is pretty but I've got belts to lay dammit
3. Route management. I know this game is built by a very small team and am amazed at what's already been achieved. But if a boy could have a wish, it would be this: A way to visualize what goods are moving where are moving on a planetary and galactic scale.
4. Waysigns/Signposts/Maps. I love the game, but trying to find out where you put that spare gear factory 30 hours later is a real pain in the butt.
Lots of new stuff when I came back today. I hope this game pulls through!

You've probably heard of Factorio, Satisfactory, and maybe Oxygen Not included. Well, this is like those games! Except you can fly through the galaxy and most of the technology progression is based on future-tech stuff. I haven't spent as much time with this one as those other titles, but I'm coming back to it now. The actual building of a Dyson Sphere in the game seems kind of daunting to get to, but that's how it should be.

There are no biters to deal with, and no survival mechanics either. So, the game can feel a bit shallow. You're basically just focused on gathering resources efficiently and running through the research tree as fast as possible. But, the complexity of resource crafting gives you a lot to play with. If you want a base builder like Factorio that is solely focused on the factory expansion aspect, obviously with a focus on interplanetary resource transport, then this game is definitely worth the price. If you want something with more depth, hostiles to fight, and a bit more of a survival feel to it, then I would go with Satisfactory or Factorio. But you'll probably buy them all anyway if you like this kind of game, if we're being honest.

This game very chill, and you can put 100% of your focus into planning, gathering, building, troubleshooting, repeat... and generally crafting a very complex, purring machine... which, in turn, creates your own custom-designed Dyson Sphere.

Here's a few ways this game is a little different than other factory builders:

- Your factories are built upon spheres... forcing you to make all sorts of interesting choices in planning.  
- The automated trade network you are eventually able to create includes many other solar systems.
- Later, you will design a customized Dyson Sphere, and begin launching bits and pieces to it.
- The sphere will slowly come together, and watching it do this is absolute bliss.

At a certain level of infrastructure, resources are no longer any concern, so you can craft the sphere like you were working clay... leading to all sorts of gigantic, satisfying pieces of art.  Almost like a Spirograph in space.

There are no enemies or combat... yet... (though "optional enemies" are planned).  It did not detract from my experience in any way.. instead, this game's building complexity was very entrancing and hypnotic.. and fun.  The graphics are sleek, the game runs well, and I didn't experience overt problems or glaring bugs.

Wonderful game, totally worth my 20 bucks.  Still playing it after 200+ hours.  I really would consider it "required" for lovers of chill factory building games, even in early access.

-------------------
After 400+ hours:  My review and opinion remain the same, but I will add these comments:
-------------------

- Once I covered a planet in infrastructure, the game would (understandably) lag whenever visiting that planet (My graphics card is a 2080TI).  FPS would drop <30, but it was never game-breaking for me, and was only after the planet was 90% saturated in belts and machinery.
- In my experience, all these factory construction games use an annoying save-file technique during the early access phase, and this game is no exception.  At the time of this edit, my save file is 400+ Mb.  This makes the autosave feature pretty jarring when it happens, which is every 10 min.  Somewhat annoying but I'm betting it improves when 1.0 comes out.
- Once the tech tree and first Dyson Sphere is complete, there's nothing else to do except expand and/or make more Dyson Spheres. I'm expecting more will be added in the future, and I can't wait!  I'd love to see the tech tree get even more complicated!


These are minor issues though... the game is still unbelievably solid.  I can't wait until the next major update and additions!  Still a hearty thumbs-up!

As a Factorio enjoyer and having tried other factory games that were good but not good enough as Factorio I am surprised to see that this game stands on the same level, if not superior, as Factorio.

The progress isn't tedious and daunting if you are a seasoned factory planner and I could imagine if you are new into this type of games it will be an amazing discovery for you, in fact it's quite achievable, you still have to pour your hours and brains in to make a good and efficient factory but it doesn't feel like a task nor something reserved for the very best logisticians.

The part that DSP made me fall in love with it are the orbits and the planetary systems, it's innovative and refreshing. You must do interplanetary/interstellar logistics to attain certain assets, you may place some infrastructures in strategic places on the planet: solar panels at the poles to recieve a smaller but constant flow of energy or put them around the equator, put the dyson rail guns on the bright side of a rotational locked planet to constantly build the Dyson Swarm, etc. These are just a few examples of what this game has to offer.

Where I have to disagree with other reviewers is that this game doesn't have a Game Over/You are Dead mechanic. It does in a way that is, to me at least, way scarier. You can run out of resources if you are a careless spender and don't plan ahead, for example: you can run out of resources if you start the Dyson Swarm too early (Solar Sails have an expiration time unless you pour them into a Dyson Sphere). What I mean is that it is very possible to get planetary locked if you don't rush certain techs and prepare to achieve a planetary/interstellar logistics chain to support your main factory planet.

I still have to build my first Dyson Sphere and I can't wait to do it but I have to be very careful not to forget about my real life responsabilites. It's scary to see how the time goes by in a single game session and you don't even notice.

So Dyson Sphere Program is a "YES, you should buy it".

I'm put hundreds of hours into Factorio and Satisfactory, both of which I was inevitably comparing this too. I enjoyed this much more than Factorio as the worlds felt more inviting, the graphics are far better (I know the 2D/3D isn't a real comparison), and there are no environmental pressures here (e.g. bugs) which you have to fight off. 

The blueprint system is exceptional. The designs for everything felt extremely smooth and exciting to look at. The progression was easy enough to get the hang of, but I do have some experience with these types of games. I was very surprised at some of the customization options which were great to play with.

My biggest gripe would be with the English translation. It's as though the Korean developers hired someone who was obviously fluent in English to read from a poorly translated script, which was laughable at times. In some ways it added to the charm, but in others I would've preferred to not have been so distracted by it.

Spoiler: [spoiler] My other grip would be with how the game ends. It's just a fancy sound effect and a dialogue box. I get that it's not a narrative-driven game, but it feels so anticlimactic and a wasted opportunity.[/spoiler]

An interstellar planetary factory builder type game that is very chill. You really focus on optimization of how you have everything set up to get resources and things you make to the right spots with travel and exploring a procedural star systems getting resources from planets to travel further to eventually make a sphere around stars for ultimate power! 
   This was my first "factory" type builder game as I love games like city skylines and other building and management games. Its a game you go to bed thinking about and are excited to wake up and play again. The mechanics are simple and the game teaches you everything along the way. the best thing you can do as a new player is go in and make an entire mess of things and have fun, you will eventually learn from your mistakes and you can always fix anything with out wasting resources. There is no rush either you are the only one slowing you down from creating your first Dyson sphere so its great to sit back and enjoy the amazing view along your travels. And don't worry if you have a smooth brain like I do its very simple to learn and you will not be overwhelmed. Things do get a bit more complicated later but you are ready for the challenge at that point and its quite satisfying when it all starts to come together.

it's so easy to say "let me just get my interplanetary titanium lines stable, then I'll go to bed" then 8 hours later you have to pretend you didn't spend all night trying to figure out how oil works.

Well, EA review and all that. 
What is DSP (Dyson Sphere Program), well the simplest way to describe it would be a factory building game, but the factory is on a Local Cluster size. You start out in your planet slowly building things on your mech and deploying them, from here you start the glorious road to automation, first the planet then the system and beyond, all this to reach your goal of building a Dyson Sphere  or two or things that are supposed to be a Dyson Sphere yet more closely resembles an art piece.
 
You research upgrades, you setup flight routes for drones and later ships that fly in system and you guessed it later out of system. 

It's the type of game that easily allows you to lose track of time due to the simple satisfaction of seeing things work out, the devs have been updating the game for as long as I've had it and as such I do believe that it will one day come out. 

The game also does have some pretty cool mods which does increase the fun factor. 

Long Story short, 
Do you enjoy building things ? 
Do you the idea of Mega Structures ? 
Do you want a genuily good game that does exactly what it says on the tin ( so far atleast)?
Do you not mind EA ? 
Do like forgetting the world exists and that sleep is a thing ? 
Then this might be the game for you, I've certainly played and enjoyed this game more than quite a few AAA tittles that i've bought for a lot more.

I wanted to update my review after playing it the very beginning and then stopping for awhile, picking it back up again after a lot of updates and i have to say that this game just gets better and better and better. They keep adding quality of life additions, to make the logistics easier to manage. Its really satisfying to see one of your planets launching thousands of sails and components into orbit. Its such a deeply intensive and also extremely chill game, that you'll never get bored, because there is always something to do. One thing I love is that the technology tiers are more difficult to achieve the higher you get. The first 2 tiers are easy to make, because you only need a level 1 or 2 refined product, but in the higher tiers, you need 3-5 cycles of refined products in order to make the right product to create technology modules. It forces you to think about logistics as well as space conservation and planning. In my case, Im more of  a spaghetti factory type setting where my path ways go all over the place with little regard to uniformity.  But, thats the way I like it. Some people like playing with more uniformity and sometimes even have entire planets dedicated to specific functions, like energy storage or smelting and transportation. Ive seen some players have entire star systems in complete uniformity all to ship its products to a system that contains a Black Hole and then building the sphere around the singularity, giving it inexhaustible and unparalleled power. I mean its pretty freaking cool to be able to build a dysons sphere around any star, but to build one around a black hole.... thats a different level of awesome. But all in all this game is so good, so worth the money and its not even fully released yet. This game is chill enough to not stress you out, but complex enough to make you think. I love this game. I love it more than most fully developed and polished games of the genre.

Essay ahead, keep reading if you care about a long review or scroll down to see the end.
So, I love factory building games like; Factorio and satisfactory. I also love space, Factorio has a mod that lets you go to space, but that's a mod, not a part of the base game. Satisfactory is a set map with no chance to go to space (that i know of. I have not done modding for satisfactory) And then we have Dyson Sphere Program. All of the above things i love while Heavily requiring you to go into space to harvest resources from other planets and stars that contain materials that the starting planet doesn't have, like silicone and titanium, and other rare resources not listed on the resource view for planets. The end goal of this game is to Create a Dyson Sphere (Basically a Star encompassing Solar panel), A theoretical Mega structure only possible by a type 2 civilization on the Kardashev scale. The shear amount of science in this game is enough to make a grown man cry. Now, my brain is very smooth, so i tend to struggle to wrap my mind around effective transport lines and efficient production, so i take a bit to get anywhere close to the sphere. But once i launched my fist solar sail and started a Dyson swarm (That's the first step to making the Dyson shell in this game) it was pure bliss, watching the EM-Rail Ejectors go to town firing off the sails into orbit was so rewarding for my smooth brain. And that's just the first step to making a complete Dyson Sphere! That doesn't include all the other stuff i had to set up to even launch the first sail!
If you are an avid science lover and enjoy Logistical puzzles and watching a massive structure come to fruition from your efforts, you will absolutely love this game.
This is an absolute solid game with more stuff planned for the future.

factorio does it by having tower defense element, progress or you will be overrun... even if the risk of being overrun is actually super tiny, it lets you maintain the illusion that the next tech is important

Good Points :
1. Graphics are very good
2. Goal is a great one 
3. Ease of construction/deconstruction
4. Size of exploration of terrain great
5. infinite space and possibilities to perfect your construction techniques and the different solar systems are great.

Bad Points:

Overall this is a really great game in my opinion once you start playing it and understand it. It's hard to stop playing! Most certainly worth the price!

I'm relatively new to the factory builder genre, but this game has been absurdly addictive. Kudos to the devs for taking on such an ambitious project, very well done!

A few notes to new players:
Get a game started and play it a bit, then scrap that game and start over. It takes a few tries before you get a feel for how it works.

By all means, go find some Youtube videos on building ideas and layouts, but some of the fun is coming up with your own designs and seeing how they work (or not).

Make use of a sandbox game to create your own blueprints and test out production line ideas. This really helps to understand how belts and sorters affect a variety of production lines. Sandbox mode also lets you unlock all of the technologies at once; the game isn't always the best about telling you why you might want to build a particular building or produce a particular resource, so being able to access the entire tech tree to see how one tech relies on another helps in the long run. 

Sandbox mode is also a good way of understanding how to build a Dyson sphere without worrying about messing up your regular game; there's very little direction on how to build a sphere in-game, which is a little ironic given that's the whole point of the game. LOL. 

The game becomes very CPU/GPU hungry the further you get into it, so don't be surprised when you hear those cooling fans kick up. :)

Similar to Factorio, but IN SPACE.

At first, until I make my first Interstellar Stations, I was not enjoying the game that much but after this, it release all his quintessence

If you feel like you would enjoy Factorio without the enemies, this will please you.  Game is solid and I cant wait to see what this small team can produce for it next.  My only complaints are that I wish there were more options to change the difficulty of certain aspects of the game.  I wish there was a recipe materials required scaling as well as research scaling to make the game more challenging in other ways.  They added resource scaling but that doesnt force you into space or logistical constraints like needing more resources per part made would.

The games definitely borrows from factorio, but in terms of that, it's purely the fact you're automating a factory at all. Past that the differences shine. The biggest is combat, Factorio has it, Dyson doesn't. This turns many away but A) Combat is on the way and B) This games goals are far more interesting in scale that combat being gone doesn't detract from the glory of building your first Dyson Sphere. Factorios main goal (aside from mods, mods are amazing) is to launch a rocket into space. We focus primarily on the transport of resources from one location in a map to another but past that pont, that is all. I sure felt joy as I saw my rocket launch into space, but there was something missing. The process to that rocket was not all that spectacular once I realized I had the production to do it already setup. It also wasn't THAT resource intensive as once you reach this point in the game, you should be SWIMMING in supplies and can easily manufacture the rocket. 

This is where Dyson excels. Building a sphere is a time consuming and resource intensive process that, (unless you've sunk thousands of hours into setting up thousands of solar launchers and rocket launchers, as well as all the sails/rockets needed to supply that) you will be constantly and slowly improving the speed of that process overtime, watching your spheres skeleton take shape, eventually finalizing and the sails filling the gaps and you slowly see your hard work take shape over time as you work as it's right above your head!

Factorio misses this one aspect as the rockets there and then it's not. Dyson sphere your work is much more tangible and amazing in scale.

If you like factorio but are not sold on a zero combat automation game, try this as I love combat and still enjoyed this and if you did like Factorio but wish the space elements were expanded upon, FIRSTLY try the space mods for factrio, really nice, but then try this for the true galactic factory sim. 

(This is no way calling Factorio bad, I got 400 hours on that one :P it's merely different)

Factorio in space; done right. 

Colonize the entire system and build your own Dyson Sphere(s) to power everything.

After nearly 100hs in my first playthrough I still scratching the surface on what is possible in this game.

Let me start with my expacations:
- i liked the scenario (building a dyson sphere is just awesome) and sci fi and expected some kind of factorio variante
- i thought i have to build everything in one solar system
- i did expect some hard handwork for every factorio i created

So what did i get for 20 Euros:
- a really technical exeptional performing game !!! i am still suprised how a game with such complexity and scale can run that smooth 
- a galaxy spanning simulation with a cool android who can use warp flight mode to get from one system to another
- a deeply complex building system , with a great blueprint system that makes your work much easier and always inspires me for trying something new
- dyson spheres which can be edited by yourself and your creativity !

In Short:
For a long time i hadnt so much fun in a game. 
BE WARNED: You will lose track of Time!

This was my first "factory" game. I was drawn to it for its sci-fi and exploration elements, and it certainly delivered on those fronts.

Pros: Very pretty 
Reasonably easy to follow progression
Very addictive

Cons: It feels like the game doesn't begin until you have interstellar logistics, and until you reach that point in the game it feels like a real slog. For a first time play-through I think the development it takes to reach interstellar logistics is necessary, but once you've done it once, it feels like it can be a real hassle getting to that stage on a new run.

I did put a lot of time into this game, but I would venture half my hours were AFK while I was waiting for things to happen or finish just because I hate constantly tearing things down and rebuilding. The efficiency of  some of the advanced buildings is so good that I'd rather for things to wait until I finally get the tech than having an inefficient mish-mash running in-between. 

Overall: Highly recommend for first time value, also highly recommend the late game as long as you can power through the early game slog.

Initial review: 

Maybe I'm just being irritable. But first impressions aren't great.

They tell you that "physics are like this in the ACTUAL universe" when the ship does some janky flying in the introductory cutscene. 
Except I've played Kerbal, and this is just on a whole another level of wrong. Vectors don't add like that. You don't kick a forward-moving football forward, and it instantly goes careening to your rear from that kick alone.
Please don't blame the viewer if you already know you made the mistake.
Either don't say anything, or fix the cutscene. 
You probably still have the code you used to render it lying around somewhere.

Also, I think attention was paid in to making it controller friendly. Gimping it slightly for PC and keyboard. I could be wrong on this one.
But the bindings in particular are very weird.
Z is never mentioned to be the pick-up-from-ground button in settings. Even though they copied it from Factorio I guess.
You also can't rebind inventory button to Tab. It's stuck on "E" for some ungodly reason, double bound with "OK". Which means you also can't rebind Q and E to rotating view.
The dichotomy between base-builder and controlling a main-character-in-a-3D-environment are all the more apparent in this game, where it can't quite figure out what it wants to do. Controls, or viewport wise.

Having said that, it is playable.

Overall looks and plays a bit like factorio without the biter distraction.
Some parts come off better, some worse. It's an interesting side-grade so far.

Crafting, automation, and tech progression working well so far. Once I got stuck by slow research, and the game had a popup tutorial telling me why. Apparently I'd missed a function of one of the buildings.

There's also no disruptive and annoying "unskippable intro". 
There is still one screen (Dyson Sphere). But it doesn't have any jarring movement, or colours that would lead to excess irritation. And it goes away pretty quickly, to another easy-to-look-at loading screen.

Overall:

Pretty? Yes.
Gameplay? Ok.
Space game? No. (Fix cutscene plox)

What is it? Factorio clone. Kinda.

Edit:
I stopped playing this for a bit, then never came back KEKW.
For 26 hrs, and the experience I got, this game's a bit on the pricey side.

My opinion's still probably gonna flip-flop between yes and no for a while. I wish steam had a "neutral" rating.

Extremely good, my personal favourite factory game.

DSP really nails it's sense of scale. Starting off manually cutting plants and trees to keep your mech powered and before you know it you're pulling resources from a dozen planets watching your Dyson Sphere be constructed piece by individual piece. It doesn't abstract this, every solar sail you fire you can watch in orbit and see it be incorporated into your sphere, you see the individual rockets carrying structural components. Along with the background comings and goings of planetary and interplanetary logistics vessels it's often visually striking if purely from the amount of stuff happening on screen. The optimisation is pretty damn impressive too, and while the FPS will eventually be impacted it's only because it really doesn't limit you in terms of what you're able to do.

It also makes things pretty easy on you. You'll make some early spaghetti but it never makes it difficult to deal with. There are a bunch of vertical levels for conveyor belts, it never feels like you've designed yourself into a corner earlier on. You can always spaghetti your way out. Further down the line with logistics towers spaghetti is (mostly) a thing of the past but it doesn't require redoing your whole factory. Draw a box around what you have and start making new nice modular bits with logistics towers, your initial factory doesn't have to replaced until you decide you want the space/resources it's using up.

I pay 0 attention in this game to ratios or throughput or anything. You CAN but also you can brute force more things and hook it up to your existing belts, my weird rube goldberg factory is in no way as beautiful as a designed, planned factory but maybe you're like me and don't care about that at all.

Anyway, it's real good and cheap. Recommend.

I haven't experienced any crashes, though there has been some quirky behavior around deletion of objects. It periodically auto saves which allowed me to gracefully recover from a power outage, which is a nice feature. Some other pre-release issues are there, like help tips covering other important text, unclear or unmarked dependencies in the tech tree and minor issues like white text on a white background.

In all, it's been a lot of fun.

Hey, so, if you have a life outside of Steam, don't get this game. If you don't, get it.

I only got this game a week ago at the time of this review and have sunk 33 hours into it so far; optimizing everything so everything runs smoothly.

The game is a logistical factory-builder, where you basically have to micro-manage [b]everything[/b] so your factory runs as smooth as butter. When you play the game, during your run you may find it hard to keep up with everything - like you run out of Energy Matrices, so you make more only to find out you're out of Sulfuric Acid, so you fix that supply line to find out that your Iron veins have dried up and you aren't producing any more Iron Ore/Iron products. It's a logistical nightmare, but a fun brainteaser. Basically, you can do what you want if you have the materials; it's fun to optimize your supply lines later on and straighten everything out.

As such, the game is in early access, which makes it a bit hard to find some bad things about the game, but I do have some suggestions - for example, maybe there could be a Hydrolizer building that turns water into Hydrogen or Deuterium, and then maybe add an Oxygen Burner power plant to burn off the excess oxygen from said plant; or maybe an easier way to teleport to planets (for example, if you needed a specific item that wasn't in your solar system or on your planet).

Overall, it's worth the $20. Just make sure you interact with the outside world.

TL/DR   The game is good, but obviously needs some work. High potential. I highlight some negatives below, but I *do* recommend this game.

Things that I believe need to be worked on:

A. The English translations are acceptable at best. I understood (usually) what they were trying to say, but the noticeable errors are distracting. 
B. The ability to customize your keys is very bad and needs work or needs to just be removed. I wanted to switch TAB with E for inventory, but E is the only key that is unchangeable. I decided then to switch TAB with F, only for it to say TAB is now in conflict with something else even though TAB was *ALREADY* in conflict with 3 or 4 other things by default, just in different menus. If it was already OK for TAB to be in conflict with these things by default then why isn't it OK for TAB to be in conflict where I want to put it? Answer: it shouldn't matter. This just means that you *CANNOT* switch TAB to any other function which completely defeats the whole purpose of being able to customize keybinds. This is pretty much the same for every key, which means they should just take out the option. There are also actions that it ONLY lets you map to mouse keys. If I want my move-to-gather button to not be a mouse key then I should be able to do that.

TLDR at end
I am absolutely loving this game, while it has a few issues most of them can simply be due to it being in early access.  If you like Factorio you will likely enjoy this game.  The largest difference is, obviously, the focus is on building a Dyson sphere and expanding within and outside of your solar system.  Likely the most obvious issues would be due to the fact that it was translated from Chinese to English, which has resulted in some odd grammar, though it is still easily understandable.  I also found this game to be relatively short compared to something such as Factorio, though it is certainly not a quick game and can keep going for some time after finishing the main objective and the tech tree.  On this, it will likely be expanded in the final version but I can't say for sure, regardless it certainly offers enough content for the price.

The graphics are beautiful, especially when flying through space.  It is also extremely satisfying to slowly watch the sun be surrounded by tons of solar mirrors and then eventually have the actual Dyson sphere be constructed around it.

Overall, this was an extremely fun and satisfying game that managed to capture much of the same positives from Factorio while adding its on twists and improvements.  There is unfortunately currently no active threat to be vigilant against, but the vast goal of expanding throughout the solar system provides enough incentive to keep expanding quickly.  New content is still being added so you can also expect this game to get better the longer it goes.

TLDR-
Pros:
+Beautiful
+Factorio similarities
+Satisfying
+Content is being added
+Mod support is likely being added in the future

Cons:
-Mediocre Translation
-Relatively short (30-50) hours though can be continued long after completion
-Lack of active threat to worry about so it can get dull at times, though this is a personal preference
-Early Access
-Few mods and no integrated support

Conclusion:
Great game and definitely worth the money at base price, though it also often goes on sale.

This is basically Factorio in space. Factorio on steroids. As if the original Factorio weren't addicting enough. This game makes Factorio's graphics seem like Minecraft in comparison.

If you haven't played Factorio, the learning curve will be similar but maybe not quite as bad. If you've played Factorio before (and I mean, really played it), you'll feel right at home here.

Some things are simplified (you start with electricity and construction drones, and lanes/belts are only 1 resource wide rather than 2), while other things can be just as tedious as in Factorio (belt management is probably the #1 issue, making undergrounds in Factorio seem much more efficient).

Where it really takes off is that instead of building train stations, you go out into space. Instead of new resource pockets on an ever-expanding single terrain area, you can go claim new planets.

The music is fantastic, although even music this good does start to wear on the ear after hearing it enough times. There is definitely variety in the music but you have to go visit other planets to hear it, and that takes a while. By the time you get off-planet you'll probably have turned the music off.

The tech tree is quite expanded and very satisfying and futuristic. Much of it should feel familiar to long time Factorio players, but again, some things are simplified. (Being unable to walk over pipes was one of my biggest irritations with Factorio - not an issue here, although I suspect in a future update they'll change the belts coming out of liquid storage into pipes, as magic boxing and unboxing doesn't seem quite right somehow.)

Honestly my biggest complaint is the often awkward game text and technology explanations, but if that's the worst thing you have to deal with, then you're doing quite well.

I should mention that if you enjoyed the combat aspect (aka having your hard work ransacked every few minutes), there's none of that here.

Just about every aspect of this game is orders of magnitude more satisfying than Factorio (and that's not saying anything bad about Factorio). Another of my favorite new additions is that the toolbar is automatically organized for you. I hated having to organize it myself in Factorio.

It's an engineer's game for sure, but may be approachable for others in a way that Factorio was not. It has less of the Age of Empires look and feel and a much more modern, sleek presentation. You'll want to have some decent hardware or otherwise this game could get quite laggy. I'd say, give it a try and you might just be surprised. If you didn't care for Factorio, did I mention that you can fly in this game?

Very dynamic, and easily scaleable in endgame. Blueprints are a bit annoying to use until you learn it. Both a pro and con is how you have full control of how buildings are placed, sorta like the differece between red alert and zero hour.

Cons:
Logistics tracking non existent.
conveyor levels needs some sort of organiztion or elavation locking
looking for certain planets with certain resources is a bit annoying, and can use more unique things like tidal locking

Like many other games of this type, Dyson Sphere Program manages to scratch that automation itch and allows for constantly improving in this logistically challenging game. It's amazing how the hours fly by in this game!
 
[b]❤️️ Pros ❤️️[/b]
[list]
[*]The game runs very smooth and everything looks colourful and distinct from eachother so that you can easily tell what is going on.
[*]Sound isn't really important here but it felt satisfying to throw down new buildings and in terms of music it fits the theme really well (except there's 1 handpan song that gets tiresome after 50+ hours) 
[*]Multiple planets but you can see them if they're close. Also the dyson sphere is very well visible in the sky as you build it, which gives a great sense of accomplishment as you can really see it being put together piece by piece.
[*]Resource nodes are limited (which at first I considered a con) but you can easily get more without having to go too much out of your way. You won't need to rebuild your entire factory because you ran out of something and that is a design choice I really appreciate.

[/list]

[b]❌ Cons ❌[/b]
[list]
[*]The storyline is paper thin, but that probably has more to do with the fact that it's still in early access and the core gameplay is still being improved upon.
[*]The "end goal" is basically completing the final tier of the research tree. You'd think it's completing a dyson sphere but that's more a means to an end.  It's very underwhelming.
[*]Currently there is no such thing as a tower defence/threat element so it's really peaceful. I like that however I would like a challenge sometimes. Please note though: combat is apparently in development, so the devs might add that later!
[*]Flying between planets is a bit of a jarring experience. You can crashland into a planet with an enormous speed which is very strange and sometimes even disorienting.
[/list]

[b]Final thoughts[/b]
Dyson Sphere Program is a ton of fun to play and I only expect it to get even better as the game will come out of early access. This game is definitely worth a strong recommendation for anyone who likes these supply chain management style of games and is worthy of a place next to great titles such as Factorio and Satisfactory.

There are just so many calculations that need to be made when you've colonized dozens of planets and have multiple Dyson Spheres being built, that the game just can't keep up. Don't let this stop you from purchasing. There is a ton of fun to be had before you hit that point.

I've played through this game three times so far, and I love it. Easily one of the best games I've ever played

That said those three times have made the game's only real flaw rather apparent. This game was made in china by a five man team and while that is impressive it's also rather obvious that said five man team does not include a competent translator. The result is bad grammar at best, and near unreadable word salad at worst. Especially when they try to describe sci-fi science.

However the game is so spectacular that half the late game tool tips being nigh unreadable is seen as a minor issue, which says a lot about how excellent the game is.

As long as you can handle atrocious English in places, and the occasional poorly explained mechanic you'll have a whale of a time.

Honestly one of the best building/automation game out there. Obviously I have to compare it to the king of the genra Factorio : It's prettier and the scale feels better somehow. I always found factorio to be pretty tedious, giving you carpal tunnel at every turn, I don't have this feeling here, the game's design feels smarter and the UI is much more pleasing to the eyes. 

The game progression is simpler to understand and visualize, which is a big plus for such complicated games that requires quite a fair amount of brainpower. It allows you to focus your grey matter where it is needed and respects your time. 
Also the fact that you have entire round planets to build on changes everything: even though building is grid-based, you will have to account for the meridian geodesic which is really great. 

The game is still in early access at the time of this review and yet feels like a complete game, and a massive one at that. Devs are great: updates are regular, well explained and communicated.
The only downside is the lack of coop.

Dyson Sphere Program is my first encounter with Automation Games and I cannot get enough. 
At the time of this review I have around 220 hours and still want to play this, most games I get bored of after around 80 or so hours. There is a lot to do and it can easily keep you busy and burn hours without even realizing it. 

PROS: 
 Excellent performance and optimization early to mid game
 Price 
 Beautiful yet simple visuals
 Mecha customization 
 Enormous sense of scale that I hope expands with further development
 Recipes are easy to remember and make sense
 Blueprints are excellent
 The Building aspect of the game is fantastic. Everything is very intuitive and smooth
 The UI is excellent and easy to read
 Camera freedom 
 Straight up addictive game play. It's highly satisfying to build and expand

CONS:
 Planets feel very repetitive
 Towards End Game it can get tedious and repetitive 
 The game really needs a marking/pinging system
 Warping mid to late game is unpleasant. Very hard to see where you are going when thousands of logistic vessels cover your 
intended location
 Once you're automating multiple systems performance starts to tank, specifically save times. It's quite jarring to have a full 1-3 
second hitch every time the game auto saves and it only get worse the longer you play the same game
Really god game

DSP is my first factory automation game, and while I'm not sure if I'll continue with the genre, I can definitely say I've had a lot of fun with the game. I love the look of the game, it runs super smooth, and it's nice to have a clear goal you're working towards. The planets actually curve so you have to plan your builds accordingly, you can build vertically, and you can actually upgrade your mech among other things. Blueprints were also a fantastic addition that makes the game much more accessible to casual players who don't want to build everything. So far, the game has consistently been getting better over time.

The only thing I'm not crazy about is the "standard" logistics station build. I don't think that's something they can fix, it's more of a meta problem, but it's hard for me to imagine someone beating the game without using them. I'm used to playing games that have a difficulty curve that eventually plateaus at the end game, but it seems like factory automation games get exponentially more difficult as you progress. Solving simple logistical problems can be extremely fun and rewarding, but everybody has a different tolerance for logistics, and eventually it will start to feel like work rather than fun. I wouldn't recommend buying this game for full price unless you've played other factory automation games or you have a high tolerance for solving logistical problems.
An incredible factory game, I am in love. Highly recommend.

I really enjoyed this game.  I didn't find any bugs and the building system is very satisfying.  My only complaint it that the end game materials, namely the building of the Dyson Sphere, were so obtuse that I finally quit trying to achieve them.  I guess the developers want to give you a lot of variety with the building of the sphere, but I never could make any sense of it.  I really think they should simplify it.  Had it just known it would take 10 billion widgets or whatever to build it, then knowing my love for these types of game, I probably would have set about designing a production line to make said widgets.  Instead, this end game content requires choosing angles of orbit and other weird things that were just beyond my attention span.  Moreover, I couldn't find and useful documentation from the developers and even YouTube videos didn't help me understand.  I provide this only as useful feedback for the developers.  Keep it up guys as I will try again in the future.  Everyone who enjoyed Satisfactory and Factorio should buy this game.

[h1] A Factory Sim with a Huge Emphasis on Scale and Exploration[/h1]

[hr][/hr]
[b] Disclaimer: I last did playthrough to the point of building a sphere summer of last year. I have kept up to date with the updates. [/b]
[hr][/hr]

                                                           What is there to like about this game?
        The game is set starting on a lone, earthlike planet. You craft machines and use them to make more resources to make more machines to make more resources. For the grindy players focused on optimization, this might be enough to sell the game. 
     If you take a look at my profile, you can see I don't have many factory building games (factorio, satisfactory, hydroneer, etc.) So then why do I have almost 100 hours in this game? [b] Exploration [/b] The sheer scale of this game is mind boggling to me. If you were to try to escape your planet in the beginning stages of the game, you would quickly find that it would not take minutes, not hours, but [i]days[/i] to get to the nearest star system. As you progress you give yourself upgrade to go farther and discover a wide variety of stars and planets... and even find black holes. If you haven't seen the 3D rendition of black holes in the game, don't look it up. Play the game and see them for yourselves. [spoiler]I will say the sheer size of them absolutely terrified me on my first viewing and the euphoria I felt for finally being able to make it there was extremely rewarding[/spoiler]
     The main driving force for me, and the main satisfaction was being able to somewhat sate my curiosity of what a massive civilization would look like. I then easily spent several hours just flying around space and exploring the different planets. The fact that you can create such a massive feeling universe and still run at 80-100fps on a gtx 1070 and ryzen 5 1600 at all times is just worth it by themselves. 

[h1]TL;DR [/h1]
[b] IF YOU LIKE [/b]
[list]
[*]Space
[*]Exploration
[*]Atmospheric Games
[*]Grinding
[*]Optimization
[*]Massive Scale
[/list]

Finally, and I know this isn't a planned feature, but being able to take advantage of this massive scale by playing a multiplayer mode where you compete with your friends to make a dominant civilization and utilize combat mechanics, or cooperate with them to build a civ together would easily make this game an instant classic in my book.

I, uh, you know how in Factorio you unlocked the builder drones for the first time and your head exploded? You get something like that every 5-10 hours in this. I know it's called Dyson Sphere Program but my God you really do get caught by surprise at just how enormous it is. 

I've only got to tier 3 tech so far and am a huge dumbass but my spaghetti homeworld and silicon/titanium mining colony feel so FUN to play around with. When you unlock a new thing there's generally not an urgent need to instantly trash all your existing designs to fit it in and instead you're encouraged to just set up parallel factories for each thing in a much more gentle and creative way. Huge win over lategame Factorio which is just "build a bus base or no completing the game for you", in my experience.

The terrifically awful translated English voiceovers are just a bonus, really "You can be benefit to unlock more actual technologies" indeed.

This game is like Factorio + Space engineers, but cranked up to 22 and given an amazing graphical flair.

Hope the combat gives us a time-based challenge in the future. It's already almost a perfect game for what it does.

This makes travelling a massive massive pain in midgame which yes I know that's intentional but it's not a very enjoyable experience. Now I'm sitting back on my home planet just waiting around for research to finish not really even wanting to do the whole space travel thing again even to the closest planet ... which is what I had assumed keeps the game interesting like wanting to find new resources on new planets in no mans sky. Great "successor" to factorio. 
Beautiful, similar complex item-system (but no complex logic: no counters, switches, sensors or lights), more space, different biomes.
No enemies yet (but announced for next update), endgame is mass-production (factory must grow) to build dyson spheres (faster) in other systems and endless research (capacity, speed etc.)
Building on a planet (sphere-shaped) is easily managable only annoying at the poles.
Blueprints and building mechanics make building big productionlines a breeze.
Orbital Stations > trains (factorio), though less micromanageable (no destination spec just supply/demand)

At the time of the review my first sphere is almost done and im planning the next sphere in a different system playing around with the sphere-design and orbits.

Mods: unofficial Multiplayer-Mod works really good with 2 players (didnt test more) but requires hamachi and a mod manager. 

More chilled and relaxed and a bit easier than factorio.

Quite possibly my favourite game ever, with the possible exception of peek-a-boo, as my parents have often told me I was a Peek-a-boo FIEND as a toddler. Think factorio, minus bugs, and on an interstellar scale, with up to 64 stars (including neutron stars and black holes), each with planets and moons around those. 
If you like peaceful gaming to relax, this is your game. It is one of the exceedingly rare games that makes no mention of combat or strife whatsoever, has no adversaries or NPC's, and just lets you build and design to your heart's content. Important : ALWAYS check your fuel before you leave a planet. Space is BIIIIIG.

A factory-building/resource-gathering game at its absolute finest, with an interesting and powerfully unifying final goal. Players are, collectively, simply by playing the game, working to create a Type III Civilization on the Kardashev Scale.

I'm not normally moved to write reviews positive or negative, but I have to say I'd recommend Dyson Sphere Program to anyone who remotely enjoys automation games or simply wants a relaxing and rewarding experience. I've tried Factorio in the past and this has very similar DNA, but for some reason I can't quite put my finger on,  DSP has hooked me in far more. 

I've barely scratched the surface of course, but the eight hours I've played so far has flown by and I can definitely say that it's a complete gem I'm very glad I took a chance on.  In fact I'm wondering now whether I should investigate Satisfactory, which up to now I've not bothered to consider.

If you're on the fence, take a punt is my advice.

i bought this game like 3 days ago and so far have 39 hrs. absolutely amazing game. like other comments say, super chill, not punishing or challenging, but for peak efficiency itll require some brain power and can be a fun puzzle to solve, or you can use blueprints.
Do you like Space? Do you Like Factorio? If you say yes to either, then this game was made for you.

Think Factorio, Satisfactory, Planetary Annihilation (Sort of!) or Supreme Commander - all had a baby and REALLY put some time into it before sending it out into the world. The game is near functionally complete and there is SO much to do. There is a definite end game. I restarted once already to fix how my initial factory was, and realized very quickly the true scalability that they're going for. Like... I guess it's a spoiler but the whole point is to build a dyson sphere around a star, and work through the technological and logistical hurdles it would take to get you there.

Wild game, totally worth it. In my second playthrough, I'm just now automating red science some 15 hours into it. Wish the blueprints were already in, but that's coming.

The devs are VERY involved, and have laid out plans in their FAQs. If it feels like its missing something, more than likely it's on the devs radar.

No combat yet, but that gives it a sort of chill vibe to build that factory as big as possible as fast as possible, and see how crazy it's gonna get.

Get it. Full price this bad boy. Support good devs!

[h1]More than just Chinese Spyware?![/h1]
[b]YOU BET YOUR SWEET PAPI[/b]

Ok so truth be told I'm a bit newer to automation games. Grew up on RTS/Turn-Based Strat games, tons of FPSs, RPGs and MMOs, but my love for automation games came about early on in my twenties a little less than a decade ago.

I love a lot of the simpler-style games (Factorio) that use a relatively simple graphics style to mask a deceptively complex and near-infinite reach of possibilities in terms of just how far you can take it. 
On the other end, you have games with much more masterful and impressive graphics systems that use it to boost a slightly simpler assembly process, which I feel is where [b]Dyson Sphere Program[/b] fits in. 

[b] [u]THIS IS NOT A BAD THING![/u][/b]
One thing that always seemed difficult for me in games like Factorio [i]was[/i] the near-infinite depth to the game; at a certain point I just found myself almost at a loss for what to do after a certain point, and in certain game modes where the mobs continue to grow, evolve and multiply over time, this could spell unavoidable disaster for any player that failed to seamlessly grow there assemblages and supply lines as before long, your procrastination has resulted in a grand mob so far past you, it's literally impossible to reload a save with the hopes of outbuilding the AI and managing to escape your fate.

[b] [u]DSP ELIMINATES THESE ISSUES WHILE STILL MAKING THE GAME INTERESTING[/u][/b]
For me, this is where the graphics system really comes in to play - simply put, [b]the game is beautiful![/b] I would find myself relentlessly driven to reach the next tech level and further my production means not to keep a step ahead of some ever-growing AI-driven enemy, but because I eargerly awaited exploring the next world! The universe itself is scaled in such a way that every time you feel you've finally started to master a given level of production, you gain the ability to explore new worlds around your star; before long you're exploring distant star systems, finding new worlds with rare and useful resources, colonizing these alien habitats with your automatons to begin ferrying these novelties back to your homeworld where they would find a place in your ever-growing massive assembly line.

Dyson Sphere Program may lack the limitless possibilities of games like Factorio in their ability to allow more items to be produced than most players could ever dream of, but it more than makes up for this by creating such a beautiful universe for you to explore. The game does a wonderful job of pacing the advancements in such a way as to keep you engaged and working towards the next planet or star to explore, instead of getting bogged down in depths with goals so far off in the distance that you end up putting the game down due to the sheer time it would have required for you to complete.

The resource types and numbers are expertly calibrated in such a way that as your assembly lines expand from entire planets to solar systems to star systems and eventually entire galaxies, your time will have to be spent somewhere between colonizing new worlds and scaling up both the size and efficiency of your earlier systems so that the increasingly complex items continue to be pumped out in large enough numbers that these systems may feed not only planets, but eventual star systems and then entire galaxies filled with your automated creations. 

Honestly, this game does a lot of things right, and the lack of any against-the-clock countdown mechanisms allows for an incredibly relaxing experience, which when coupled with the amazing world it leaves you to explore, filled with countless planet- and star-types, leaves you with a supremely enjoyable gaming experience.

The only thing which prevents me from giving the game a full 10/10 is the fact that the game (at the time of this writing) is still in a early-release state, and while bugs/VERY occasional crashes are to be expected and will (hopefully) be worked out by the time the game launches, are still there and while again VERY rare are prevalent enough that I have to settle for a 9/10

[h1]This is simply an excellent game.[/h1]
For those who have a long experience on similar games such as Factorio and Satisfactory (I have played a lot on these), this is a mix of both : the automation looks like Factorio (ie. Smelting arrays) and the story looks like Satisfactory (ie. Sci-Fi based).

The background of this game scientifically talking is also incredibly realistic, even if this is still Sci-Fi, it stays accurate: the researches are based on real life discoveries and theories, and they're adapted pretty well to be understable and logical in the story 

I was bluffed when I learnt that it's a team of only 5 persons who developed this game, and furthermore in a tiny office! This is a miracle that it only cost $20 on Steam and ~$6 on Instant Gaming. Personnaly I am at the limit of being guilty to buy this game because it is so cheap !

The soundtrack and the graphics are very good too, in my opinion.

The performance requirements are pretty low for such a game and can be easily optimized if necessary.

The only issue is in the late game, the autosaves start to be pretty big and since they happen every 5 mins, it's a bit annoying.

The second big problem is thatw after entering the far end game (150+ hours), the pattern of playing start to be repetitive, even if the Devs have made an update with several new buildings, the construction is pretty much the same at this moment.

Overall, this game is easily one of my favourite, as it mixes to of my beloved games and correspond exactly to what you would intend of it. I definitely recommend it to anyone who love factory games: I've easily already passed 70+ hours on this game!

Also, English is not my native language (I'm French), so, please excuse any grammatical misconceptions.

If Kerbal Space Program (a space program simulator where you explore your solar system) and Factorio (a factory/industrial simulation game, hard to explain so just check it out first) had a baby, it's definitely this game. Industrial expansion on a galactic scale, while at the same time you can just step away from that and fly from system to system, exploring what each system has to offer. My only cons would be that there is no multiplayer (though the single player experience is amazing, again think of Factorio), and no combat like Factorio has (though as of writing this the developers announced a combat update is in the works so keep that in mind). 13/10 game, nothing has vacuumed my time like this game has in a long time :)

I like to think of this game as in the genre of "spaghetti factories", and in that category it stands strongly among the greats. It executes the tropes well, and adds plenty into it to give it a unique character all its own. Factory building is challenging and satisfying. The scope of the game and its graphics make it, frankly, strangely beautiful. Staring over the horizon of a planet at your dyson sphere as its built, flying over your factory world with the belts, machines and sorters blinking away in the darkness, there's really nothing like it.

I have about 5400+ hours on DSP. When you start a new game at first it is all micro managing your nodes and building a new part every time you get an upgrade, vs power, and ratios, blah blah blah. Once you get fairly advanced if you micro manage, you will get carpal tunnel, blueprints are your friend on the factory and planetary levels. If you have to do something twice by hand just blueprint it blank with no assignments. then as you fill the assignments take a blueprint of that and save it with an assignment

The game is different once you get along in the game. It is more about managing volume than managing a perfect ratio of one mini mall, you are constantly evolving and adding nodes or factories or just a lot of stuff. Eventually you have whole planets making sails, another building rockets and multiple full iron ingot smelting planets. Think bigger than just a planet, don't limit yourself in this game. Once you unlock the new miners you can literally set up your power grid and drop the buggers all over the place move on, next thing you know you don't have enough smelters to deal with the ore, so then you expand all your smelting, and on up it goes till you have full solar systems devoted to making white matrix and consuming them. I wish I could find a solution to getting so much stuff the game slows down, eventually is unplayable and you have to start all over again.

Have a great time in this game,

Good strong game! 3 STARS out of 5.
I've had a good long time with this game now and started last year with a very early release. Here are my takes and gives...
PROS:
-Innovative resource management / building game. 
-Build at your leisure and with your goals in mind
-Truly colossal building potential with extraordinary energy generation potential.
-Research into technologies and upgrades follows a logical pathway and bridges the gap of unrealistic reality. 
-Use strategy to make your factories efficient - you'll need it so you don't break you computer (more later)
-Stacking, 'painting', the new miner and blueprints have made huge improvements to the play and possibilities.
-BLUEPRINTS! BLUEPRINTS! BLUEPRINT! This games would not be playable without them in my opinion. Yes, you can have small creations but if you are truly thinking on a BIG scale you won't survive. I played a couple hundred hours without them and believe me they are a welcome addition!
CONS:
-Conveyor belt construction is horrible. I have nothing good to say to about this system. You loose 1 whole STAR on my rating for the poor building construction in this game. I have 2000 hours now of dealing with this contempt for players and it is the weakest link. To be fair I don't believe the game studio has contempt for the player but this is an area where you feel like it. 
-Rail gun control. You can set up an incredibly complex supply and distribution network in this game. You can call out and order for any item you make from across the star cluster instantly but you can't tell any kind of grouping of rail guns to change an orbit. You must click each individual gun and change it. To put this in perspective.... I'm now on my 70th TW of energy production between two star clusters. I have rail guns in the tens of thousands and you want to make me change each one individually! To be fair you only have to build it once then make a blueprint but I DID ALREADY! This is another area you may feel contempt for the player during game play.
-Main Character. I personally don't like the main character in this game at all. I couldn't remember the last game I played where I disliked (to put it mildly) the main character so much. This largely has to do with the character abilities or lack there of. The character is a big oaf! It's like steering a cruise ship and lacking in style and any semblance of grace.  It's like pulling around a big lead weight that you have to have with you to do anything. He's got an impressive power core no doubt but he can only muster a 5W flashlight to help you do your work. That kind of sums it up. 
-CPU FPS; Depending on how you choose to play this game you may likely choose to see how much energy potential you can harness as I did. Be advised that this game will eat up your CPU and bottleneck. At the time of this review I have about 500 hours of play for a factory that consumes about 100 GW and has a total energy potential of 44.5TW. I am down to a dismal 11 FPS! I'm running a AMD 5600X, 32 GB 3600 RAM, GTX1080, 2 TB NVME. 4 of my 12 threads run about 85% while the rest are about 40%. My GPU is now only at about 40% where it was full throttle in the early part of the game. I honestly don't know how much longer I can play. I'm done building (I've done almost everything I want to do) so I will just let it run for a while-Maybe 60-70TW).  
CONCLUSION: This is a really good strong game and there is a reason I've been engrossed in it for 2000 hours. There's so much to say but you can find that out for yourself. I would recommend this game for sure. Just understand there are very rough spots in my opinion. 
STRATEGY: Completely up to you! If you want some good solid general recommendations read on.
-Realize the potential of your star cluster! Take the extra time to click through random generations until you come across some with high levels of Type O stars. These play off the best. If you can get a blue giant in there too you are golden. You may not even be able to finish a blue giant so don't be greedy.
-Don't rush in! Build your initial needs in modesty. Use the resources you do have to get all of your tech and necessary upgrades done first! This will save you time in the long run and once that is done you  are off to the races with nothing to stop you and no worries to upgrades in massive factories.
-Work to build modular factories for a specific purpose and output. Build stand alone modular rocket, sail, anti-matter fuel rods and paint. Work on making them most efficient you can then make blueprints.
-You can build modular factories to fit 1/8 sections of the globe and give yourself the potential of getting 8 factories on one planet. One of my planet rocket factories makes 1650+ rockets a minute and is 8 individual rocket factories that operate completely separate from each other.
-Make sure you are keeping your supply up to the demand. Specially with the paint. You can bring down your whole star cluster without it if you are using it and you should!
-Paint only top tier items and..... sails! Yes you will need large amounts of paint so plan on making a number of modular factories. 
-Don't overdue the warp drive. You can get going too fast and it becomes a liability when your FPS drops (and it will) if you make a big factory. 
-Use the vast majority of your early upgrades on mining, drones and transport speed. These give the best benefit during early game play. 
-NUMBERS: This is a numbers game and to get big you have to make a lot of things. At 500 hours of my second complete game play through I have the following numbers to give you and example of what to expect to achieve about 45TW. I took a very leisurely approach to building.
Iron Ingot - 2.64G, Silicone Ingot - 1.20G, Hydrogen - 3.47G, Rockets 46.3M, Sails 1.22G

Lots more to be said but you can find that out on your own. Happy building!!

Essentially Factorio in space.

A couple of things are a bit more streamlined than in Factorio: there are no different inserters for different distances/filters, there is no separate system for liquids, the transportation across planets is way less finicky than the train system of Factorio (although also less satisfying when it works). The Endgame of DSP is also nicer, because in Factorio you essentially have to make your own goal, while here the longterm goal is clear: build a Dyson Sphere.

There are however also a bunch of things that are less well worked out. Because you are working on a sphere, it is much harder to reuse parts of your factory, as different tropic zones have different grid sizes. This means much more must be constructed manually. There is also much less fine-grained control over the logistics system, and no logic systems to do some more custom logic. There are also a bunch of things that are still very much early access, such as the bad English translations.

Overall, I really like this game, but Factorio is the more polished and well thought through one.

Cons:

* Absolutely horrible English translation. There are some sentences that are completely illegible. Even the tutorial voice guy just reads his lines as if straight through an old version of Chinese to English google translate. Fortunately, the game as a whole doesn't rely too much on text.
* Some missing quality of life tools. For example a map search function to find stuff in your factory would have been great. And a personal logistics functionality like Factorio.

Pros:

* Very well optimized. It runs well even on several generations old hardware. Considering how much is going on in the game I feel this is a big achievement for the devs.
* Catchy and environment dependent music.
* Keeps being interesting and engaging until very late game.

(early access review)

A production chain game. Currently, the first thing to do is get the Icarus PhD achievement. Then you should build a sphere - the size of which depends on your aspirations. 

You will be able to see and observe the entire process from up close, which can be rather inspiring and simply beautiful. The entire "space mechanics" part of the game is great. 

A setup of about 200/min of small carrier rockets is recommended + extra solar sail. Once the sphere is done you can make another and another... Nothing else to do.

IF you setup everything perfectly there is nothing much to be done while the sphere is being built - it can take a lot of time. Depends... This is more or less it, currently.

It is very important you stick to the production ratios otherwise you will just waste your time, going around in circles. Go to dsp-wiki to see Recipe and Building quick reference.

Make your construction area between "Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn".

Pay attention to stuff such as belt capacity. Like L3 belt being able to handle the output of max 15 arc smelters where each unit takes 1 seconds to produce. Feeding 30 arc smelters in a row, on a single L3 belt, is only doable once all the stacks are researched. Casimir crystal production will gobble up tons of hydrogen, even with max stacks researched you can not put too many in a row...

Hopefully the game will evolve, with some story, plot twists, additional industrial mechanics/options/aspirations etc

It's a rare thing for me to review a game, but this game begs for a review.  I've only played 10 hours, but have LOVED every minute.  It strikes me as a release build because it's so polished and bug-free.  It has a spectacular concept and reminds me of a game from the 90's called Ascendancy, but with far more depth and nuance.  It's part puzzler (base design), resource management and problem solving.  The learning curve really isn't all that terrible.  Only real problem I had was figuring out how to transfer resources to other base structures, but once that was overcome everything else was pretty simple.  The translations are a bit rough, but is easy enough to understand what they're trying to say.  It's a very relaxing, enjoyable play that really keeps you thinking.

Overall, this game will devour your free time because it's so chill and fun.  The 5 developers deserve every cent they earn for this amazing title and zen game concept.

The idea to bring Factorio style gameplay to a galactic scale is amazing. This makes researching upgrades meaningful since not only are you awarded through new buildings, you're also upgrading your mech for more efficient interstallar travel. 
Finding rare resources in outer space, travelling tens of lightyears and thinking ahead - bringing with you an inventory filled with the correct items and materials to setup a self-sufficient mining colony - is immensely satisfying. 
In contrast to this, making the Dyson Sphere is kind of meh. 
If it had more functions than giving energy, things might be different. 
Still, it looks cool. And you can always build multiple Dyson Spheres. 
Currently the weakest part of the game IS THE ENDGAME. There should be more to the Dyson Sphere. 
There should be lategame super important cool items that require turning entire planets into factories just to make that one specific item.
There should be automation available in the form of bots - ultra lategame options for sending pre-programmed bots to convert planets into factories.
There should be a way to manipulate stars, altering their power output or creating other sorts of anomalies.
There should be exotic ways to harness black holes in some way.
And the very endgame should have the map expand into an infinite universe... where the player realizes they will never have enough time to colonize everything... only to discover one last technology to be researched which allows for swarms of interstellar bots to convert planets into factories en masse. 

Ah, a man can dream :D

So much potential! But the game's great in its current form too. I just wish it had more automation options for more massive scale.

You can also unplug ALL GAME Controllers and Bluetooth devices as this game does not like them. What would make this game perfect for me.

1.) Cosmetics and Decoration - I feel sad when I can't decorate a fully working factory. All of your machines are just out in the open.

Praise the Sphere

------

Dyson Sphere Program is a work in progress game. Not everything in the game completed, but for the most part, the game is absolutely playable. The most irritating issue for me is that there are only English and Mandarin translations. The player must add their native language as a mod. Building a Dyson Sphere is one of the most profound experiences I have ever had playing video games.

This game is a like a cross between Satisfactory and Factorio because of its graphics and mechanics. Looking at gameplay footage pre-purchase will help you to understand what I mean. 

Gameplay: The numbers are for the most part easy to work with, however, there are some challenging recipes that can cause you to go absolutely nuts. This game can take up a majority of your time, I had a huge number of hours in a small amount of time before I largely stopped playing and moved on to other games like Factorio and Satisfactory which have both more grind and content.

Overall, I would rate this game a WIP/10. I will not be able to correctly judge DSP until it is completed and is published to everyone. I would recommend that you buy it, however, as it is a fantastic game.

Note: Due to the early access nature of this game, it is not feature complete - and so is subject to change.

In short, this game so far is the meeting point of Factorio's detailed factory planning and construction and Satisfactory's gorgeous 3d visuals. All bent towards the goal of eventually conquering your little corner of the galaxy by creating a titular Dyson Sphere (or more than one). 

While combat of some form has been stated to be a major goal of this game, the current state of being able to create, plan, and endlessly tune (and troubleshoot, in my case) your factory to be as efficient as you can make it has a relaxing, thoughtful quality that I don't quite get from this games' inspirations. 

Despite the game's early access nature, the gameplay feels very well-tuned, and the visuals are already spectacular - even on my aging hardware. No game I've seen so far has been quite so awe-inspiring with it's visual spectacle. What makes it all the more satisfying is the thought that it's a spectacle you, as the player, create for yourself - instead of having it dumped on you like in so many action games.

From your humble beginnings on the starting world, to watching your arrays of magnetic cannons fling solar sails into orbit for your dyson swarm, or arrays of launch sites sending flight after flight of payloads to the dyson sphere proper, the visuals never stop being gorgeous, and become even more awe-inspiring the closer you get to your goal.

What issues this game has so far are rather minor. The localization on the voice-over could use some work, but is still easy enough to understand. I have concerns for the upcoming combat mechanics, but am withholding judgement for the time being.

I love this game. It is gorgeous. It's very derivative conceptually of Factorio's belts / logistics systems / iron plates -> iron gears sorts of things. But it's also completely new because of the latitude regions, the orbital characteristics of the planets actually influence building behavior in a meaningful way.. it's just fun!

Old negative review was because of a Unity engine bug they took several months to resolve which caused the game to go from perfect to unplayable for me. Keyboard inputs were just never bound, didn't work regardless of which device, USB port, or whatever. I can't type anything in the game, move with WASD, can't exit the tech screen without keyboard (only button is Escape..)... but I could Alt-Tab and type into notepad or other Unity games or whatever. Just a bad ver. I missed the game while it didn't work.

I sat on this game for a while in my wishlist because I've stopped buying early access games. A couple weeks ago, I decided to go ahead and pick it up, why not.

This. Game. RULES.

Early Access in name only. This is a fully fledged, incredibly deep management sim with beautiful progression. The game is paced incredibly well, slowly moving you up in complexity and (playfully) forcing you to interact with all of the varied mechanics that you will eventually need to master. 

Nothing more satisfying than starting from a lone robot picking up stones to building a galaxy-wide empire that results in a beautiful dyson sphere.

Really a phenomenal game. I can't recommend it enough. Can't wait to see where it goes from here!
